  10. Solve case-studies using the rules of international criminal law (problem 7);
  11. Analyze the existing institutional framework of international economic law and some of its problematic dimensions
  12. Analyze international case law and, on this basis, form and give an independent opinion regarding the legal merits of individual cases;
  13. Examine opinions and comments of commentators concerning various topics of the course.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['E Kappenberg', 'EA van Gemert, MSc', 'prof.dr. W Schinkel']
text:
Inhoud Public issues are issues of public contestation whose formation often coincides with the formation of previously non-existent publics. This introductory core course studies the historical, geographical, socio-political and socio-technical aspects of such issues. We ask how issues are publicly imagined, and by which technological mediations and infrastructure this occurs. We also focus on the ways issues are intertwined with (potential) publics. This requires also that we investigate contemporary conceptions of the public sphere in an interdisciplinary way. In order to do so, you are made familiar with a number of key contemporary public issues, such as: climate change, racism, smart urban technologies, global drone warfare, sexism and contemporary neoliberal capitalism and the precarization of life.
These issues are analyzed by means of a conceptual vocabulary that centers on the social and material infrastructures (policy and politics, media, the internet, energy supply lines etc.) that underlie many public issues; the social imaginaries through which public issues come into being; the identities at stake in public issues; the interfaces that allow people to engage with such issues; and the investments and interests that are entangled with them. By means of this conceptual vocabulary, the course seeks to highlight the importance of composition in making things public, and to move from ‘the public’ and ‘the public sphere’ to the ongoing and uncertain constitution of a plurality of publics (policy makers are one particular public, or they can be part of publics). Publics, in other words, are composed out of a variety of people and things.
The course provides room for the development of your own engagement with public life and allows you to experiment with ways of unpacking the complexities of a public issue of your choosing in a paper.
  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will:
 
1. have insight into the main sociological theories and analyses of the contemporary public sphere
2. be familiar with cutting edge sociological approaches to the ways publics and issues emerge
3. be able to apply these approaches to a variety of current public issues
4. be able to write an academic paper on a current public issue and analyze it in sociological terms

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course brings together state-of-the-art theories on public knowledge, in-depth analyses of knowledge circulation in public issues, and exciting field experiments with inventive methods. The aim of this course is to develop your critical understanding of what knowledge can do in public issues. By studying exemplary cases and experimenting with methods, you will learn how research can itself be an intervention in and engagement with public issues.
As a start, you will become more familiar with a set of concepts and approaches that will allow you to analyze what knowledge can do. You will learn how methods, research and knowledge are performative: they do not disinterestedly describe but actively compose our common worlds and the issues through which we engage with it.
On this basis, you will be performing your own attempts at (re-)composing a public issue through social scientific research methods. Throughout the course you will be testing materials and methods as ways to intervene in public issues.
This course is expressly aimed at preparing you for your thesis trajectory. You’ll deepen your understanding of research methods, while also developing an initial mapping of the topic and field that you have chosen for your thesis. The final assignment of the course consists of a field exploration report that will become your launching pad into your master’s thesis research.
  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will:
 
1. be familiar with the main cutting edge sociological theories and analyses of knowledge and expertise
2. be familiar with the different modalities of public intervention
3. be able to make a sociological analysis of the ways knowledge figures in the staging of public interventions
4. be able to judge the performative role of knowledge claims in the public sphere
5. be able to set up and conduct a study of a public knowledge controversy

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. AM Kanas', 'dr. W Belabas', 'IM Duivenman, BA', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']
text:
Inhoud Hoe en waarom wordt een probleem een ‘beleidsprobleem’? Wat is beleid, en hoe wordt het ontwikkeld? Wie neemt er besluiten over beleid? Hoe kun je zorgen dat beleid ook echt wordt uitgevoerd? En op welke wijze kun je bepalen of beleid succesvol is geweest, of niet?

Deze vragen staan centraal in de cursus ‘Beleid’. De cursus laat studenten kennismaken met de ‘beleidscyclus’ en leert de student vanuit meerdere perspectieven (rationeel, politiek, cultureel en institutioneel perspectief) een analyse te maken van beleidsprocessen. Op deze wijze krijgt de student inzicht in de meervoudigheid van beleidsprocessen waarin kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties een rol spelen.

Ideaaltypisch worden maatschappelijke problemen geagendeerd (agendavorming), waarna politici doelen stellen en beleidsambtenaren bij deze doelen instrumenten selecteren (beleidsvorming en -besluitvorming), en uitvoerders deze instrumenten toepassen (beleidsimplementatie). Vervolgens wordt in de fasen toezicht, handhaving en evaluatie gecontroleerd of het beleid conform de intentie van beleidsmakers is uitgevoerd, respectievelijk of met het beleid het achterliggende maatschappelijke vraagstuk is opgelost. Tevens wordt aandacht besteed aan de factoren die ten grondslag liggen aan beleidsverandering.

Gedurende de cursus zullen de perspectieven op de beleidscyclus worden toegepast op diverse maatschappelijke problemen. Dit zal bijdragen aan een beter begrip van de weerbarstigheid en complexiteit van hoe beleidsprocessen in de realiteit plaatsvinden Leerdoelen Na afloop van het vak kan de student:
  • de assumpties en kernelementen van het rationele, politieke, culturele en institutionele perspectief op beleidsprocessen benoemen;
  • een analyse maken van de rol van kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties in beleidsprocessen
  • de verschillende fasen van de beleidscyclus herkennen en toepassen op concrete maatschappelijke problemen;
  • een analyse maken van hoe en waarom beleidsproblemen op de maatschappelijke, politieke en beleidsagenda komen, of waarom agendavorming juist wordt voorkomen
  • een analyse maken van processen van beleidsvorming en besluitvorming rond een concreet beleidsprobleem
  • een analyse maken van hoe beleid wordt uitgevoerd, met aandacht voor aspecten van implementatie, toezicht en handhaving
  • een analyse maken van hoe de effecten van beleid kunnen worden bepaald (beleidsevaluatie) en welke factoren een verklaring bieden voor beleidsverandering.
  • strategisch adviseren aan beleidsactoren die een lobby strategie willen ontwikkelingen in het kader van beleidsprocessen
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud It is often (if not always) not what we communicate but how we communicate. Getting our message across (especially verbally, when having merely a limited amount of time), within the context of a highly internationalized (business) world, can be a cumbersome task from a personal or organizational perspective. Humans make a business run. Personal development (in this case learning ‘to speak out loud’), theoretical knowledge and practical skills as such, are essential aspects nowadays. Having an interview for a new job, speaking ‘out loud’, presenting or pitching in front of the class or in a future work-setting, and even ‘worse’, speaking in front of a group of people on a set ’stage’ or even in the board room during company meetings, can be very challenging. Not possessing public speaking skills (theory, strategy and practice) can nowadays truly make or break someone’s career (prospects) and can cause serious, unnecessary anxiety issues, not to mention hinder the ‘sales of knowledge, service or product’ with (personal, social, economic, stakeholder relation etc.) consequences to follow....
 
Public Speaking essentials, involve verbal and written storytelling and communication theories and practices; pitching/presentation training; all in all, based on the understanding and practice of effective verbal, written and body language strategies within a 21st century international business context. Several scientific fields / studies and work field practices are relevant in this case. To name a few: Leadership-, Management-, Organizational-, Entrepreneurial studies, Sociology, (Positive) Psychology and of course Communication sciences. This seminar is a strategy and implementation oriented ‘training’ with relevant and specifically selected theory as an additional solid backbone to accommodate university students in their next step towards ‘real life scenarios’.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • What we can consider public speaking (types)
  • Why public speaking is essential in a globalized 21st century (individual and business) context
  • What characteristics of verbal (and written) communication we can consider important when willing to be effective communicators
  • The difference between public speaking and storytelling
  • The importance of storytelling and other verbal, written and body language methods in public speaking
  • Why cultural differences matter in public speaking
  • The practice of public speaking: How to effectively speak in public
 
Students have developed the skills to:
  • To understand the difference between effective and less effective public speaking
  • To use storytelling in public speaking
  • To implement other, verbal, written and body language methods in public speaking
  • To be confident when speaking in front of a smaller or larger group of (multi-cultural) individuals
  • To be able to identify personal setbacks, fears and other blockages and potentially how to mitigate those to be effective in public speaking
  • How to communicate a properly structured text in public speaking (writing and by heart)
  • To evaluate the (inter-cultural) context within which public speaking takes place
  • To evaluate and learn from other public speakers

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. F Van De Putte', 'dr. FH Wijen', 'dr. HCK Heilmann', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Inhoud This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
  • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
  • What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
  • What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
  • How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?
Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed. Leerdoelen The goal of this course is a refresher about the core methodological issues and choices in empirical research. It focuses on specifying and defending decisions about the research strategy (experiment, survey, case study), case/sample selection, and data analysis.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['JJS van der Meer', 'prof.dr. S van Thiel', 'R Warsen']
text:
Inhoud Publiek management is het managen van publieke organisaties. Het gaat dan om twee soorten management. Ten eerste, het interne management ofwel de bedrijfsvoering van publieke organisaties. Dat betreft zaken zoals organisatiestructuren en -typen, personeel, financiën, communicatie, ICT, strategie en bedrijfsvoeringtechnieken. Ten tweede, het externe management ofwel het aangaan en onderhouden van contacten met tal van stakeholders, burgers en de politiek.
In dit vak gaan we in op beide soorten management in een serie colleges, kennisclips en praktische voorbeelden. De opgedane kennis wordt getoetst in een schriftelijk tentamen en toegepast in een groepsopdracht over een echte publieke organisatie. Daarbij kijken we niet alleen naar de overheid in enge zin, maar naar de publieke sector in de volle breedte.
  Leerdoelen Aan het eind van deze cursus is de student in staat om:
  • Verschillende onderdelen en vormen van publiek management te benoemen en in eigen woorden uit te leggen;
  • Organisatiestructuren en -typen te herkennen en de voor- en nadelen ervan te benoemen
  • Verschillende stadia van strategievorming te herkennen en adviezen te formuleren over de toepassing ervan door publieke organisaties;
  • Meerdere bedrijfsvoeringtechnieken te benoemen en de toepassing ervan te beoordelen of daarover te adviseren aan publieke organisaties;
  • Meerdere methoden voor extern management te benoemen, te herkennen in de praktijk en de voor- en nadelen ervan te benoemen;
  • Te adviseren aan publieke organisaties over het aangaan en onderhouden van contacten met stakeholders, burgers en de politiek; en
  • Kritisch te reflecteren op het managen van publieke organisaties en theorieën of modellen daarover.
Belangrijk om te weten Studenten worden geacht in groepen een analyse te maken van de inhoud en het functioneren van een strategisch plan van een door hen te kiezen publieke organisatie

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Leiderschap is een ‘hot’ onderwerp, waarover tal van wetenschappelijke en niet-wetenschappelijke publicaties verschijnen. Ook binnen de bestuurskunde is veel aandacht voor het thema waarbij wordt beargumenteerd dat de positie en rol van (publieke) managers door allerlei (externe) ontwikkelingen is veranderd.

De module begint met een inleiding over leiderschapstheorie waarna vervolgens een verdieping volgt op basis van het boek Van Wart. Daarnaast kijken we ook specifiek naar enkele actuele ontwikkelingen in leiderschap aan de hand van enkele wetenschappelijke artikelen. Daarbij staan we ook nadrukkelijk stil bij de invloed van de publieke context op leiderschap.
  Leerdoelen • Op het einde van dit opleidingsonderdeel kunnen de studenten verscheidene basisbegrippen, methoden en instrumenten m.b.t. tot (publiek) leiderschap benoemen en begrijpen ze de samenhang;
• Op het einde van dit opleidingsonderdeel kunnen studenten hun opgedane basiskennis gebruiken om de verschillende theorieën over leiderschap te herkennen, te begrijpen, uiteen te zetten en met elkaar te vergelijken;
• Op het einde van dit opleidingsonderdeel kunnen studenten beredeneren welke consequenties een publieke context heeft voor het geven van leiding;
• Op het einde van dit opleidingsonderdeel kunnen studenten analyseren of een publiek leider beschikt over de vereiste competenties om effectief te opereren in een publieke context.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AG Nikulina', 'dr. LSG Ried, MSc', 'FZ Chen, MSc', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In its very essence, purchasing involves everything one receives an invoice for. But what is the more substantive definition of this business process, particularly from a management point of view? Over the years, numerous definitions have been provided for Purchasing and Supply Management (PSM). In broad strokes, one could depict the development of definitions over time as moving from more operational, to tactical, to more strategic. We define PSM as “The design, initiation, control and evaluation of activities within and between organisations aimed at securing inputs from suppliers at the most favourable conditions.” (Van Raaij, 2016; Wynstra, 2006). 

Central in any definition of purchasing and supply management is the process (at least as final objective) of acquiring inputs. As such, the economic transactions between actors are at the heart of purchasing and supply management. This is also the core difference with logistics or supply chain management, which focus on planning and controlling the amounts, routes and timing of flows of goods and services and associated information. 

As a management activity, purchasing and supply has a quite rich history. In the 18th century, the United East India Company (in Dutch: Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) already conducted make-or-buy analyses. While at a general level, the principles of purchasing and supply management may thus have remained largely the same, there are some particular areas of development in the last decade or so. 

There is a growing realization that purchasing and supply management can contribute not only to the ‘bottom-line’ of organisations, but also to the ‘top-line’. In other words, the buying organisation does not only seek to reduce costs but also to increase the revenue-generating potential of the acquired inputs.  Another development is that organisations place growing emphasis on strategy development at the level of so-called purchasing ‘categories’. More and more organisations apply an explicit approach to segmenting their spend in terms of characteristics such as financial importance and supply or technological risks, and apply explicitly differentiated strategies for the different segments. 

Last, but not least, PSM is changing due to the increasing digitalization. Digital procurement, or Procurement 4.0, brings new opportunities to the organisations, such as streamlined and simplified processes, data-driven purchasing decisions, and overall increased time for strategic activities. However, it also brings challenges: a complicated task to develop a suitable digital PSM strategy and choose appropriate IT solutions, but above all the need to rethink roles and skills of PSM professionals. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The objective of this core course is to provide students with the key concepts regarding purchasing and supply management. This course will cover the whole purchasing cycle, including strategic, tactical, and operational purchasing activities. Upon completing this course, students can: 
  • Explain the role of purchasing and supply management in the value chain; 
  • Analyse the relationships between buyers and supplier in a supply chain; 
  • Compare and apply different outsourcing and purchasing (category) strategies; 
  • Identify alternative approaches to enhance the sustainability of supplier relationships; 
  • Select appropriate types of contracts and justify their applicability; 
  • Define and apply supplier selection criteria and negotiation strategies; 
  • Identify and apply supplier development actions; 
  • Explain the importance of the effective an efficient organization of  operational purchasing process for organizations; 
  • Select effective organizational forms and performance indicators for purchasing given the business context.

Inhoud

The content of each lecture is chosen one month in advance. It will always be a mathematical topic of interest and its applications.

Leerdoelen

Q.E.D. or QED is an abbreviation for the Latin phrase "quod erat demonstrandum" ("that which was to be demonstrated"), a notation which is often placed at the end of a mathematical proof to indicate its completion.
The QED lecture series are extracurricular lectures. Needless to say, extracurricular means that presence is not required; these lectures are organized for all impatient students who do not want to wait too long to see how all mathematics you learn is used in practice, and for those students who are eager to know a bit more than the material which is strictly needed for the exams. The lectures will be in English but provided for all first-year Econometric students.
Each month there will be a lecture of one hour organized on a mathematical topic, given by various professors.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Deze module bouwt voort op de module ‘Ontwerpen van Sociaal Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek’ waarin studenten kennis hebben gemaakt met methoden en technieken van bestuurskundig en sociologisch onderzoek. Het vak bestaat uit hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. De module geeft studenten inzicht in het gebruik, de mogelijkheden en de beperkingen van kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden. Studenten verwerven kennis over het verrichten van kwalitatief onderzoek, en zij oefenen met diverse onderzoeksmethoden in de werkgroepen. Behandeld worden onder meer het opzetten van een goed onderzoeksdesign; de keuze voor en gebruikmaking van bronnen en methoden zoals interviews, audiovisuele data en digitale bronnen; dataverzameling, analyse en codering van het empirische materiaal en de rol daarbij van hulpmiddelen zoals memo’s, kwalitatieve datamatrices en computerprogramma’s zoals Atlas.ti. Leerdoelen Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
  • de keuze voor kwalitatief onderzoek onderbouwen op basis van wetenschapsfilosofische en methodologische overwegingen;
  • de sterkten en zwakten benoemen van een breed scala aan kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden;
  • alle stappen noemen die gezet moeten worden bij het maken van een onderzoeksopzet;
  • beredeneren welke kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethode het beste past bij een gegeven probleemstelling;
  • systematisch data verzamelen (o.a. interviews of geschreven bronnen)
  • verschillende kwalitatieve analysetechnieken toepassen;
  • de structuur en criteria van een onderzoeksrapportage benoemen.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The following topics are covered in this course in 4 consecutive weeks: (1a) qualitative “versus” quantitative research; (1b) measurement and operationalization in qualitative research settings; (2a) data collection: interviews, participant observation, textual documents, unobtrusive data, and visual materials; (2b) data analysis: data reduction, causal inference, and qualitative data analysis software (NVivo, Atlas.ti, fs/QCA, et cetera); (3a) ethnography; (3b) grounded theory methods; (4a) case study methods; and (4b) content analytical methods and discourse analysis.
Leerdoelen

The goal of this course is to equip students with the intellectual baggage necessary for the design, execution, and publication of truly excellent qualitative research studies. The emphasis in this course will be on getting acquainted with: (a) the canonical steps of the qualitative research process in general, and (b) four exemplary qualitative research designs in particular.
Central to this course is that students acquire an advanced understanding of the qualitative research process in general, and of several commonly used qualitative research designs in particular. Students are also expected to get acquainted with and learn how to use qualitative data analysis programs, such as NVivo, Atlas.ti, DICTION, fs/QCA, or MAXQDA.

course_title: Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. AM Diallo', 'dr. AMM Hermans', 'dr. G Evolvi', 'dr. J Vanhaelemeesch', 'dr. JF Pereira Campos', 'dr. JH Pridmore', 'dr. M Avraamidou', 'dr. YK Nguyen', 'FM Bellaard, MA', 'JK Herkommer']
text:
Inhoud In order to understand, analyze and make sense of diverse changes in the social world, research is paramount. This course aims to provide theoretical and applied knowledge in the different methods of qualitative social scientific research and an understanding of how to analyse and interpret the data gathered through these methods. This course first focuses on methods of qualitative data collection (e.g., focus groups, interviews, observation) and then on different forms of qualitative data analysis and interpretation. Within a qualitative tradition students will increase their skills in developing a comprehensive qualitative research plan and should be able to critically assess the methodological approaches of published qualitative research. The focus within this course is on developing students’ abilities to design their own research using qualitative methods for use in their future research courses and thesis development.
 
Note: Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • How and when to use common qualitative research methods in the field of media and communication;
  • The benefits and challenges of these methods;
  • How to develop a research design and how to collect and analyze qualitative data.
  • An understanding of the relationship between theory, methodology and methods in qualitative research.
Students have the ability and/or propensity  to:
  • Critically evaluate qualitative research in terms of methodological soundness;
  • Develop a qualitative research design;
  • Collect and analyze qualitative data;
  • Present qualitative research plans in a systematic and clear manner.

Inhoud
The course aims to acquaint students with key qualitative research methods, their application as well as conceptual underpinnings. Students learn what kind of research questions can be effectively addressed by qualitative methods. Participants of the course learn how the application of qualitative methods allows one to move from collecting information to its analysis. Course materials highlight that the application that qualitative methods spans not only across disciplinary boundaries but also across both empirical and interpretivist traditions in social and behavioural sciences. The course shows that qualitative methods adhere to the same ‘excellence criteria’ as quantitative approaches do, namely validity and reliability, as well as being able to provide a poignant critique of existing social order and practices. By focusing on contemporary societal and environmental challenges, students will learn how qualitative methods can be of help not only in identifying causes of these problems but also contribute to the development of their solutions. Throughout 7 lectures and 7 seminar sessions students will get acquainted with various forms of qualitative data collection, sampling and analysis, namely various forms of cases studies and process-tracing, interviews and focus groups, ethnography, discourse and qualitative content analysis, visual methods, fieldwork as well as the potential ethical challenges that the application  of these instruments entails. The lectures embed qualitative methods in various research traditions as well as highlight strengths and weaknesses of particular approaches. The seminars will introduce students to the application of qualitative methods as well as acquaint them with examples of best practice in using distinct qualitative approaches.
 
Open to exchange students: no
Leerdoelen The goal of this course is to equip you with basic knowledge of the principles of the scientific method and the most important methodological concepts in the social and behavioral sciences. With this knowledge and hands-on practice, you will be able to evaluate research articles in terms of their methodological quality and design your own research. The course will give you insight into the current controversies surrounding the integrity of research in the social and behavioral sciences. It will also prepare you for subsequent courses on statistics and a capstone project where you will apply all this methodological and statistical knowledge and skills in performing your own research project.
 
You will gain knowledge of:
  • the scientific method, its principles, and criteria for evaluation
  • the most important types of research and research designs
  • measurement, measurement methods, and criteria for evaluation of measurement instruments
  • sampling and sampling techniques
  • ethics and integrity in science
 
You will gain experience in:
  • evaluating research articles in terms of their methodological quality
  • identifying solutions for methodological weaknesses found within (published) academic articles
  • establishing your own research question
  • proposing a research design for a given research question

lecturers: ['dr. IH Casteren van Cattenburch', 'dr. S Wendel']
text:
Inhoud

This course introduces students to various qualitative research approaches applied across various contexts and topics. You will learn about data collection, analysis and interpretation in qualitative research. In this course theory and hands-on practical experience will be blended to provide students with a good basic understanding to work on their own qualitative research project(s).

Leerdoelen

The course objectives are (1) for students to understand various qualitative research methods and their underlying philosophical assumptions, (2) for students to understand the difference between qualitative and quantitative research method approaches, (3) to expose students to hands-on applications of qualitative research methods.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This course will be offered for the first time this year. Extra Course participation requirement
To participate in this course you need to be able to physically come to campus for the duration of the course. This is necessary to be able to meet the requirements of the assignment. Hence, do not choose this course if you are unable to come to campus for (part of the) course, for example because you are abroad. You will not be able to successfully complete the assignment which means that you cannot pass the course.

Inhoud Why do people do what they do? People can have many different motives for doing things and
often construct their life worlds with others. Qualitative research is specifically suited to study the
meaning systems of the participants in social life. In this course you will take the approach of the
qualitative researcher. We will introduce you to the fundamentals of qualitative research and
different qualitative research methods. Like all skills courses, we use a hands-on approach: in teams
of 3-4 students you will think of a theoretically relevant research problem, write an interview
protocol and then go out to conduct interviews. For data analysis, you will learn about analytical
methods based on the Grounded Theory approach, start to code your own data using the software
program Atlas.ti, and identify and analyse patterns across the data. At the end of the course you
will outline your findings (your theory) in a research report and also present them to your fellow
students in our mini-conference. Leerdoelen At the end of the course, you will be able to:
  • Connect your research question to relevant theory
  • Discuss the appropriateness of different data collection methods for qualitative research questions
  • Design, conduct and analyze semi-structured interviews
  • Analyze semi-structured interviews using the software program Atlas.ti
  • Write your own research report

course_title: Qualitative research in Strategic Management & Strategic Entrepreneurship
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The challenges of qualitative research such as case studies are widely underestimated. While it is obvious that quantitative research cannot be conducted without mastering relevant statistical or mathematical techniques, many researchers engage in qualitative research without having the requisite knowledge and skills. This course seeks to endow prospective researchers with the insights needed to adequately perform one type of qualitative research: case studies.

It seems easy to collect and analyse cases, because information about business organisations is abundantly available and all students have a certain experience in interpreting and writing texts. However, a number of thorny issues render qualitative research a challenging task. First, how to know whether the focal research topic lends itself to the use of this type of research? Second, if qualitative research is indeed a suitable method, how to determine what data are most relevant and how to access those data? Third, once all data has been gathered, how to reduce the vast amount of data to manageable proportions and how to make sense of the data? Fourth, after the data analysis, how to report relevant findings in an insightful way? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting qualitative research (such as case studies). Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • To create understanding when qualitative (especially case study) research methods are appropriate
  • To develop the ability to select and tap into different qualitative data sources
  • To develop the skills to systematically analyse qualitative data
  • To develop the skills to report findings from qualitative (especially case study) research in a structured and concise yet complete way

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. JDH van Wijngaarden', 'dr. MB de Graaff', 'dr. RLE Wehrens', 'MJC Aspria, MSc', 'prof.dr. DMJ Delnoij', 'prof.dr. HM van de Bovenkamp', 'prof.dr. IP Leistikow', 'prof.dr. RA Bal']
text:
Inhoud Quality and safety are very much on the agenda of health care governance throughout the world. In this course we engage students to actively explore theoretical backgrounds to, as well as the major themes of, quality and safety governance. In general, the course takes the position that quality and safety in health care are emergent properties that need continuous work. Consequences of specific interventions to improve quality and safety are often unpredictable, hence we take the position that a straightforward ‘how to’ improve quality and safety is, at best, not very productive. Instead, we emphasize in this course the need for both ‘top-down’ and ‘bottom-up’ approaches to quality and safety, and place particular stress on theories of the 'middle' - the level where the work of management and leadership usually resides. The course explores six challenges that come from this 'mangle of the middle'. These challenges are said to face each quality and safety improvement effort, and can be structural, political, cultural, technological, emotional and educational.

Taking these challenges and their relations as a core theme, the course invites students to explore amongst themselves, and with their tutors, several recent cases of quality and safety improvement efforts. Guided by given concepts and theories, students formulate their own questions about and answers to these cases, and while doing so they can explore strategies and instruments that can be taken in dealing with each challenge. 

Language: Obligatory literature and lectures are in English. Workgroups are in Dutch, assignments and the exam can also be written in Dutch. Leerdoelen The goals of the course are to give students an understanding of the theoretical backgrounds to and challenges of quality and safety in healthcare settings, to train students in reflexively working with these theories and in exploring specific quality and safety issues from a multi-dimensional perspective. Using active participation in class focused on professional behavior, peer review and a written take home examination, we aim for this course to help students in developing a self-reflexive and concrete academic mode of argumentation.

After this course you will be able to:
  • Critically appraise quality and safety issues in healthcare organizations based on critical organizational theory
  • Critically reflect on methods for quality and safety work in healthcare organizations
  • Develop a logically coherent argumentation based on scientific literature
Professionally lead and participate in meetings, using theoretical perspectives to substantiate your arguments

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. JDH van Wijngaarden', 'dr. MB de Graaff', 'dr. RLE Wehrens', 'MJC Aspria, MSc', 'prof.dr. DMJ Delnoij', 'prof.dr. HM van de Bovenkamp', 'prof.dr. IP Leistikow', 'prof.dr. RA Bal']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Relevance
In many situations, making decisions solely based on intuition does not suffice. Especially in situations with uncertainty, following your intuition might lead to suboptimal decision making. A structured and systematic approach based on sound analysis of the relevant data can improve the quality of the decision making process. In addition, making decisions based on intuition makes it hard for managers to justify decisions in the future, especially when decisions turn out to have negative consequences. This course provides students with the methods and tools to make better, more responsible, decisions. The methods and tools are not only discussed conceptually during lectures and exercise sessions, but are also implemented using spreadsheet modelling software.

Topics
In this course, we cover three main topics related to quantitative decision making:

Decision making under uncertainty
In many managerial decision making situations, there is uncertainty about the future consequences of a decision which makes the decision making more complex. This uncertainty can, for example, come from unknown future demand for new products. This course provides tools to improve decision making by structuring decision problems using pay-off tables and decision trees.

Monte Carlo simulation
In complex business situations, multiple uncertain processes are interrelated and together determine the outcome of a decision. A common mistake is to ignore the uncertainty and consider the average value of an uncertain process as its true value. This is called the flaw of averages. Monte Carlo simulation is a strong alternative method to analyze systems with interrelated uncertain processes and better account for the uncertainty.

Integer linear programming
Optimization is the process of selecting the best solution with respect to a given objective function satisfying a set of constraints. Companies often face optimization problems when deciding upon the best allocation of their resources. One of the most broadly applicable optimization techniques is linear programming. We introduce the main concepts of linear programming and discuss how to find optimal solutions both conceptually as well as with the use of spreadsheet models. Leerdoelen Content related learning goals
After successful completion of this course, students are able to:
  • Explain the most important concepts related to decision making under uncertainty and risk
  • Explain the most important concepts related to Monte Carlo simulation to analyze complex business systems with uncertainty
  • Explain the most important concepts related to modelling basic business decision problems as (integer) linear programming problems
Skills related learning goals
After successful completion of this course, students are able to:
  • Implement and analyze decision models using payoff tables and decision trees conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
  • Implement and analyze a Monte Carlo simulation conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
  • Implement, solve and analyze (integer) linear programming problems conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
Belangrijk om te weten Course structure
This course consists of three modules. Each module consists of 1 or more lectures and associated exercises. Each lecture covers the material for 1 week and is divided into 4 or 5 recorded videos. In total, each lecture contains approximately 1 hour of video material. For each lecture, a set of exercises is available which can be divided into two categories: written exercises and computer exercises. In the written exercises you are asked to apply the material to small problems that can be solved on paper. In the computer exercises you are asked to implement the material in Excel so that larger problems can be solved.

Each module is concluded with an online workshop in which the material is briefly repeated and part of the practice exercises will be discussed. These sessions take place on the Friday of the week in which the module ends (weeks 2, 3 and 6). On the other Fridays (week 1, 4 and 5) there is an online Q&A session in which students can ask questions to the teacher.

The course will be concluded with two exams: a computer exam and a written exam. Both exams will take place on the same day.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. M Pourakbar', 'dr. PL van den Berg']

After successful completion of this course, students have developed:
  • A critical attitude towards decision making processes by recognizing model and data limitations and common cognitive biases

Inhoud 
This course will not be given in the academic year 2022-2023 due to too few participants.

The elective course Quantitative Empirical Legal Studies aims to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge regarding the use of quantitative empirical methods to study empirical intuitions, questions and claims underlying legal analysis.
The students will learn different quantitative empirical designs and their relevance in gaining insights for the law. They will get acquainted with descriptive and inferential statistics and will be able to identify patterns of causality between phenomena through examples of experimental and observational methods (from the advantages of running an experiment to exploiting natural shocks in the law). The students will acquire knowledge on the types of data that exist and how to use them properly, understanding how to gather data and describe patterns or variations. The course also contains tutorials where students will learn how to use the statistical software STATA. At the end of the course, they will be able to create correlations and run different types of regressions, instruments that are essential to identify relationships between variables characteristic of legal problems. Finally, they will be able to distinguish when causality can be inferred from relationships present in their sample and when not.

The course is a hands-on course. Students will have both lectures and tutorials. The course will be active from week 10 to week 15, on Wednesdays and Fridays between 11 AM and 1 PM. In addition to individual assignments, students will attend their final exam in week 16.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. JJ Euwe', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. V Baptist']
text:
Inhoud
Quantitative skills are an important asset for historians. Data can be summarised in a clear manner using statistical techniques, empirical data can be accurately analysed using statistical programs and quantitative models can form the basis for testing theories. This course will deal with the collection, description and analysis of quantitative data. Many scientific articles are incomprehensible to researchers without a thorough knowledge of some basic statistical techniques. Moreover, the popular media also refer to quantitative data to provide insight into societal phenomena. Data and numbers are so important in contemporary society that academics should be able to cope critically with this kind of material.
 
Students will learn to interpret and perform statistical research in this course. This course mainly deals with descriptive statistics but some basic principles of interferential statistics will also be introduced. After a brief introduction about the collection and processing of quantitative data, different methods for summarising the data will be reviewed and practiced. Students will learn to create tables, draw graphs and calculate central tendencies and measures of dispersion. Index numbers, moving averages and trend lines are also covered in this course, as these are essential tools for understanding historical evolutions. During the second part of the course, students will discover how they can determine the relationship between two variables. Finally, they are also introduced to multiple regression analysis. These skills will be practiced in tutorials using SPSS. The assessment consists of a couple of assignments during the term and a final written examination in the PC labs.
 
Quantitative Historical methods is a mandatory course in the bachelor history at Erasmus University.

This course is in line with the specific profile of the history programme in Rotterdam with a strong emphasis on the connection with the social sciences. Most historians rely on qualitative methods, which are dominant in the humanities, but a social science approach urges historians to use quantitative methods. This course is programmed in the first term of the second year, because this enables students to make use of quantitative methods in their papers during the second and third year. Quantitative methods are for instance essential to understand historical analyses of economic developments, social inequality and international relations.
  Leerdoelen
This course has four main objectives:
  • Students can explain statistical terms and use these terms correctly in their own research.
  • Students can critically evaluate the use of statistical analyses in historical research.
  • Students can process historical data using SPSS and interpret the statistical analysis of these data.
  • Students can use the results of statistical analyses in research reports.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course has been designed to help students understand important and topical dilemma’s financial market participants face in real live and how academic insights can be used to solve these problems. The course builds on Financial Modeling course in which basic financial models have been discussed and implemented in MS Excel. The main features of the course are the following: (1) introduction to topical dilemma’s in the financial industry such as differentiating between alternative philosophies in setting up investment portfolios and the implementation of sustainability, (2) the use of both classical studies and latest insights from the stream of literature on empirical asset pricing to solve these problems, and (3) Problem-Based Learning.

This course will cover topical and relevant topics in the financial industry that are put forward by authoritative financial institutions. The lecturers will rely on their networks in the financial industry and interview decisionmakers to understand the problems they face. This will facilitate students to understand real problems like gauging the value added of active managers; evaluating the performance of investment portfolios; understanding the economic rationale behind investment strategies and anomalies in financial markets; and the
dilemmas investors face when incorporating sustainability in their investment portfolios.

Through the course, both classical studies and the latest academic insights will be used to solve these problems. Developing a skillset to solve such problems will help students to better understand the nuances of the methods used, and facilitate placement of students at authoritative investment institutions.

The course aims at students that want to further develop their financial modeling skills and obtain deeper understanding of topical dilemmas in the financial industry. Although assignments need to be solved using MS Excel there are no specific requirements other than strong motivation. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After having followed this course students are able to build MS Excel models using best-practice modelling techniques, and using a wide range of MS Excel functionalities required for financial calculations and for presenting results, knowing which technique is appropriate for which purpose and knowing how to apply each technique correctly.

At the end of this course, students should:
  • Understand the concepts active, passive, and factor investing for setting up investment portfolios
  • Understand the complications of implementing sustainability in investment portfolio
  • Understand the techniques for constructing rank portfolios, performing returns-based style analysis, and optimizing portfolios under sustainability restrictions.
  • Understand how to use MS Excel to implement these techniques to solve the problems mentioned earlier.
  • Understand how to interpret and present key results of their empirical analyses.

lecturers: ['B Van Os, MSc', 'prof.dr. DJC van Dijk']
text:
Inhoud

This course provides an introduction to the field of Quantitative Finance by studying modern econometric techniques that are widely used in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management and derivatives pricing and hedging.
The course can be divided into three parts:

  • In the first part, we consider models for time-varying volatilities and correlations of asset returns, which are crucial inputs for quantitative risk management. We also consider concepts such as Value-at-Risk and Expected Shortfall of an asset or portfolio of assets. The most important techniques for computing and evaluating these risk measures are studied. Ample attention will be given to the practical implementation of these techniques.
  • In the second part of the course, we study factor models, which are commonly applied in asset pricing and portfolio management. For example, constructing a portfolio with optimal risk-return characteristics requires an estimate of the covariance matrix of asset returns. In practice the number of assets typically is large (100+), such that the number of unknown parameters becomes too large. Factor models then are an attractive way to reduce the dimensionality of the problem. Again, ample attention will be given to the practical implementation and use of these models.
  • In the third and final part, we provide an introduction to the most important derivative securities, including options, forwards and futures. Popular models for computing the fair price of these derivatives are discussed, while we also consider the use of derivatives for hedging risk involved in other assets.

This course uses knowledge of FEB22008(X) Markov Processes, FEB22017(X) Finance, and FEB23001(X) Time Series Analysis and is required for FEB23022 Seminar in Investing.

Leerdoelen
  • To understand modern quantitative techniques that are widely used in various financial applications such as portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing and hedging.
  • To obtain a broad overview of the field of Quantitative Finance.
  • To be able to apply econometric tools used in the empirical analysis of asset pricing models, and for portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing and hedging.

Inhoud

The quantitative models will be treated for

  • Facility location problems (with a single or two echelons)
  • Long-haul freight transportation problems (including network design)
  • Short-haul freight transportation problems (both node and arc routing)
  • Inventory management problems (both with deterministic and stochastic demand)
  • Warehouse design and operation problems

This course uses knowledge of FEB22002(X) Combinatorial Optimization and FEB22013(X) Simulation, and is required for FEB23014 Seminar in Quantitative Logistics.

Leerdoelen
  • To be able to understand, analyze and adapt quantitative models.
  • To be able to apply quantitative models for: facility location; inventory control; warehousing; vehicle routing; transportation.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The lecturers will focus on topics that are more technical in nature. For non-technical parts, students will sometimes be referred to the book and/or a video covering that material.

Inhoud

This course surveys modern finance theory as well as econometric and time series techniques that are used for modeling and forecasting (the term structure of) interest rates.
Topics include:

  • Bond market concepts: bond prices, interest rates, yields, forward rates and the term structure of interest rates
  • Empirical features of the yield curve
  • Theories of the term structure (expectations hypothesis, asset pricing theory)
  • Models of the term structure (Nelson-Siegel, Vasicek, CIR, Affine) in discrete and continuous time
  • Yield curve forecasting
  • Interest rate derivatives
Leerdoelen
  • To gain a profound and state-of-the-art insight into quantitative methods in fixed income, both from a theoretical and empirical perspective.
  • After passing the course, students have a solid knowledge of different models for the dynamic behavior of the term structure of interest rates and other fixed income products.
  • Students are able to apply advanced econometric tools for modeling and forecasting interest rates. In particular, they are able to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specification testing, and forecasting.

course_title: Quantitative Methods in Media and Communication
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['BG Zerebecki, MSc', 'dr. FGR De Keyzer', 'dr. J Kneer', 'dr. K Riskos', 'dr. L Zheng', 'N Maru', 'TTV Nguyen, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
This course aims at getting students involved in quantitative research. Students learn how to formulate appropriate research questions and hypotheses, how to operationalize key constructs, and how to use an online data tool (i.e., Qualtrics) for collecting data. Furthermore, students will learn how to write the Methods and the Results section of a scientific publication which uses quantitative data. Finally, students gain the knowledge of different data analyses (i.e., factor analysis, reliability analysis, ANOVA and mediation analysis using regression) by using SPSS and learn how to interpret results. 

The course has a dual structure. First, students gain a thorough understanding of a variety of commonly used quantitative research methods. Second, students engage in practicing on specific methods in-depth and analyze data using statistical analysis.
 
Note
  • Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication.
  • Students should have completed the course Introduction to Statistical Analysis (CM1005) before they may enter Quantitative Methods in Media and Communication.
 
Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • How and when to use common quantitative research methods in the field of media and communication.
  • The benefits and restrictions of these methods.
  • How to develop a research design and how to choose the right data analyses.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Critically evaluate research reports on its methodological soundness.
  • Develop a research design.
  • Identify the right method for data analyses.

Inhoud Data can be collected through a variety of methods: peering through a microscope, measuring brain activity, retrieving records from large databases, excavating ancient artifacts, etc.; the list is virtually endless. Often, the data collected are quantitative in nature. This course will provide you a solid foundation for making well-informed decisions from quantitative data and turn data into understanding, insight, and knowledge.
 
The skills you develop in this course include the collection, organisation, analysis, interpretation and presentation of quantitative data. Doing this by hand  is  often  slow,  tedious  and  error  prone. With the rise of information technology, powerful tools have been developed to support us conducting these activities. You will learn how to import and export data, explore and manipulate data (i.e. recoding, transforming, aggregating and combining datasets), and create data visualizations using freely available statistical programming tools. Furthermore, you will learn about basic statistical theory to draw valid inferences from your datasets.

Open to exchange students: no
Leerdoelen  After completion of this course you should master (i.e., know, understand and be able to explain) the following:
  • The major statistical indices used to describe variables and relations between variables;
  • The basics of probability theory;
  • How to draw statistically valid inferences about a population from samples;
  • How to use SPSS to process and analyze data, and make graphs.
Evidently, a single course cannot teach you all there is to know about statistics. In later years, depending on the major that you choose, more advanced courses on statistics (and research methods) will be offered.

Inhoud

The course focuses on modern, quantitative methods for measuring risks faced by financial institutions. It covers:

  • Various risk measures and risk measure theory (Value-at-Risk, expected shortfall, coherency)
  • General method used for quantifying risks (analytical method, historical simulation, Monte Carlo)
  • Market risk and risk aggregation (dynamic volatility model, normal mixture distributions, Extreme Value Theory, copula)
  • Model validation and backtesting
  • Credit risk (Merton model, threshold model, Bernoulli mixture model)
  • Systemic risk
Leerdoelen
  • To understand the risk management process from the perspective of financial institutions as the process by which various risk exposures are identified, measured, and controlled.
  • To understand various quantitative techniques and econometric theories that are widely used in financial risk management. The course focuses on modern, quantitative methods to measure and manage the risks faced by financial institutions.
  • To be prepared for the role of a risk manager in financial markets and to have necessary skills for future research in risk management.

course_title: Quantitative research in Strategic Management & Strategic Entrepreneurship
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In this course students will learn how to do empirical research. The course touches upon the fundamentals of research design and quantitative research, in addition to more advanced statistical tools. In addition to the lectures, a set of video tutorials provide deeper insights into the specifics of using statistical software and running various models therein. The course is attended jointly by students from two programmes: Strategic Entrepreneurship and Strategic Management.

This course seeks to provide students with the practical tools and theoretical vocabulary required to understand conduct, and critically evaluate quantitative empirical research. During the course, students are exposed to the key types of models, their assumptions, common data collection approaches, and statistical software needed to become a successful, independent researcher.

The following key questions are addressed in the course: First, what research design is the best fit with my research question? Second, how do I measure the concepts underpinning my research question? Third, what data do I need to collect to address this question, and what tools should I use to collect this data? Fourth, what statistical models are best suited to analyse these data? And, finally, how do I report the results of my analyses in a rigorous and statistically sound manner? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting quantitative research. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The course touches upon the following subjects and learning goals:
  • Understanding the key considerations in designing and implementing a quantitative empirical study.
  • Developing the skills to utilize the most appropriate statistical model and construct measurement.
  • Developing the vocabulary required to communicate research design choices and empirical results.
  • Developing the ability make an informed decision regarding different data approaches.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. S. Uitte de Willige', 'dr. S.E. Hoeks', 'dr. S.J. Baart', 'dr. S.P. Willemsen', 'MSc D.F. Nieuwenhuijse', 'prof. dr. D. Rizopoulos']
text:
Inhoud

Prerequisite: Participants are required to have followed the one of the following courses before participating in Module II. 
- PHDCO-013 Introduction to Biostatistics (Module I)
- MEP-CK020s Biostatistics I Spring 

If you have already followed MEP-CK020 Biostatistics I, we do not recommend to do this course, as the contents are similar and overlapping. 
For questions about the requirements, please contact Dr. Sara Baart s.baart@erasmusmc.nl. 

Course description 
R has recently become one of the most popular languages for data analysis and statistics. This course teaches students the basics of this statistical programming language. The aim of this course is to equip participants with the R knowledge needed to explore data, make data visualizations and perform simple statistical analyses. At the end of the course, the participants will have gained basic skills in R, such that they will be able to independently read data into R, bring it in the correct structure, visualize the data, perform basic statistical analysis and write simple R functions. This course is module II in the modules on statistics. Participants must have followed module I (Introduction to Biostatistics) and need this module to follow the courses on Survival analysis (module III) and prediction models (module IV). 

Learning goals  
After completing of the course, the participant should: 

  • Understand what R and Rstudio are, install them on their own PC/laptop, and know how to code in R; 
  • Be able to load in their data sets in R and perform different data transformations  to prepare the data for analyses; 
  • Know how to explore characteristics of their data set and visualize the data; 
  • Perform simple statistical analyses with R and interpret the results; 
  • Be able to write simple functions and loops to aid with data transformation and automation.

Assessments  
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course 
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.
Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.
The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.     
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’. 

Evaluation  
Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.  

Assignment  
All assignments will be made during the planned practical sessions in the course. There are no additional assignments. 

No certificates 
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved. 

Cancellation policy  
Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The 2022-2023 Honours Programme examines the various aspects of high-tech entrepreneurship, hypergrowth corporate strategies, knowledge transfer and innovation clusters.  Leerdoelen In general, students will collect broad and in-depth knowledge and insights around strategic entrepreneurship, innovation management and clustering from renowned faculty (at RSM) and industry experts in Silicon Valley. More specifically, participants will
  • explore best practices of start-up and/or corporate entrepreneurship and innovation of leading companies;
  • obtain essential know-how around early stage venture deployment, effective corporate venturing and successful university-industry-government collaboration
  • acquire important skill sets including Silicon Valley pitching techniques), effective consultancy capabilities, business idea development and business plan writing, successful fundraising, and entrepreneurial pro-activeness.
  • develop a thorough understanding of the dynamics and constituents of national and regional innovation clusters
  • will develop skills to analyze national and regional innovation clusters and understand how entrepreneurial ventures can benefit from these clusters.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This research workshop focuses on the relation between theory and research in the domain of cultural participation taken in the broad sense. The questions to be addressed can be summarized as: who engages in which cultural activities and why? Students formulate questions about (specific forms or patterns of leisure or) cultural participation and its relation to people’s socioeconomic background characteristics and formulate hypotheses on the basis of the relevant literature.
Subsequently, they employ data made available by the lecturer to test their hypotheses on social differentiation in cultural participation (be it museum visits, concert or theatre attendance, TV watching, reading, going out, etc), Statistical techniques for causal analysis will be used in order to determine which characteristics of respondents are actually determining their cultural taste or behavior.
Students produce a research report (individually or in duos) that includes a concise literature review on the topic to be analyzed, and a presentation and discussion of the statistical analyses carried out.
 
It is recommended to take this course only after the Statistics course has been completed successfully.
In this course, students learn to answer questions about cultural participation by analyzing existing quantitative data. After this research workshop, they are able to translate substantial questions into adequate statistical analyses and produce a sound report of their work. They learn to critically reflect on the (im)possibilities of empirical research and to interpret their results in light of the original research questions.

Inhoud The course deals with key concepts of rationality and choice:
- preferences and their interpretation, representation, and measurement,
- intertemporal decision-making,
- behavioural economics,
- game theory and its interpretation. Leerdoelen This course gives an advanced introduction to problems of rationality and choice. In doing so, we will encounter and analyse a number of foundational problems associated with both decision and game theory. After having completed this course, you will be able to:
(i) name, understand, and criticise key concepts in rational choice theory from a philosophical perspective and in terms of their role for the foundations of economic theory,
(ii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to decision theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,
(iii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to and uses of game theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,
(iv) critically evaluate and engage with philosophical and economic literature in rational choice theory and any literature in the humanities and social sciences that employs rational choice theory, in an independent way.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. M de Mul', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'prof.dr. WBF Brouwer']
text:
Inhoud If there is one problem that health care systems face and share, it is making the best use of the available resources in health care. Despite growing health care expenditures, there are never sufficient resources to meet all health care needs and demands. This means that health care somehow needs to be rationed. Baily (2003) defined rationing as follows:

“To limit the beneficial health care an individual receives by any means – price or non-price, direct or indirect, explicit or implicit.”

Hence, we somehow decide or organise that some care, that would benefit certain patients, is not provided (timely or freely). Although perhaps necessary and unavoidable, rationing (even the word itself) has been, is, and likely will remain a contentious topic in both politics and society.
This course focuses on this important topic mainly from an economic perspective, making use of behavioural economic insights. The topics that are discussed are rationing in general, demand and supply side rationing, and principles of rationing. Moreover, you will gain insight into how different countries ration health care. 
 
The course consists of 6 weeks of interactive lectures.

  Leerdoelen

To acquaint students with principles and practice of rationing health care from an economic perspective.

To provide a thorough understanding of supply side and demand side rationing and their advantages and disadvantages

To give insight in how different European countries deal with this difficult topic

Inhoud This is a transdisciplinary minor for students from Erasmus University, University of Leiden, Delft University, Codarts University of the Arts, and Willem de Kooning Academy.

In this minor, students from various fields and backgrounds develop theoretical competences in the area of transdisciplinary research and together with teachers and societal partners, a setting is created in which theory and practice, and academic and artistic practices interact to identify and reframe a complex societal issue. The minor facilitates the building of collaborative learning contexts and networks, with an emphasis on the involvement of societal partners (e.g. government, businesses, and civil society members). This encourages students to (further) develop an entrepreneurial attitude.

Students and teachers from Erasmus University College, Codarts and Willem de Kooning Academy will work together to create a collaborative framework that allows combining disciplines within a project situated in a specific context. The minor is suitable for open-minded, engaged and critical students who feel an urgency to work beyond disciplines and are keen to actively partake in shaping their learning process. This minor requires serious interest and an open and flexible attitude towards education. Students will collaborate continuously and intensively with their fellow students, teachers and societal partners, and take position as active, committed world citizens. This gives students the opportunity to engage in transdisciplinary, collaborative project-based research, in a small team of students and teachers from the fields of science, visual arts and performing arts, and together with stakeholders from beyond the academy/university. The minor is part of the innovative educational practices of the Rotterdam Arts and Sciences Lab (RASL). While exploring a complex societal issue (the selection of the issue is student-led) in depth and from a range of perspectives, students will develop creative, critical and other skills needed in the 21st century.

The minor is divided into two parts (15 EC + 15 EC). Students can either participate in Part I or in Parts I and II. It is not possible to participate only in Part II. EUC students can enrol in Part I (15 EC) as an EUR minor and opt to enrol in part II in their elective space.

This is a full-time minor, and the collaborative nature of the programme requires committed attendance and a flexible attitude throughout the entire process.

Open to exchange students: no

lecturers: ['dr. CB Binder', 'dr. CJ Clarke', 'dr. E Dekker', 'dr. F Van De Putte', 'dr. HCK Heilmann', 'dr. N Vrousalis', 'dr. S Wintein', 'G Boncheva', 'prof.dr. JJ Vromen']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

This subject explores the factors that shape contemporary Africa and its people, through the lens of multiple disciplines from the three participating institutions. The course objective is to gain a foundational understanding of significant factors that shape contemporary Africa, with the goal to establish a broad understanding of Africa’s past, present and future.

With time scheduled for discussions and debates, the seminars will foster a greater understanding of this extremely diverse and richly endowed continent. Students will receive further reading and references to online material to deepen their knowledge, and through creating a multimedia country profile they will showcase their ability to integrate different factors that shape an African country.

Leerdoelen

Upon successful completion students will have:

  1. Acquired a foundational understanding of:
  • Significant factors that shape societies and cultures in contemporary Africa;
  • Dynamic characteristics and diversity of African states and their people;
  • Africa’s role in a globalised world and the socio-economic and geo-political issues at play;
  • Methodological and ethical approaches to African studies.
  1. Developed skills and competencies to:
  • Critically search, structure and evaluate information about African states;
  • Consider relevant aspects in the analysis of complex questions;
  • Communicate own secondary research data through multimedia sources;
  • Reflect on how Africa’s past, present and future relates to own discipline.
  • Reflect on how Africa’s past, present and future relates to own discipline.

lecturers: ['CSA Westdorp', 'J van Haaren', 'MMY Omar, MSc', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']
text:
Inhoud

Real Estate Economics covers the economic processes underlying our built environment. Based on insights from Urban Economics we look at markets for residential and commercial real estate. In this course we cover land use and land pricing, hedonic pricing, implicit prices of urban amenities, land negotiations, zoning, development, valuation and real estate as a specific class of assets.

Leerdoelen
  • Reproduce and interpret theories and views on the spatial-economic development of cities and the functioning of urban land and real estate markets.
  • Reproduce and interpret theories on real estate economics, dealing with investment decisions and real estate development.
  • Apply economic reasoning to analyse current issues in the development of urban areas on various spatial levels: from region to neighbourhood to dwelling.
  • Apply theories, concepts and research methods from contemporary literature to practical examples.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Traditional exam reinstated instead of take-home essay.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In this course the focus is on financial topics related to Real estate investment and financing (corporate Real estate, commercial Real estate and residential). The course provides a theoretical framework to study these topics; ample empirical facts and actual practices of agents in Real estate and finance markets will show business relevancy.
 
This course prepares students to understand the risks and rewards associated with investing in and financing Real estate. There are three main topics:
  • Market analysis;
  • Real estate valuation, and most importantly,
  • Real estate finance.


Entry requirements or required background knowledge 
Students should have followed introductory courses in corporate finance (particularly discounted cash flow method) and investment before taking this course. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After having followed this course students should have
  • A thorough knowledge of the working of real estate capital and space markets;
  • The knowledge to identify and analyze different investment opportunities in these markets;
  • The skills and tools to apply the knowledge in practice.
