lecturers: ['dr. FL Stevens', 'FG Kwekel, LL.M', 'M van den Heuvel', 'mr. FJ Alvarez y Peña', 'mr. HJ de Kloe', 'mr. L Kirkpatrick', 'mr. LE Kooreman', 'mr. MN Kuijer', 'mr. O Kirman', 'mr. O Oost', 'mr. S Alatag', 'mr. SR Sripal', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'prof.dr. CM Stokkermans', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr. N van Tiggele - van der Velde', 'prof.mr.dr. AR Houweling', 'prof.mr.dr. MA Verbrugh']
text:
Inhoud Het vak bestaat uit twee delen. In het eerste deel van het vak – duurt tien weken – komt de basis van de rechtsgebieden aan bod. Op deze manier leren de studenten de kern van ieder rechtsgebied. Tijdens de hoorcolleges zal het verband tussen de verschillende rechtsgebieden aan de orde komen (integratie) als ook de spanningsvelden (confrontatie). Zo kan een rechtsregel in het ene domein een knelpunt vormen voor het andere domein (denk aan bescherming van werknemers versus vrijheid van ondernemerschap).

In het tweede deel van het vak – duur vijf weken – verdiepen de studenten zich in een rechtsgebied naar keuze. De studenten kiezen voor een aan het gekozen rechtsgebied gekoppelde bedrijf. Studenten gaan vervolgens groepsmatig en zelfstandig aan de slag om op projectmatige wijze de projectdossiers uit te werken en de bedrijven te voorzien van advies. Zij hebben daarbij de rol van juridisch specialisten/junior advocaten van een advocatenkantoor die het bedrijf van advies moet voorzien en worden ‘begeleid’ door hun patroon (docent). De adviezen worden door de studenten gepresenteerd aan het betreffende bedrijf. Zij leren daarmee de stof toe te passen in de praktijk en samen te werken. Leerdoelen Het vak Recht en Bedrijf draait om de samenhang van de rechtsgebieden Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht. Het vak duurt in totaal 15 weken (blok 4, 5 en 6) en bestaat uit twee delen. Het vak beslaat in totaal 21 EC.
Het doel van het vak is studenten (op hoofdlijnen) de juridische taal te leren spreken van het Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht, om vervolgens de verschillen en overeenkomsten tussen de drie rechtsgebieden aan de hand van concrete casus te analyseren. De student neemt als het ware de positie in van een bedrijfsjurist en is in staat de juridische knelpunten die zich in het bedrijfsleven op het snijvlak van Arbeids-, Handels-, en Ondernemingsrecht manifesteren te herkennen en een (begin van een) oplossing aan te dragen. Daarnaast leren studenten door middel van projectmatig onderwijs samen te werken. Ze leren de stof toe te passen in de praktijk door bedrijven te adviseren over juridische vraagstukken die bij deze bedrijven spelen. In dit tweede deel verschiet het perspectief van de bedrijfsjurist naar dat van de junior advocaat of juridisch specialist die door het bedrijf is ingehuurd een vraagstuk op te lossen.

O Kirman', 'mr. O Oost', 'mr. S Alatag', 'mr. SR Sripal', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'prof.dr. CM Stokkermans', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr. N van Tiggele - van der Velde', 'prof.mr.dr. AR Houweling', 'prof.mr.dr. MA Verbrugh']

Inhoud In deze Minor wordt u geprikkeld om op juridisch-medisch-ethische, sociaal-economische en communicatieve vraagstukken te reflecteren en om op grond van de geldende regelgeving en heersende morele opvattingen hier beargumenteerd over te kunnen discussiëren.
De gezondheidszorg beslaat inmiddels meer dan 10% van de nationale economie. Het is de sector waar verhoudingsgewijs het meeste geld in om gaat en waarin, ondanks de economische recessie, een spectaculaire groei van de werkgelegenheid is waar te nemen. In de afgelopen tien jaar groeide het aantal banen in de zorg met 385 duizend. Het totaal aantal banen in Nederland nam toe met 515 duizend. Drie kwart van de banengroei in het afgelopen decennium is dus toe te schrijven aan de zorg. De gezondheidszorg is sterk in beweging en juridiseert in toenemende mate. Met gezondheid en gezondheidszorg samenhangende economische, juridische en ethische vraagstukken halen dag in dag uit de voorpagina’s van de dagbladen.
Recht en gezondheidszorg staat allereerst uitgebreid stil bij de rechtsbetrekkingen tussen de belangrijkste partijen in de gezondheidszorg: de burger als patiënt, de zorgaanbieder (dokter, ziekenhuis), de zorgfinancier (de verzekeraar) en de burger als verzekerde. Aan bod komen onder meer de geneeskundige behandelingsovereenkomst, het beroepsgeheim, de rechten en plichten van patiënten, de rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaars, de aansprakelijkheid voor medische missers, het medisch tucht- en klachtrecht, medezeggenschap in de zorg, (good) governance, marktwerking, rol en taak van de overheid in de sector en het zorgverzekeringsrecht. Ook de uitdijende internationaalrechtelijke dimensie van gezondheidszorg komt aan bod. Het recht op gezondheidszorg is immers een mensenrecht en ook op dit terrein wint de Europese Unie aan invloed.
Een van de functies van het recht in onze samenleving is het voorkomen van conflicten en, als conflicten al bestaan, om deze op te lossen. Dit geldt ook voor het terrein van de gezondheidszorg, waar men soms van andere regels moet uitgaan dan in andere maatschappelijke sectoren gebruikelijk is. In deze Minor staat die specifieke wetgeving op het terrein van de gezondheidszorg centraal.
Het gezondheidsrecht bestaat naast eigen wetten en regels die specifiek op de gezondheidszorg van toepassing zijn, ook uit leerstukken van algemeen recht. Allereerst gaan we dan ook in op een aantal algemene rechtsgebieden, zoals het burgerlijke recht, het strafrecht, het bestuursrecht en het internationale recht. Doel is het bekend worden met de aard en de functie van deze rechtsgebieden. Daarnaast staat de betekenis hiervan voor de gezondheidszorg centraal. In sommige gevallen zal dan blijken dat het algemene recht niet voor alles een oplossing heeft, waardoor er toch weer behoefte is aan specifieke regelgeving. Ook de relatie tussen algemeen recht en bijzondere wetgeving is dus een punt van aandacht. Omdat deze Minor toegankelijk is voor studenten van verschillende studierichtingen, zullen afhankelijk van de beschikbare voorkennis, (aspecten) van te bespreken onderwerpen bekend, minder bekend of nog totaal onbekend zijn. Binnen deze Minor is dan ook een van de doelstellingen dat studenten elkaar bevragen, elkaar zaken uitleggen en zo van elkaar leren. Leerdoelen De student verkrijgt kennis van en inzicht in:
  • de wijze waarop in Nederland het stelsel van de gezondheidszorg juridisch is vormgegeven
  • rechten en plichten van de patiënt
  • rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaar, zorginstelling, zorgverzekeraar en zorgverzekerde
  • de internationaal- en Europeesrechtelijke aspecten van gezondheidszorg
  • de juridische aspecten van bijzondere vraagstukken als euthanasie, dwangbehandeling, biotechnologie, orgaandonatie, proefpersonenonderzoek, toegankelijkheid van de zorg, de menselijke waardigheid, et cetera.
De student verkrijgt vaardigheden in:
  • het opzoeken, interpreteren en toepassen van relevante regelgeving
  • het zelfstandig schrijven van een essay
  • het mondeling presenteren van onderzoeksresultaten
  • het met elkaar discussiëren over gezondheidsrechtelijke actuele onderwerpen in hun sociaaleconomische en/of sociaalmedisch-ethische context

Inhoud Waar mensen samenleven en goederen schaars zijn, ontstaan onvermijdelijk conflicten. Het recht biedt oplossingen voor deze conflicten. Rechten worden dus toegekend en plichten worden opgelegd omdat ze ergens toe dienen, omdat ze een functie vervullen. In R.E.M. wordt het recht bestudeerd vanuit de functie van het verlagen van kosten voor de samenleving als geheel.
De verschillende rechtsregels vormen samen een aaneensluitend geheel van oplossingen die ervoor zorgen dat verschillende soorten kosten voor de samenleving als geheel verminderd worden. Bij deze kosten kan gedacht worden aan bijvoorbeeld ongevalskosten, vervuilingskosten, overlast en hinder, schade doordat regels en afspraken niet worden nageleefd, kosten door criminaliteit et cetera. In het vak komen voorbeelden aan bod uit onder andere het privaatrecht (eigendom, contract, onrechtmatige daad), het strafrecht en het bestuursrecht. Ook worden fiscaal recht en internationaal en Europees recht aangestipt.
Bij het analyseren van de effecten van rechtsregels is, naast theoretisch onderzoek, empirisch onderzoek van belang. In R.E.M. worden enkele voorbeelden van zulk empirisch onderzoek kort besproken.
R.E.M. dus gaat over de maatschappelijke rol van het recht, waarbij de verschillende rechtsgebieden worden gezien als onderdelen van een samenhangend geheel, en waarbij niet alleen aandacht aan theoretisch maar ook aan empirisch onderzoek wordt besteed. Op deze manier beoogt het vak een ‘scharnier’ te vormen waarmee inzichtelijk wordt dat alle vakken uit het eerste bachelorjaar, alsmede uit de verdere rechtenstudie, met elkaar verbonden zijn.
  Leerdoelen Na dit blok kun je:
  1. Uitleggen dat het recht een functie in de samenleving vervult.
  2. Uitleggen hoe de rechtseconomie de functie van het recht in de samenleving invult.
  3. De ex ante en ex post benadering van het recht vergelijken en uitleggen welke benadering de rechtseconomie hanteert.
  4. Beargumenteren hoe efficiëntie en rechtvaardigheid samen kunnen gaan.
  5. Vanuit rechtseconomisch perspectief schetsen hoe verschillende rechtsgebieden één systeem vormen.
  6. Alternatieve juridische oplossingen voor een samenlevingsprobleem met elkaar vergelijken aan de hand van een prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse.
  7. Concrete voorbeelden uit wetgeving en rechtspraak beoordelen aan de hand van de prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse

  5. Vanuit rechtseconomisch perspectief schetsen hoe verschillende rechtsgebieden één systeem vormen.
  6. Alternatieve juridische oplossingen voor een samenlevingsprobleem met elkaar vergelijken aan de hand van een prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse.
  7. Concrete voorbeelden uit wetgeving en rechtspraak beoordelen aan de hand van de prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse

lecturers: ['dr. EM Galenkamp', 'dr. MJ Luth - Morgan', 'FG Kwekel, LL.M', 'I Zahuan', 'mr. CDM van Hacht', 'mr. HJ Kok', 'mr. O Kirman', 'mr. PC Grimmius', 'mr. S Alatag', 'mr. WJ Schaap', 'mr.dr. C Elion - Valter', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg']
text:
Inhoud Het overkoepelende thema van dit vak is ‘recht, staat en samenleving’. Onderwerpen die onder andere aan bod zullen komen zijn de belangrijkste ethische theorieën (utilisme, kantiaanse plichtenethiek en deugdenethiek) en juridische beroepsethiek, grondrechten, democratie en rechtsstaat, maatschappelijk onrecht, de problematiek van multilevel legal orders en global legal pluralism, theorieën van het sociaal contract, theorieën van verdelende rechtvaardigheid, het debat over legal moralism, strafrechtstheorieën en het debat over universalisme versus relativisme. De relevantie van de vaak abstracte theorieën zal inzichtelijk worden gemaakt door middel van terugkoppeling naar actuele casus. Leerdoelen De algemene doelstelling van het vak valt in twee delen uiteen. Het eerste doel is om de studenten kennis en inzicht te laten verwerven in de normatieve grondslagen en de achtergronden van het recht en de vier grote rechtsgebieden: privaatrecht; staats- en bestuursrecht; strafrecht; internationaal en Europees recht. Het lezen van rechtsfilosofische teksten – moderne én klassieke – is een van de methoden hierbij.

Het tweede doel van het vak is om de studenten te trainen in de schriftelijke vaardigheid om filosofisch te reflecteren op het recht en een beargumenteerd normatief standpunt in te nemen. In het onderwijs worden vaardigheden, kennis en inzicht zoveel mogelijk op elkaar betrokken.

Een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak vormt de schrijfvaardighedentraining. Deze training vindt onder meer plaats in de vorm van studievragen en het wekelijks facultatief uploaden van een antwoord op een essayvraag. In week 3 is er een verplichte take-home schrijfopdracht (rechtsfilosofisch advies voor 40 punten). Op het (her)tentamen dienen twee essays te worden geschreven (2 x 30 punten).

lecturers: ['dr. EM Galenkamp', 'dr. MJ Luth - Morgan', 'FG Kwekel, LL.M', 'I Zahuan', 'mr. CDM van Hacht', 'mr. HJ Kok', 'mr. O Kirman', 'mr. PC Grimmius', 'mr. S Alatag', 'mr. WJ Schaap', 'mr.dr. C Elion - Valter', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg']

Inhoud De rechter moet achterhalen of de verdachte schuldig is aan het tenlastegelegde feit. Dat doet hij door te bekijken of er in het dossier voldoende wettige bewijsmiddelen zitten die hem overtuigen van de schuld van de verdachte. In deze minor wordt ingegaan op wat er allemaal mis kan gaan bij dit proces. Ook wordt ingegaan op een alternatieve, rekenkundige manier van bewijsweging, de zogenoemde Bayesiaanse benadering. Bewijsmiddelen die aan bod komen zijn: getuigenverklaringen, herkenningen en bekentenissen. Verder wordt onder meer ingegaan op leugendetectie, verhoren en tunnelvisie Leerdoelen Tijdens dit vak worden deelnemers bekend gemaakt met de volgende onderwerpen:
  • Diagnostische waarde
  • Bayesiaanse analyse
  • Tunnelvisie
  • Waarneming en geheugen
  • Getuigen- en verdachtenverhoren
  • Leugendetectie.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This research workshop examines recognition within the art world. As in most fields, recognition can lead to various types of artistic success, from economic gain to critical acclaim. However, recognition in the arts is better understood as a social phenomenon, rather than exclusively the consequence of an artistic creator or artwork’s characteristics. Field conventions dictate what is created and "greatness" is evaluated according to the standards of time, place, and those professionals credentialed to offer their opinion. In this course, we will take such a sociological perspective in order to arrive at a better understanding of why certain creators are celebrated, while the majority of art and artists are largely unknown. We begin by thinking about what is recognition in the art world and what the different forms of recognition are. Next we discuss what factors contribute to differences in exposure and value. As this course is a research workshop, once we have discussed these questions, we will begin to empirically find answers. Students will conduct a small qualitative research project in which they examine recognition in the art world.
Note: It is highly recommended for entry into this course that students have completed the first year course on Methods.
 
Note: The maximum number of participants is 18. Leerdoelen By the end of this course, students will be able to:
  • Understand key concepts in the sociological examination of recognition in the visual arts;
  • Design their own small, qualitative research project about recognition in the visual arts;
  • Conduct their research project about recognition in the visual arts;
  • Report on their research project through written and oral description.

course_title: Reconstruction from Head to Hands: A Multidisciplinary View
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['A. Oudijn', 'dr. J.W. van Neck', 'dr. M.J. Koudstaal']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'dr. KA Lasak', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Inhoud This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
  • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
  • What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
  • What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
  • How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?
Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed. Leerdoelen The Refresher Statistics deals with elementary topics in statistics, which are taught in 4 sessions and assessed with a multiple-choice exam. The course addresses basic topics in statistics: summarizing data, probability, random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, sampling distributions, estimation and hypothesis testing. The aim of this refresher course is to ‘refresh’ statistical knowledge of students who have some background in statistics and to introduce basic statistical concepts to students who have limited or no knowledge about statistics

course_title: Regenerative medicine: a game changer technology
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['D. de Jongh', 'dr. D.C.J. Vissers', 'dr. E.M. Bunnik', 'dr. F.M.S. de Vrij', 'dr. H.M.M. van Beusekom', 'dr. ing. B.C.J. van der Eerden', 'dr. R.A. Poot', 'N.B. Fahy', 'PhD R. Narcisi', 'prof. dr. G.J.V.M. van Osch', 'prof. dr. L.J.W. van der Laan', 'prof. dr. M.H.N. Schermer', 'prof. dr. R.J. Rottier']

text:
Inhoud This Reinforcement Learning course focuses on using machine learning methods to model and solve problems relevant to management science problems – in particular, those problems involving machines that autonomously make decisions on the behalf of the modeler, as in online settings.

The course is based mainly on reinforcement learning (when we model states and transitions) and multi-armed bandits (when states are not modelled). We will focus on the design, solution, and implementation of learning methods for sequential decision-making under uncertainty. Sequential decision problems involve a trade-off between exploitation (acting on the information already collected) and exploration (gathering more information).
These problems arise in many important domains, ranging from online advertising, clinical trials, website optimization, marketing campaign and revenue management.

Course content:
1. Reinforcement Learning and multi-armed bandits: introduction and foundations
2. Stochastic Bandits and Regret Analysis
3. Optimality and lower bounds. The UCB algorithm
4. Thompson Sampling
5. Contextual Bandits, Adversarial Bandits and Bayesian bandits (e.g., Gittins and DAI)
6. MDP and Model-based State-based RL algorithms
7. Reinforcement Learning and Deep Reinforcement Learning

  Leerdoelen By the end of the course students will be able to:
  • Understand the fundamental building blocks of reinforcement learning methods and in particular, state-free multi-armed bandits, such as Thompson sampling, UCB, index-based methods and regret-based methods.
  • Choose the appropriate method for solving specific problem, program these methods, apply them sensibly, interpret the results and understand conceptual and practical implications.
  • Written and oral presentation of results within the research project.
  • Work on the research project in a team.

lecturers: ['AJ van Casteren, MSc', 'LK van Os', 'prof.dr. AL Bovenberg']
text:
Inhoud

We are moving from studying the economist inside the human being to studying the human being inside the economist.

This minor teaches the foundations of relational economics, an emerging field in economics in which relationships between human beings are of central interest. Relational economics explores interpersonal social connections. While traditional economics has generally viewed relationships as a way to reduce transaction costs in case of specific investments, recent scientific developments suggest to see the nature of relationships between humans from a more holistic perspective. Traditional economic tendencies (such as interpersonal cooperation and competition) and subjective ethical tendencies (such as altruistic reciprocity and intrinsic mutuality) are allowed to co-exist, with economists identifying how exactly humans create value through these complex interactive processes.

Among many other things, the minor demonstrates how today’s broadening of concepts like welfare and wellbeing are in agreement with early works on economics (as these were actually often highly relational in scope). As the course progresses, concepts that originate in psychology (in the case of values) and in organizational science (in the case of leadership) are introduced. The focus thus shifts gradually to the side of relational economics that specifically deals with theories on human values as well as theories on leadership.

As part of the applied economics department, the minor allows you to use relational economics as a viable lens to analyse and study governance, organizational behaviour and the psychology of human motivation. Through an interactive case method and project-oriented teaching style, you will acquire the basic analytical tools to relate to pressing contemporary issues of your choice.

Should you wish for additional information on the course, please contact the course coordinator with your questions by email.

Leerdoelen

General learning objectives:
• To know and be able to recall the discussed theoretical and empirical mechanisms that have been developed regarding the three concepts of values, leadership and relational economics.
• To understand theoretical frameworks for modelling relationships in economics and how to apply these to real-life topics and problems.
• To improve the academic skills of academic presenting, group work and assessment, writing and performing critical review and analysis and carrying out independent research projects.

Specific learning objectives (a selection):
• You know why economists are increasingly interested in values and relationships.
• You understand that the trade-off between commitment and flexibility reflects a trade-off between cooperative relationships and competition.
• You know and are able to recall the evolutionary (socio-)biological and philosophical grounds of values in human beings and groups.
• You have a reasonable grasp of the social dynamics of interpersonal value priorities in various social contexts.
• You understand and are able to explain the benefits and drawbacks of i.a. behavioural, cognitive and microeconomic theory and methodology concerning the study of leadership phenomena.
• You can explain in what ways leadership behaviour can be used to establish, maintain and diminish personal and social commitment, form reciprocal relationships and promote cooperation and mutuality.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. N da Silva Perez', 'J Beocanin', 'N Sikkema', 'R Wervers']
text:
Inhoud In this course we look at how religion is variously defined in relation to its content and performance as well as to the ways in which religion is organized and impacts on society. Believers rather than believes are central in our approach, religion being considered to be part of particular historical and cultural contexts and, often, wider global networks. In the lectures Christianity and Islam figure prominently, representing the two largest religious traditions on the globe, but due attention will be paid to other religious traditions and trends, including new religious movements, such as Wicca, but also counter movements such as Pastafarianism. For their assignments and final papers students select and define their own topic in one of following fields:
  • Religion and colonization (missionaries, colonial policies, local responses, postcolonial developments)
  • Religion, migration and citizenship (diaspora’s, transnational communities, debates and policies concerning (national) identities, including issues of gender)
  • Living religion (religion as lifestyle, rituals and beliefs ordering daily life and –possibly- the hereafter)
Leerdoelen

Students acquire knowledge of the various concepts and definitions of religion and of the changing nature of religion and religious organization and within a global perspective. They acquire the skills to analyze specific cases of social and cultural developments in modern history in which religion is or appears to be a key element as well as the skills to present their findings in a scholarly final paper.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
In this course in ‘Business Analysis and Valuation’ you will learn the basic concepts of financial statement analysis, enabling you to understand how financial reports are used by investors and to take a fundamental approach to equity (and debt) valuation.
The course has a practical emphasis. We adopt the view of an active investor and apply methods of fundamental analysis in a series of real-life exercises, cases, and assignments involving listed companies. We examine various valuation methods—residual earnings, abnormal earnings growth, and discounted cash flow approaches to valuation, among others—and ask which one will give us an edge. We do all this under the strict discipline of a fundamentalist: separate what you know from speculation and anchor in what you know from analysing financial statement information.
Just as importantly, we learn how to handle accounting and financial reports in valuation. We see that valuation is really a matter of accounting for value. The course combines accounting principles and investment principles to answer the question: How do I account for value so that I can challenge stock prices with some confidence?
As members of RSM, we aim to be a force for positive change in the world, using as guidance the framework set out by the UN Sustainability Development Goals (SDGs) to address the most urgent social, economic, and environmental challenges. Business analysis and valuation can play a leading role in allocating resources to sustainable companies and, thereby, accelerate the transition to a sustainable economy. We will discuss how environmental, societal, and governance (ESG) performance affects firm value. For example, a strategy analysis (Learning Goal (LG) 2) includes the assessment of a firm’s innovation (SDG 9) and responsible production (SDG 12), which can significantly affect a firm’s expected profitability and growth, two key drivers of future performance and value. Credit agencies may increasingly lower their assessments of firms’ creditworthiness (LG 7) for environmental liabilities expected to result from pollution (SDG 6). Similarly, when pricing risk for valuation purposes, environmental damages significantly affect a firm’s cost of capital (LG 8).

The course discusses techniques that are commonly used in an equity research department of a bank, independent research firm, or equity hedge fund. However, the material covered in the course is just as relevant to the corporate business analyst or financial consultant, for private equity analysis, for evaluating acquisitions, restructurings and other investments, and for calculating the value generated by strategic decisions. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in investment banking, security analysis, accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.

Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
On completion of this course, students should be able to:
  1. Understand the environment in which financial reporting by companies takes place;
  2. Analyse business strategies to understand the value that they add;
  3. Determine the quality of the accounting in financial reports and undo accounting distortions;
  4. Analyse a firm’s operating and investment performance through ratio and cash flow analysis;
  5. Understand theories on capital structure and dividend choice;
  6. Analyse a firm’s financing and dividend decisions;
  7. Analyse a firm’s creditworthiness;
  8. Understand the primary determinants of the cost of capital;
  9. Forecast future financial statements, determine the cost of capital, and apply fundamentals-based valuation techniques;
  10. Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular valuation case, and present and defend the joint findings and conclusions in a report.Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular valuation case, and present and defend the joint findings and conclusions in a report.

course_title: Representation, the People and Contemporary Democracy
lecturers: ['dr. GH van Oenen', 'J van der Klaauw, MA']
text:
Inhoud

This course is part of cluster 1: Representation: Democracy, Science, and Culture. 

Ever since the concept of ‘we the people’ was born, with Rousseau and the American and French revolutions, there has been a search for how to represent this sovereign yet elusive entity, ‘the people’, the product of the abolition of fixed social categories like estates. Social relations have now become a matter of contestation and proclamation fueled by association and mobilization. Combined with processes of emancipation, and division of labour, this had led to ever shifting ideas and practices of who represents whom. Parliament, government, the magistrature, labor unions, new social movements, the media, populist politicans all claim to speak in name of the people and to somehow represent either some part, or all of the people.

Democracy, as it unfolds in thought and in practice, both enriches and complicates representation through its claim that ‘the people themselves’ are both willing and able to participate in processes of representation. In its radical form this implies that the people could, and should, represent themselves. As ‘natural’ or traditional representation has vanished, yet ‘the people’ can never be present, the place of power in democracy is ‘empty’, or structurally vacant, and the shaping of both the people and whomever represents them becomes a matter of symbolic practices, which temporarily assign roles and legitimize procedures.

In this course we look at manifestations, conceptualizations, and institutionalizations of the people in forms such as crowds, masses, parliaments, movements, and assemblies. We discuss phenomena like populism, anarchism, communism, and post-politics in their relation to more established forms and ideologies of politics and democracy. We will be reading and discussing authors such as Claude Lefort, Frank Ankersmit, Jodi Dean, Nadia Urbinati, Warren Breckman, Chantal Mouffe, Michel Foucault, and Judith Butler.

Leerdoelen - understanding the basic concepts around democracy and representation;
- understanding the relation of the basic concepts around democracy and representation in historical and cultural context;
- understanding how to apply the basic concepts around democracy and representation to societal issues and problems

course_title: Representing War in Popular Historical Culture
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud World War II until today is an important reference point in popular historical culture, both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Other large-scale conflicts, such as the First World War, the Cold War  and the recent wars in the Middle East, are as well appealing historical experiences with an impact on the collective memory. But the way wars are represented and collectively remembered is anything but immutable and unambiguous. The ways in which wars of the past were brought to the fore (usually outside of academia) during the 20th and 21st centuries for a variety of audiences are quite diverse: ranging from museum exhibitions to comics and novels, and from films and musicals to games and new media. In this course the focus is on the question in what kind of historical representations of war all these elements have resulted, and what meanings are assigned to it? What are the expectations of both producers and consumers regarding different ways of presenting this past, and which views exist on understanding and – in as far as possible - 'experiencing' past wars. The emphasis will be on war representations in the popular historical culture of the Western world with a special focus on the medium of comics

  Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to gain knowledge and understanding of the ways in which wars from the early 20th century to the beginning of the 21st century are represented and framed in popular historical culture. Students learn in what ways a diversity of media and other forms of historical presentation reflect memories and visions of various large-scale conflicts and how developments in these representations relate  to historical interpretations.

course_title: Research & Writing Skills (Commercial and Company Law)
lecturers: ['A Cordina, LL.M', 'dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. C Bian', 'dr. FL Stevens', 'dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr. J Hornig', 'dr. M Stambulski', 'dr. P Wilinski', 'dr. SF Airey', 'drs. FJ Unz, LL.M', 'EW de Waegh, LL.M', 'I Aksakal', 'J Bonat', 'JP Valdivia Pizarro', 'mr. E Silva de Freitas, LL.M', 'mr. LE Dijkman', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema', 'SD Efstathiou']
text:
Inhoud The Research & Writing Skills course has the objective of developing practical skills in doing legal research and in writing legal texts. The course will assist students with developing expertise in three different legal methods, namely classical black letter law research, comparative law research and legal research design. Law and Ethics will be part of courses in block 2 to combine substantive and social aspects of law at the same time. The skills of the course of Research and Writing Skills will be trained through writing papers, oral presentations and group discussions. All topics you will be studying relate to commercial law, with a further focus on questions relating to the master variation you have chosen. This way, the course not only introduces you to legal research, improving skills necessary for the remaining of the course as well as your legal career, but also introduces you to the exciting field of commercial law, which will be explored for the rest of the year.
During the Research & Writing Skills course you will be confronted with many practical and legal issues from recent years. Common to these issues is the international nature and complexity of the legal relations involved. In order to find sound and workable solutions to these problems, you must learn to determine the relevant international standard(s) applicable. Where no uniform international standard exists, a comparative legal approach may be necessary to determine the main schools of thought about certain issues adopted by different legal systems.

The internal moot case plays a central role in the Research & Writing Skills course curriculum. It means that (almost) all of the assignments are linked to this case and constitute important building blocks that you use, structuring your argumentation for instance when drafting a legal memorandum (it will be explained further in a section with the assignments’ overview). For example, the comparative law assignment concerns force majeure, which is a relevant legal concept used in the moot case. Case reports that are discussed during the workgroup sessions are also useful authorities that can be used to support legal argumentation during the internal moot.

Each week you will face more and more challenging legal concepts, which will be based on (building on) the knowledge already acquired from the previous sessions. It means that the course requires your full attention.

[IMPORTANT NOTE to Exchange Students]
Dear Exchange Students, Research and Writing Skills courses designed for different variations of Commercial Law LL.M. (RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84) offer an intensive small group teaching and training. These courses are taught by the same teachers, have a very similar structure and will allow you to acquire the same set of skills. Please bear in mind, however, that in case when the limited capacity of the chosen track is reached, we might be forced to assign you to another Research and Writing Skills variation of Commercial Law LL.M. (thus another course from those available under these codes RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84).
  Leerdoelen The course Research & Writing Skills has not only the objective of introducing the student to the subject matter by way of in-depth study of certain selected topics within the field of international commercial law, but also by way of developing the skills that are required for conducting legal research and are transferrable in their future (legal) career. After this course the student should have an ease of using the following research and writing skills both while working independently but also when collaborating with others.

course_title: Research & Writing Skills (Maritime and Transport Law)
lecturers: ['A Cordina, LL.M', 'dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. C Bian', 'dr. FL Stevens', 'dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr. J Hornig', 'dr. M Stambulski', 'dr. P Wilinski', 'dr. SF Airey', 'drs. FJ Unz, LL.M', 'EW de Waegh, LL.M', 'I Aksakal', 'J Bonat', 'JP Valdivia Pizarro', 'mr. E Silva de Freitas, LL.M', 'mr. LE Dijkman', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema', 'SD Efstathiou']
text:
Inhoud The Research & Writing Skills course has the objective of developing practical skills in doing legal research and in writing legal texts. The course will assist students with developing expertise in three different legal methods, namely classical black letter law research, comparative law research and legal research design. Law and Ethics will be part of courses in block 2 to combine substantive and social aspects of law at the same time. The skills of the course of Research and Writing Skills will be trained through writing papers, oral presentations and group discussions.
All topics you will be studying relate to commercial law, with a further focus on questions relating to the master variation you have chosen. This way, the course not only introduces you to legal research, improving skills necessary for the remaining of the course as well as your legal career, but also introduces you to the exciting field of commercial law, which will be explored for the rest of the year.
During the Research & Writing Skills course you will be confronted with many practical and legal issues from recent years. Common to these issues is the international nature and complexity of the legal relations involved. In order to find sound and workable solutions to these problems, you must learn to determine the relevant international standard(s) applicable. Where no uniform international standard exists, a comparative legal approach may be necessary to determine the main schools of thought about certain issues adopted by different legal systems.
The internal moot case plays a central role in the Research & Writing Skills course curriculum. It means that (almost) all of the assignments are linked to this case and constitute important building blocks that you use, structuring your argumentation for instance when drafting a legal memorandum (it will be explained further in a section with the assignments’ overview). For example, the comparative law assignment concerns force majeure, which is a relevant legal concept used in the moot case. Case reports that are discussed during the workgroup sessions are also useful authorities that can be used to support legal argumentation during the internal moot.
Each week you will face more and more challenging legal concepts, which will be based on (building on) the knowledge already acquired from the previous sessions. It means that the course requires your full attention.
[IMPORTANT NOTE to Exchange Students]
Dear Exchange Students, Research and Writing Skills courses designed for different variations of Commercial Law LL.M. (RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84) offer an intensive small group teaching and training. These courses are taught by the same teachers, have a very similar structure and will allow you to acquire the same set of skills. Please bear in mind, however, that in case when the limited capacity of the chosen track is reached, we might be forced to assign you to another Research and Writing Skills variation of Commercial Law LL.M. (thus another course from those available under these codes RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84). Leerdoelen
The course Research & Writing Skills has not only the objective of introducing the student to the subject matter by way of in-depth study of certain selected topics within the field of international commercial law, but also by way of developing the skills that are required for conducting legal research and are transferrable in their future (legal) career. After this course the student should have an ease of using the following research and writing skills both while working independently but also when collaborating with others.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
text:
Inhoud In this module you will perform
  • a quantitative research project in groups of 2 or 3 students, within the topic of behavioural health economics. You can collect your own data by means of an experiment, a nudging study or a survey, or analyse an existing dataset. The results have to be reported in a research paper. Examples include the empirical implementation of the intervention you proposed as part of the assignment in ACUB, measuring health-related preferences in a survey (e.g. as a preparation for a nudge), or testing particular hypotheses related to health behaviour (e.g. concerning the presence of specific biases and heuristics) in a lab, online or field experiment; or
  • A research project in groups of 2 or 3 students within the topic of Value Based Health Care

Please note this elective course is only open for a small group of students from the minor Smarter Choices for Better Health and the bachelor program in Health Sciences at ESHPM. More information about the selection process is communicated at the beginning of the academic year.
  Leerdoelen After following this course you:
  • Can formulate a research question and hypotheses.
  • Can design an economic experiment or find and clean an appropriate dataset.
  • Are able to conduct your own quantitative research by means of a statistical software package.
  • Can report your research in a scientific report.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The aim of this course is to offer the foundational considerations for starting your thesis project. Specifically, it focuses on a variety of topics around the first, theory-focused part of your thesis (rather than the empirical part)—including topic choice, research question formulation, framing, and hypothesis development. These topics will be addressed in a series of lectures, building on published work on doing research as well as the experiences and submissions of prior students.
In addition to these subjects, a key aim of the course is to provide students with practical insights with respect to writing academic work, including but not limited to: identifying relevant literature, the issue of plagiarism, writing style, referencing style, reading academic papers, organizing your notes, and using the TOP system.   Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The course touches upon the following subjects and learning goals:
  1. Identifying a research topic.
  2. Formulating a relevant and feasible problem definition and research question.
  3. Positioning this research question in the wider academic literature within your research topic.
  4. Articulating both academic and managerial contributions that the research, if successfully completed, is likely to add.
  5. Outlining a conceptual model to be developed in full in the thesis.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
The research clinic (BMRSCMiM) supports the first steps of the thesis trajectory where the students develop their research proposals. It helps students see what it takes to go from an interesting research topic, to specifying a concrete research problem, decide on a research question, research strategy and method. Lectures and workshops during the research clinic will help to craft a research question, conduct the literature review, craft the introductory chapter and discuss methodological topics. Furthermore, the research clinic introduces the students to the specific possibilities of either qualitative research or specific quantitative methods for research in finance, depending on the students’ choice of research profile. It builds on the course Business Analytics.

This course is worth 1 EC
 

Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Being able to define a relevant research question in the current business context
  • Formulate a research plan
  • Provide a relevant and coherent overview of the most relevant literature
  • Understand the managerial importance of the research question

Inhoud
Instructors: Francesca Sotgiu (VU)


Course content:

During the course, students write a research proposal for possible PhD and/or grant applications. In this process, they start by fine-tuning their own curriculum and cover letter to highlight the potential
of the proposal. When writing their proposal, they focus on aspects that all committees and referees look at: the novelty of the idea, its relevance, impact and feasibility. Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:


- Identify the key elements of a successful cover letter and elevator pitch supporting their idea

- Explain the key elements of their proposal

- Address important questions pertaining to the novelty and relevance of their idea (“So
what?” & “Who cares?”)

- Identify ways to engage their audience during presentations.

Leerdoelen By the end of the course, students will be able to:
  • Identify relevant business problems
  • Understand how data science can be used to address these business problems.
  • Show an understanding of business that allows them to broadly read and understand the current scientific literature in business and management, and follow scientific debates across these sciences
  • Written proposal of a research project.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
The research clinic prepares the student for writing the thesis proposal. The clinic will provide insights into types of research questions and their requirements. It will provide an overview of research strategies and the appropriateness of these related to various types of research questions. Furthermore, various forms of data collection and analysis techniques – related to the research strategy – are discussed. As students follow a ‘master in management’ students will learn how to discuss and think about the managerial relevance of their research question.

To properly discuss and learn about types of data collection and data analysis the research clinic is organized in various tracks running in parallel for different groups of students depending on their choice of a thesis topic and the exact research question. Students will participate in one of the following tracks:

  • Track for students who want to write their thesis in Finance
  • Track for students who want to conduct a quantitative analysis
  • Track for students who want to conduct a qualitative analysis

These tracks provide hands-on exercises to help students to collect their data adequately and conduct their analysis in the thesis autonomously. The thesis proposal is conditional for the thesis.

This course is worth 1 EC.

Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Being able to define a relevant research question in the current business context
  • Formulate a research plan
  • Provide a relevant and coherent overview of the most relevant literature
  • Understand the managerial importance of the research question

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'dr. L Guzman Ramirez', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text: Inhoud We will discuss Research Data Management (RDM) as a strategy for your data and research. You will get familiar with RDM processes and the Data Management Plan Template. We will show you examples of how-to fill-in the template and we will have a hands-on session on which you will have time to fill-in and get answers to all your questions about your own Data Management Plan.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. RB Bouwman', 'dr. RFI Moody', 'F de Haan']
text:
Inhoud
In this course various aspects of the research design are discussed and applied in a research proposal that students develop for their master thesis that they will start in the 3th and 4th block.
In interactive sessions research designs, and research methods are introduced and discussed.
Leerdoelen After this course students are able to:
·         Describe the most important methodological considerations in choosing a certain research strategy and research methods.  
·         Choose a research strategy and research methods that fit with a certain research question; 
·         Draft a research design that is coherent in terms of its problem statement, research question, theory, and methods for data collection and –analysis.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Research design refers to a series of interrelated decisions about the kinds of questions that can be answered empirically (and ethically); the theoretical and social justification for asking those questions; and the appropriate procedures for sampling, collecting, and analyzing data to answer them.

In this course, students strengthen their research design skills by developing a research project (proposal) of their own. They formulate scientifically sound research questions, place them in relation to existing literature, make and justify decisions related to data collection and analysis, data management and research ethics. By presenting and discussing their work in class, they also engage in peer review processes, sharing and receiving suggestions for and from their peers. Opportunities to scrutinize successful research (grant) proposals and to discuss with authors the ‘behind the scenes’ of specific research projects further sharpen students’ critical sensibility toward research design choices.


Seminar discussions pay special attention to the relationship between theory and research; alternative methodological approaches and styles/traditions of research within the social sciences, as well as the pros and cons of combining methods; personal involvement and/or bias; research ethics and data management. Practical constraints that affect research decisions are also considered.

The course is meant to advance and systematize previous knowledge and experience students already have in social scientific research in general. It prepares students for the more specialized methodological courses that follow Leerdoelen Students have advanced knowledge and understanding of:
  • The different decisions involved in the design of empirical research in the fields of sociology of culture, media and the arts.
  • The epistemological, practical, and ethical implications of these different decisions.
Students have developed skills to:
  • Review qualitative, quantitative or mixed methods research designs in the sociology of culture, media and the arts.
  • Design a research project of their own.

college: Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS)
lecturers: ['BG Calzada Olvera', 'dr. A Baliga', 'dr. A Los', 'dr. J Fransen', 'dr. NB Sakizlioglu Uitermark', 'dr. P Nagler', 'dr. S Pagliarin']
text:
Inhoud This course provides a general understanding of the basics of research design and writing of a research project, i.e., master’s thesis. It also offers practical guidance working with hands-on exercises based on different research cases covering quantitative and qualitative strategies across several subjects. The course focuses on how various elements of a proper research project should be developed, including: 
  • Motivation - often referred to as problem statement[1].
  • Research questions (and sub-research questions if applicable).  
  • Literature review and conceptual framework.
  • Selection of a research strategy.
  • Introduction to survey, case studies, secondary data (also desk research), and ethnography.
  • Identification of appropriate data collection, variables, and analysis methods.
  • Research ethics.
The RD course, UDA1 & 2 complement each other. Within those courses, students learn and apply methodological skills that support them in completing their theses[1].
 
 
Leerdoelen The course introduces the basics of social science research and offers a practical guide to developing a research framework. The learning objectives of the course are as follow:
  • Understand how to formulate a research question (and sub-research questions when applicable) based on an academically sound justification (i.e., problem statement).
  • Recognize elements contained in a competent literature review.
  • Identify the critical elements necessary for producing a sound conceptual framework.
  • Recognize why research design choices are made in consideration of the research questions, data, and limitations.
  • Understand the objectives and elements in the formulation of an empirical strategy for data and variables, i.e., the translation of concepts into indicators, and in presenting a clear explanation for methodological choices.
  • Understand how to properly present and discuss analysis results.
  • Explain how ethics are involved and can be addressed in social science research.
Apply the elements above in the development of a master’s research project

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Inhoud This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
  • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
  • What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
  • What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
  • How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?
Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed. Leerdoelen This module introduces you to interrelations among core elements of academic research and highlights the role of one key element, theory development. Conceptual insights, methodological aspects, and field study are well-known components of academic research, but how are they related? A combination of seminal readings, practical exercises, and in-depth class discussions will make you discover ways to design robust research and develop solid theory.

The module’s learning objectives are to:
  1. Understand different research design options;
  2. Warrant consistency and coherence in your research design;
  3. Draw on and develop theoretical insights.

course_title: Research Design 1: Start 1 October 2022 or 1 January 2023
lecturers: ['dr. A Bouabid', 'dr. A Naudé - Fourie', 'dr. J Hoevenaars', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'prof.dr. EF Stamhuis, LLM', 'prof.dr. K Heine', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'prof.dr. P Mascini', 'prof.dr. RHJM Staring', 'prof.dr.mr. T Wallinga', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg', 'prof.mr.dr. F Weber', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema', 'WC Puper']
text:
Leerdoelen Writing your research proposal

Part 1. Research question
You will learn what is necessary to move from a broad PhD topic to a researchable and relevant research question. After this module you can distinguish the academic relevance of your research from societal relevance.

Part 2. Theoretical framework and literature review
You will learn: what the importance of a good literature review is and what the building blocks for making it are. You will understand the role of a theoretical framework and the differences between different types of frameworks, most importantly theoretical (in an empirical setting) and normative (in a legaldoctrinal setting).

Part 3. Research method
You will understand the need to specify your overall methodology and the elements that determine the choice of specific methods (research question, approach, skills). Research Method seminars In this part of the course you will learn the basic principles of various research methods that are used in the research into legally relevant phenomena. During these seminars you will receive an explanation by several teachers about the specific method and how to apply it.

The following Research Method Seminars are offered in this course:
  1. Doctrinal Legal research
  2. Comparative law
  3. Legal philosophy
  4. Legal History
  5. Law & Economics
  6. Empirical legal research (a basic part and an in-depth part)
  7. Law & Ethnography
The aim of these modules is:
  1. To introduce PhD students to the different methods of legal research.
  2. To create awareness about the possibilities of these methods for their project.
  3. To highlight the risks connected with each method.

course_title: Research Design 2: Start 1 March 2023 or 30 May 2023
lecturers: ['dr. F Violi', 'dr. J Hoevenaars', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema', 'WC Puper']
text:
Leerdoelen The Academic Writing Process

In this course we will focus on one of the most important parts of academic life: the writing process. All experienced writers know that writing a paper, a chapter or even a book is never a straight march from the idea to a finished product. While writing you will likely go through many drafts, go into blind alleys, and even make new discoveries that may lead you to rethink your entire project. In the end, a lot of what is in your early rafts will not even make it into the final version. One of the most important skills you will learn during your PhD is working your way through this process of drafting, reviewing, rewriting, receiving and incorporating feedback and refining your work. In this course we will go through this process together. We will not only focus on writing itself, but also on giving and receiving feedback. In this course we will focus on 3 general steps that will help all researchers in their struggle towards a well-written and convincing product:
  1. Strategy, how do you get started with writing and what should be included in your text.
  2. Inter-vision, how to read other peoples’ work and how to provide as well as receive feedback.
  3. Revising your work and incorporating any feedback.
First you will write an abstract in which you briefly introduce your research, second you will write a first version of your introductory chapter, and finally you will write the revised and final full version of your chapter.

Inhoud
Instructor: Ines Lindner (VU).
 
Course content:
Scholars and companies deal every day with large and big data. This course allows the students to put their knowledge to the test and apply it to different fields. They will analyze big data, identify possible solutions with the help of specialized second-year research master students or PhD students. The course offers an important meta-learning experience, conneting all the teachings preceding the course and thought simultaneously. While during the first year, they will focus on different business problems, second-year students will dedicate their attention to the assignments related to their specialization.
Leerdoelen After the end of this course, students will:
  1. Demonstrate prior methodological knowledge and a clear understanding of key business principles.
  2. Apply this theoretical and methodological knowledge and experience in group assignments.
  3. Identify relevant research questions
  4. Analyze and evaluate different methodological approaches and findings
  5. Have worked on a research project in a team with written and oral presentation

lecturers: ['CE Weeda, MSc', 'dr. TFC Fischer', 'jonkvrouw TMA van Suchtelen, MSc', 'M van den Heuvel', 'MH Kox, MA', 'MJ Davarci, LLM', 'mr. AVR Hagers', 'mr. LE Kooreman', 'mr. RF Shaikh Mohamedbux', 'mr.dr. H Weijers', 'mr.drs. IR Bluijs', 'S Nieuwland', 'SD Kruit, MSc']
text:
Inhoud In het vak Research Lab – de Basis (dat je gedurende het hele jaar volgt) van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit vak richt zich in vier modules op onderzoeksmethoden (bestaande uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses), (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden, het toepassen van rechtsregels en het schrijven van een juridisch betoog. Dit zijn allemaal vaardigheden die van pas komen in de dagelijkse werkpraktijk van de criminoloog. Leerdoelen Na afloop van dit vak is de student in staat om:
 
  1. op basisniveau kwantitatieve (beschrijvende en verklarende analyse) en kwalitatieve (interviewen) onderzoeksmethoden uit te voeren;
  2. op basis van wetenschappelijke bronnen en empirische gegevens gestructureerde wetenschappelijke teksten te schrijven;
  3. het interpreteren en toepassen van rechtsregels, het begrijpen van rechtelijke uitspraken en een juridisch betoog te schrijven.

lecturers: ['A Haspel, LLM', 'dr. F Coman Kund', 'dr. J Jansen, MSc', 'GJ Koops - Geuze, MSc', 'IPJ Aarts, MSc', 'JM de Dood, MSc', 'LK Krijger', 'MH Kox, MA', 'mr. D Stankovic', 'mr. MK Shahid', 'prof.dr. FM Weerman', 'S Nieuwland', 'SAM Verbeek, MSc', 'SD Kruit, MSc']
text:
Inhoud In het vak Research Lab – de Toepassing (dat loopt van blok 3 t/m 6) van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit blok richt zich in vier modules op onderzoeksmethoden (bestaande uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses), juridische analyse en (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden. Deze gevorderde vaardigheden worden toegepast op een criminologisch relevant en blijvend actueel onderwerp: surveillance door de overheid. Dit zijn allemaal vaardigheden die van pas komen in de dagelijkse werkpraktijk van de criminoloog. De tijdens dit geschreven stukken en verzamelde data vormen de basis van het bacheloronderzoek, waarmee jullie de bachelor Criminologie afsluiten. Leerdoelen ​De student kan na het succesvol afronden van deze cursus:
 
  1. Literatuuronderzoek uitvoeren en een vraagstelling afbakenen over de mening over en beleving van surveillance door de overheid en hierover schriftelijk rapporteren.
  2. Wetenschappelijke kennis vergaren over de mening over en beleving van surveillance door de overheid aan de hand van het uitvoeren van kwantitatief en kwalitatief criminologisch onderzoek.
  3. Wetenschappelijke kennis vergaren over surveillance door de overheid en asiel en migratie aan de hand van juridisch onderzoek.
  4. Een pleitnotitie opstellen en pleiten voor rechters in een Moot court.

text:
Inhoud In het vak Research Lab – de Verdieping (dat je gedurende het hele jaar volgt) van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit blok richt zich in vijf modules op onderzoeksmethoden (bestaande uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses), (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden, argumenten opbouwen, mondelinge vaardigheden, observeren en het toepassen van strafrechtelijke kennis. Dit zijn allemaal vaardigheden die van pas komen in de dagelijkse werkpraktijk van de criminoloog. Leerdoelen ​De student kan na succesvol afronden van deze cursus:
 
  1. Op gevorderd niveau kwantitatieve (beschrijvende en verklarende analyse) en kwalitatieve (analyse van verschillende kwalitatieve bronnen) onderzoeksmethoden uitvoeren.
  2. Op basis van theorie, wetenschappelijke bronnen en empirische gegevens gestructureerde wetenschappelijke teksten schrijven.
  3. Argumenten logisch en overtuigend kunnen overbrengen in een mondeling betoog en schriftelijk paper.
  4. Criminologisch relevante fenomenen wetenschappelijk observeren.
  5. Juridische, meer specifiek strafrechtelijke, kennis toepassen op casuïstiek.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. J Kneer', 'dr. O Nyirubugara', 'dr. SJ Opree', 'PM Leendertse, MA', 'prof.dr. MNM Verboord', 'prof.dr. MSSE Janssen']
text:
Inhoud The course is devoted to practical and ethical issues related to the academic field of the social sciences. In these meetings, students will learn about several key aspects of this field, including aspects that are particularly relevant for PhD students and other junior researchers. Each meeting starts with an introduction/presentation  by a staff member, which is followed by an open and informal discussions between all participants. This format is explicitly meant to leave plenty of opportunities for students to raise relevant issues themselves.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • A variety of practical and ethical issues related to the academic field of the social sciences
Students are able to:
  • Make strategies for presenting at academic conferences and publishing in academic journals
  • Reflect on ethical issues in the academic field.
  • Give high-quality academic presentations.
  • Develop a career plan.
