text:
Inhoud The Milestones are convenient intermediate steps, e.g. writing and presenting draft thesis proposals, that will help you in submitting your ReMA thesis before the deadline.

For more information: see Canvas

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course prepares students for the thesis trajectory that starts in January. The course consists of plenary sessions that are a combination of lecture and workshop. The first two lectures regard general topics about research, research questions and literature review. After these two joint sessions, students join either a qualitative or a quantitative research track for which three/four sessions will follow. In these tracks students are taught a more specialized understanding of either qualitative or quantitative research.

Assessment is mixed and consists of an individual assignment and a team assignment. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
At the end of this course, students should be able to:
  • Apply key phases of a qualitative or quantitative research project.
  • Write a literature review that is conducive for writing the thesis. 
  • Systematically analyse qualitative or quantitative data via the application of the approaches learned in class.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Research Methodology 1 & 2 will provide students with an understanding of the basics of qualitative and quantitative research methods, as well as the skills to design and implement sound research projects in the area of sustainability management. The overall aim of the course is to provide students with insights and skills to make informed choices regarding the research methodology to be used for their MSc thesis. The course is structured to coincide with work on the master thesis.

Research Methodology 1 is focused on research design and literature review. By taking this course, students will have the opportunity to find their research topic and formulate their research questions. Research Methodology 2 offers more specific knowledge on qualitative and quantitative methods.

Assignments and feedback
Throughout the course, students are asked to submit an assignment on Canvas.

Attendance
Class attendance is not mandatory but strongly recommended.

Outlook
In continuation of this course, students will take the second course, Research Methodology II, which consists of separate lectures on qualitative and quantitative research and workshops that they can pick based on what methods they need for their thesis.

Improvement option
In case the final grade is between 4.5 and 5.4, students will have the opportunity to revise their assignments based on the feedback they received. The deadline for the revision will be provided by the lecturer. The maximum grade after revision is 6.0.
  Leerdoelen Learning Goals
Students can select research methods based on the research questions they want to address.

Learning Objectives
  1. Students can draw on existing research to develop their research question (Session 1)
  2. Students can assess how appropriate different research strategies and research designs are to answer a particular research question (Session 2)

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course consists of a series of workshops on specific qualitative and quantitative data collection and analysis methods, such as interviews, experiments, surveys, qualitative coding, and statistical hypothesis testing. In principle, all workshops are offered multiple times, so that students can follow them when at a time that matches with the progress in your thesis project. Students are expected to follow, and actively participate in, at least two of these workshops, depending on the methods they will be using in their thesis research.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
At the end of this course, students should be able to:
  • Apply methods for data collection and analysis, in the context of their own thesis.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
  • This course will provide students with an understanding on the basics of qualitative and quantitative research methods. The overall aim of the course is to provide students with insights and skills to make informed choices regarding the research design to be used for their MSc thesis. The course is structured to coincide with work on the thesis.
  • In this course we provide an overview of methodological principles underlying both qualitative and quantitative methods. We will cover the following topics: research strategies and designs, sampling, common types of data collection methods (interviewing, surveys, and experiments), data analysis, writing, and research ethics.
Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
At the end of this course, students should be able to:
  • select research methods based on the research questions they want to address
  • collect and analyse data in line with best practices for qualitative research
  • collect and analyse data in line with best practices for quantitative research.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
One of the main reasons why companies hire university graduates is because of their academic mindset and skills. This includes a critical attitude towards what is presented as “the truth,” the ability to assess the quality of research presented to them, and the competence to study a phenomenon in a structured way. These same qualities are required of you as you design and execute your Master thesis project. This course teaches you how to design your project, use the available literature, and collect and analyze data for empirical research. It follows the chronological steps of research design, data collection, and data analysis. On top of these basics, you will have the chance to go into depth for specific topics (methods and/or skills) that you will need for your own Master thesis, thereby allowing you to tailor your study program to your specific needs. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
  • Contrast different research methods
  • Evaluate the methodology of research studies
  • Develop a scientific research project

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. DAJA Derks - Theunissen', 'G Martins Van Jaarsveld', 'S van Weeghel']
text:
Inhoud Digital media have influenced empirical research. Using smart devices and experience sampling techniques we can capture “life as it is lived”.  Instead of taking a photo by a one-time questionnaire, we use repetitive measurements taking within person fluctuations into account. We try to meaningfully interpret the fluctuations over the measurement points (days, moments…). This implies that retrospective bias is reduced, but also that we can answer a different kind of research questions. Leerdoelen At the end of this course, the student…
  1. knows what experience sampling is and can reflect on potential advantages and side backs;
  2. understands what type of research questions can be answered by ESM studies;
  3. is capable to think of possible research questions and research designs in ESM;
  4. is able to analyze the results of an ESM study;
  5. is able to report the results in the format of an extensive abstract or poster presentation.
Belangrijk om te weten Practical meetings are in English

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud The research project aims to provide a first taste of social science research. Working together in small research groups, students will follow the entire empirical cycle according to the standards of a social science hypothesis testing research. The research starts with formulating a preliminary theoretical answer to the research question, which is subsequently tested in a methodically sound way. In the conclusion, a clear answer is provided to the formulated research question and hypotheses are confirmed or disproven. Finally, students will reflect on the limitations of the research and their findings.

Two types of research will be conducted: a quantitative hypothesis-testing approach, and a qualitative approach, where data collection and theory enforce each other. In each of the approaches students conduct assignments that allows them to follow the entire empirical cycle. These assignments form the foundation for the research paper that the students write.
  Leerdoelen
  • Conduct a full deductive empirical research cycle, according to the academic standards: including a relevant explanatory research question, a theoretical framework and conceptual model, empirical data, clear-cut conclusions and discussion;
  • Combine qualitative and quantitative empirical research methods following a mixed methods research approach;
  • Communicate the research (report and presentation) in a transparent, clear and well-argued manner;
  • Work together as a research team with fellow students.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['BJJ Rombach, MSc', 'dr. AW Eigenraam', 'dr. CLP Pennings', 'dr. O Slivko', 'dr. R Cadario', 'dr. Y Zheng', 'dr.ir. OR Koppius', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts', 'RM Silva, MSc', 'Y Kuper, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Course content
The Research Project course is about learning how to conduct empirical research to solve business and societal problems. The course provides you both with hands-on experience on the main research methods and on acquiring the knowledge about the principles underlying these methods.

The design of the course covers all stages of the empirical cycle, in which a research problem is identified, relevant literature is explored, a research strategy is designed, qualitative and quantitative data are collected, processed, prepared and analysed, results of analysis are summarized in writing and presented in various ways in order to communicate the insights effectively and to further critical academic discussion.

During the course, students will work with different kinds of data, both qualitative and quantitative and stemming from different sources. Some data will be self-collected through qualitative interviews, surveys or online experiments. Other data may come from secondary (online) sources and will be downloaded for use in the project. Students will learn how to collect and (statistically) analyse these various kinds of data in order to answer research questions.

This course aims to enable you to approach managerial problems scientifically by learning how to: (1) understand what information is required to answer a question; (2) select the best method for obtaining the required information; (3) learn how to apply the different methods of data collection effectively; (4) apply statistical methods and draw appropriate conclusions from data; (5) engage in precise causal reasoning and understand the limits of data; (6) ethically and accurately communicate information and uncertainty.

Relevance
Organizations base their strategies on information about the business environment and their main stakeholders such as consumers, industrial buyers, distributors, employees, competitors, suppliers and regulatory bodies. The Research Project course deals with how to collect and analyse this information. The presentation and discussion of results of empirical research are part of everyday life. Not only in discussions about or presentations for business, but also in newspapers about business-related phenomena, and in academic papers. Understanding the way these empirical results have come about and have entered the business, public or academic debate is important in order to be able to judge the validity of the argumentation and the scope of the findings. A thorough comprehension of the many choices that are inherently part of conducting research, the various assumptions that underlie the valid use of research techniques, and the many ways that findings can be presented and communicated, are key ingredients of a critical academic attitude. The Research Project will contribute to these skills.
 


Place and function in the curriculum
The Research Project course covers block 5, 6 and 7 of the bachelor curriculum. It is jointly offered by the department of Marketing Management and the department of Technology and Operations Management. It builds on knowledge and skills obtained in Year 1 courses on Philosophy of Science, Marketing Management, Strategic Business Plan, Organizational Behaviour, Mathematics and Statistics.

Connection with the RSM mission
The Research Project course contributes to the overall mission of the school to develop business leaders that can be a force of positive change, by providing the future leaders with the tools and knowledge of research. The course is aimed to make students understand the value of accurate information to solve business problems. It enables students to critically reflect on a business research problem, to evaluate how research findings from within or outside their organization help to (not) solve the problem, and to initiate research in domains where relevant business insight is missing. For the course assignments, a general theme or business or societal problem will be chosen that fits the mission of the School. For example, how to change consumer behaviours towards healthier or more sustainable choices.

Course structure
The course research project runs over three blocks in the second year of the bachelor program. Each year, a specific topic or research problem related to the mission of the school will be defined that connects the work in the three blocks.

The first block (block 5) concentrates on defining the research problem and learning how to use literature and exploratory research methods to get more and deeper insight into the research problem. Students learn how to formulate research questions, learn about different research designs, setting up research preliminaries, how to collect and summarize literature, how to conduct and report and visualize qualitative and quantitative (secondary) data, how to formulate hypotheses, and how to communicate their problem and findings in an effective way. 

The second block (block 6) focuses on survey research methods. A transition is made from exploratory research in the previous block to more confirmatory methods. This block is about quantitative data, data collection by means of questionnaires and analysing data with inferential statistics. Students learn how to develop valid and reliable measures for the constructs in their research model, learn to design and distribute a proper questionnaire (‘the art of asking questions’), learn about sampling methods, and learn how to use and statistically analyse the collected data to evaluate research hypotheses. Both the knowledge and implied skills of measurement theory and inferential statistical methods will be assessed.

The third block (block 7) puts causality and experimental methods in focus. More specifically, students learn about how to assess causality using the experimental method, learn about the main experimental designs, how to apply experimental or statistical control, and learn how to analyse large data sets using multivariate methods (specifically, regression analysis). Students learn about the use of experiments, the boundaries of correlational analysis, the need for multivariate analysis, the background and application of regression analysis, and the presentation of research results.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals

After successful completion of the Research Project course students have the knowledge and practical skills to conduct basic empirical research.

More specifically, students are expected to be able to:
  • define a research problem, formulate a research question and develop research propositions, and understand what information is required to answer a question
  • learn how to make use of a literature study and exploratory research methods to gather insight into the topic of interest
  • learn how to develop interview protocols, conduct interviews, and process and present the results of these interviews
  • learn how to download online data from secondary sources or Internet, design stimuli and measures to collect data effectively, set up and conduct (online) surveys, design and conduct (online) surveys and experiments consistent with the research problem under study
  • understand, motivate and apply statistical techniques to analyse and report the collected quantitative data, and validly infer from these analyses
  • summarize research findings in well-thought-out writing, present those findings in various presentation forms, and professionally give feedback about the merits and limitations of the research conducted by others.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Het doel van Research Project is een verdere kennismaking met de sociologische onderzoekspraktijk. Centraal staat het zelfstandig verbinden van sociologische theorie en empirisch onderzoek. In groepen van gemiddeld 5 personen wordt aan het leeronderzoek gewerkt. Het onderzoek wordt begeleid door één van de docenten. Iedere groep verricht een kwantitatief onderzoek naar een vooraf gegeven probleemstelling die wordt beantwoord op basis van bestaande surveygegevens. Aan de hand van verschillende opdrachten wordt de probleemstelling uitgewerkt tot een onderzoekbaar conceptueel model. Op basis van secundaire survey-data wordt gerapporteerd over de operationalisering van de variabelen uit het conceptuele model en over de toetsing van de hypothesen. De opdrachten vormen de bouwstenen van een onderzoeksverslag dat de integrale verslaglegging van het verrichte onderzoek behelst (bestaande uit een theoretisch kader, de resultaten van de data-analyse en de inhoudelijke conclusies).
  Leerdoelen Aan het eind van dit vak zijn studenten in staat zijn om zelfstandig de empirische cyclus van een kwantitatief onderzoek te doorlopen. Dit betekent meer concreet dat studenten na het af- ronden van dit vak:
 
  • een sociologisch relevante verklarende probleemstelling kunnen uitwerken;
  • zelfstandig een literatuurstudie kunnen verrichten waarmee een zo goed mogelijk beredeneerd antwoord op de probleemstelling kan worden gegeven;
  • een conceptueel model met daarbij behorende hypothesen kunnen opstellen;
  • secundaire data kunnen gebruiken;
  • op een verantwoorde manier variabelen kunnen operationaliseren;
  • vooropgestelde hypothesen kunnen toetsen met een regressieanalyse;
  • helder en logisch kunnen rapporteren over hun onderzoeksresultaten.

lecturers: ['dr. M de Vries Mecheva', "dr. TM Marreiros Bago d'Uva", 'prof.dr. JLW van Kippersluis']
text:
Inhoud

DEFAULT HAS TOO MANY CHARACTERS (length = 6090, max length = 4000)

Topics covered
1. The structure of a research paper;
2. causality;
3. null hypothesis testing;
4. interpreting regression results, including p-values and confidence intervals;
5. understanding bias using the potential outcomes framework;
6. how to use uni- and multivariate regression to make predictions;
7. why non-experimental data typically do not yield consistent estimators of causal effects;
8. the internal and external validity of experimental results;
9. logit average marginal effects and the linear probability model;
10. interpretation of the coefficients of dummy variables and interaction terms;
11. forecasting;
12. using Stata.
Timeline of the learning activities

  • There will be four plenary lectures: in weeks 1, 2, 3, and 6.
  • In the first three weeks, you will complete three online quizzes on Canvas, which will guide you through the learning materials: the first quiz provides information on the topic of this year’s regular assignment: equality of opportunity; the second quiz aims to improve your understanding of econometrics; and the third quiz helps you to brush up your Stata skills. Completion of these online quizzes is compulsory to pass the course and to be allowed to submit your individual homework (see the next item), but they will not count towards your final grade.
  • In weeks 1 through 3, students will submit individual homework every week (3 times 5% of your final grade). These three homework problem sets will be graded individually, and form the basis of the regular assignment report that you will write together with your fellow group members (see below). If you get stuck, you may consult your team members but the answers should be your own. Guidelines on how to report your results (e.g. references, tables, figures) will be provided and these guidelines will be strictly enforced by the graders of your individual homework and your group reports.
  • Together with your fellow group members, you will hand in the research proposal for the creative assignment in week 5 (10% of your final grade). During the compulsory midterm meeting with an OP team member in week 5, you will discuss this research proposal, as well as any questions you may have about the course materials.
  • You will write the reports on the regular (25% of your final grade) and the creative assignment (20% of your final grade) together with your three fellow group members, to be submitted in weeks 5 and 7, respectively. These reports will be assessed at the group (and not the individual) level. There will be inspection sessions for the regular and creative assignment reports, after the lecture of week 6 and in week 9, respectively.
  • We encourage all students to meet with their fellow group members (in person, or through Zoom or Skype) at least once a week, for at least two hours, to work on the assignments. Schedule tese meetings at the start of the course. This should enable you to learn from each other.
  • During the optional question sessions which, depending on the week, will be held once or twice per week, your group will have the opportunity to discuss with the RP team any questions you may have on that week’s topics. You can submit your questions by email to RP team member [TBD] until 5 PM on the day before a question session, to allow the RP team members to prepare in advance. These question sessions form the core of this course, and we recommend that your group uses this opportunity to get personalized guidance approximately three times throughout the course, depending on need. Try to have all team members attend. Brief answers to the questions that came in will be published in the Q&A-thread on the Canvas discussion board.
  • In week 8, there will be a compulsory oral defense of your group work (30% of your final grade, differentiation of the grade between group members is ...
Leerdoelen

Research Project

Increasingly, employers are looking to hire employees who know how to handle big data files, or who have the skills to use the results from data analyses as inputs for operational or policy advice. Our aim is to help you understand how to apply modern econometric methods, and to help you develop the skills that will allow you to do quantitative empirical research yourself.

What will you learn?

In this course, Research Project, you will apply the econometric methods from the course Introductory Econometrics to several data sets. You will write two reports, in the form of research articles, describing your findings. We will refer to the assignments that will help you to write these two reports as the “regular assignment” and the “creative assignment”.

Writing these reports will help you improve your understanding of econometric methods, your Stata skills, and you will gain experience with reporting your findings in a structured manner. Each of the two reports will look like academic articles, following the guidelines that you learned during the course Academic Skills. Taken together, these components of Research Project will provide you with a solid basis for writing your Bachelor’s thesis.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course content, description
​The Research Methods in Finance course gives students the opportunity to acquire the statistical and econometric skills needed to work with data, conduct an empirical analysis, interpret and report the results in the context of an academic paper or thesis. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the Master Thesis. Students will attend lectures and workshop sessions, will work with Stata (and Excel) and have to complete an empirical assignment. 

For the assignment, students can choose between two tracks: Corporate Finance or Investments. Otherwise, the two tracks are identical. The skills students train are the same (e.g., processing data, implementing empirical methods using statistical software, and interpreting results), and so is the exam.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After having followed this course, students should know how to write and structure a thesis, be able to collect and process data, and be able to use statistical software for conducting an empirical analysis. Importantly, students should understand the main econometric methods used in finance and apply these to answer research questions.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. J Hofhuis', 'dr. JCF Schaap', 'dr. MJ Berghman', 'dr. SJ Opree', 'dr. TJ van Woudenberg', 'JA Schlicht', 'K Noordzij', 'prof.dr. MNM Verboord', 'prof.dr. MSSE Janssen', 'prof.dr. W de Koster']
text:
Inhoud During the research traineeship in the first year of the Research master's programme, students participate in one of the Faculty's research projects or in an external research project which is led by a Faculty member or in which a Faculty Member is involved as an advisor. The traineeship results in (a substantial contribution to) a research paper or research report and familiarizes students with some of the most vital research activities: developing a research project, writing a research proposal, doing the actual research and data analysis, and presenting research findings in the form of a research paper or research report and an oral presentation. In principle, the research subject should fit within the fields that are covered in the research master's and it should fit within the Faculty's current research projects and research interests. In order to guarantee the suitability and quality of the supervision and the traineeship, a concise research traineeship proposal should be submitted to the Programme directors who need to approve of the chosen subject and content of the traineeship before the start of the traineeship. A research traineeship includes at least the following components:
  • Research activities
  • One presentation
  • Self Reflection
  • Contribution to research report or research paper
  • Attendance and active participation in presentations by fellow students.
Leerdoelen Students have developed the knowlegde and skills to:
  • Make a substantial contribution to the development and execution of a research project
  • Give an oral presentation about a research project
  • Make a substantial contribution to the research paper or research report in which the main findings and conclusions of the research project are presented
  • Collaborate with other researchers in a team.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Short description of the course
The course Research training I deals with common univariate statistical methods and techniques in an applied empirical context. The course gives a start to independent assessment and application of of elementary quantitative empirical research. It has a theoretical part (the online modules with corresponding material), which emphasizes the theory of statistical methods and techniques, and an applied part, which considers the application of these methods and techniques with the statistical software program R.

Results of statistical research are routinely found in various presentations, journal articles and reports. As a consequence, it is essential for managers to have the knowledge to be aware of the assumptions and analyses on which these results are based and to be able to judge the manner in which these results are interpreted.

The course Research training I builds on the course Statistics (BPE1101) and prepares for the course Research training II (BPE1104), but of course also for various research-oriented courses in general.


Course information
It is assumed that the course Statistics (BPE1101) has been completed.

Below summarizes the topics covered in the four modules of this course. These topics are introduced in the videos about the theory and are practiced in the tutorials about the use of the statistical software R.

Summary of topics covered per module:
1 Elements of statistical research, choices of methods and techniques, measurement levels and role of models
2 Sample and population, sampling methods, descriptive analysis statistical estimation
3 Statistical hypothesis testing
4 Overview bivariate techniques

The course has four weeks during which the material is explained. Use is made of pre-recorded online videos for both the theory and the tutorials. In addition, an online platform will be used to make exercises. A recent version of the time table is available via timetables.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals
The objective of the course is that participants:
(1) gain insights into the theoretical background of statistical methods and techniques; and
(2) develop practical skills in applying statistical methods and techniques.

More specifically, the learning goals are stated as the ability to:
* Explain and reproduce elementary methodological parts of statistical research, like sampling methods and modelling;
* Visualize assumptions about empirical processes by means of a causal diagram;
* Formulate research hypotheses;
* Apply univariate statistical methods and techniques in well-defined problems;
* Apply univariate statistical methods and techniques in a programming environment. Belangrijk om te weten Literature
The teaching material consists of:
(i) online videos and slides on the theory of statistical methods and techniques
(ii) online videos and program code explaining the application of statistical software R;
(iii) online exercise material.

text:
Inhoud Short description of the course
The course Research training II deals with common bivariate statistical methods and techniques in an applied empirical context. The course gives a start to independent assessment and application of of elementary quantitative empirical research. It has a theoretical part (the online modules with corresponding material), which emphasizes the theory of statistical methods and techniques, and an applied part, which considers the application of these methods and techniques with the statistical software program R.

Results of statistical research are routinely found in various presentations, journal articles and reports. As a consequence, it is essential for managers to have the knowledge to be aware of the assumptions and analyses on which these results are based and to be able to judge the manner in which these results are interpreted.

The course Research training II builds on the courses Statistics (BPE1101) and Research training I (BPE1103) and prepares for research-oriented courses in general.


Course information
It is assumed that the courses Statistics (BPE1101) and Research training I (BPE1103) have been completed.

Below summarizes the topics covered in the four modules of this course. These topics are introduced in the videos about the theory and are practiced in the tutorials about the use of the statistical software R.

Summary of topics covered per module:
1 Statistical independence, contingency tables
2 Covariance and correlations
3 Two-sample t-tests
4 Analysis of variance

The course has four weeks during which the material is explained. Use is made of pre-recorded online videos for both the theory and the tutorials. In addition, an online platform will be used to make exercises. A recent version of the time table is available via timetables.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals

The objective of the course is that participants:
(1) gain insights into the theoretical background of statistical methods and techniques; and
(2) develop practical skills in applying statistical methods and techniques.

More specifically, the learning goals are stated as the ability to:
* Explain and reproduce elementary methodological parts of statistical research, like statistical independence and research hypotheses;
* Visualize assumptions about empirical processes by means of a causal diagram;
* Formulate research hypotheses;
* Apply bivariate statistical methods and techniques in well-defined problems;
* Apply bivariate statistical methods and techniques in a programming environment. Belangrijk om te weten Literature
Course materials consist of:
(i) online videos and slides about the theory of statistical methods and techniques;
(ii) online videos and programming code with explanation of the use of the statistical software R;
(iii) online exercises.

Summary of topics covered per module:
1 Statistical independence, contingency tables
2 Covariance and correlations
3 Two-sample t-tests
4 Analysis of variance

The course has four weeks during which the material is explained. Use is made of pre-recorded online videos for both the theory and the tutorials. In addition, an online platform will be used to make exercises. A recent version of the time table is available via timetables. Leerdoelen Learning goals
The objective of the course is that participants:
(1) gain insights into the theoretical background of statistical methods and techniques; and
(2) develop practical skills in applying statistical methods and techniques.

More specifically, the learning goals are stated as the ability to:
* Explain and reproduce elementary methodological parts of statistical research, like statistical independence and research hypotheses;
* Visualize assumptions about empirical processes by means of a causal diagram;
* Formulate research hypotheses;
* Apply bivariate statistical methods and techniques in well-defined problems;
* Apply bivariate statistical methods and techniques in a programming environment. Belangrijk om te weten Literature
Course materials consist of:
(i) online videos and slides about the theory of statistical methods and techniques;
(ii) online videos and programming code with explanation of the use of the statistical software R;
(iii) online exercises.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Qualitative research methods will help you study phenomenon in organizations through the eyes of people, such as how corporate culture influences individual behaviors, how teams make decisions, how branding and packaging influence consumer behavior, or why do some people work better with flexible work schedules and others do not? The objective of Research Training III is to train students to understand, design, and conduct scientific qualitative research. These objectives guide the course’s structure, content, and assessment of the course. The course consists of four modules.

In module 1, students are introduced with fundamentals of qualitative research. We will discuss the philosophical assumptions on which qualitative research is based, and the difference between qualitative and quantitative research. An important focus of this module is how to develop qualitative research questions that are practically relevant and grounded in theory. Furthermore, we will take a closer look at the role of the qualitative researcher and the important concepts of ‘reflexivity’ and ‘reflectivity’. At the end of this module, students should be able to answer the following questions: What kind of research questions can be answered through qualitative research? What are the characteristics of qualitative research?

In module 2, we will discuss various qualitative research methods (e.g. case study, action research), data sources and data collection techniques (interviews, observations, text analysis). We discuss when the methods can be used, what the method entails, and how they are applied. A closer look is given to interviews as a data collection method, assessing different interview approaches and types of interview questions. Students learn how an interview is structured and what to pay attention to during the interview. Students will start to design questions themselves and practice an interview.

In module 3, data analysis is discussed, in particular how to code data. Students learn how data from interviews is prepared for analysis, and which (basic) coding strategies they can apply to analyze the data. The interpretation of data and theory building is also discussed. Furthermore, students will learn to apply coding techniques to analyze interview data.

In module 4, students learn how to conduct rigorous qualitative research. To this end, attention is paid to techniques and principles that can be applied throughout the research to enhance the quality and scientific rigorousness of research findings.
  Leerdoelen After completing this course, the student will be able to:
  • Describe the differences between qualitative and quantitative research
  • Develop qualitative research questions that are grounded in theory and practically relevant
  • Identify strengths and weaknesses of qualitative research
  • Distinguish between different qualitative research methods
  • Conduct qualitative data collection and analysis
  • Evaluate scientific qualitative research
Belangrijk om te weten The content of this course will be taught through online videos, seminars, readings, and through assignments. Students will have the opportunity to reflect on and apply content in small-scale seminars. Attendance of the seminars is mandatory. Assessment will take place through three individual assignments and a group exam.

M Avraamidou', 'dr. O Nyirubugara', 'FKS Robinson', 'FM Bellaard, MA', 'G Bidassi, MA', 'ML Gaitan Aguilar, MA', 'N Maru', 'P Mashigo, MA', 'PM Edwards', 'S Lambrechts', 'S Pieters', 'TTV Nguyen, MSc', 'Y Leder, MA']
text:
Inhoud This research workshop introduces students to the main issues concerned with doing cross-national comparative research in communication and media, while it also offers them advanced training in writing a comprehensive literature review on a research topic of their own choosing. It is a practical course that introduces students to a number of important steps in the choices to make when carrying out cross-national and/or comparative research. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The main theoretical principles and methods of cross-national comparative research in the field of media and communication;
  • The possibilities and limitations of conducting a literature reviews.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Conduct a systematic analysis and critical evaluation of the secondary literature on selected issues or topics in the field of communication and media;
  • Write a clear and balanced literature review as a team, presenting the state of knowledge regarding their chosen cross-national and comparative research topic;
  • Work collaboratively on small and large international teams while profiting from and reflecting on the diverse input this entails;
  • Manage a team project

course_title: Research Workshop Management of Arts and Culture
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course will provide students an understanding of management in the cultural sector. The starting point of view is that cultural organizations such as museums, venues, musical societies, theatre companies, and other creative enterprises possess particular characteristics from an organizational point-of- view that influence the way they operate. Cultural/arts management has developed as a full-fledged discipline. Cultural organizations increasingly need to develop management strategies to realize their objectives, paying attention to their potential visitors-audiences-users, and to the financial constraints that may hinder their activities. The cases selected by the students will be used to study and illustrate the impact that strategic management can have on the performance of cultural institutions. Students will have to apply the theoretical framework to cultural organizations in order to see how theory translates into reality.
 
Note: The maximum number of participants is 18.
  Leerdoelen This research workshop will familiarize students with the management of cultural organizations by case study research methods. They learn to connect theory to practice by conducting their own small research project about an existing cultural organization.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text: Inhoud From Hobbiton to Graceland to 221b Baker Street, media- and cultural tourism – visiting places in the wake of popular culture & heritage – is a growing industry. While connected to traditional forms of sightseeing, media- and cultural tourism raises different questions about the relationship between the mass media, its audiences, and physical places. What are tourists looking for? How are these attractions marketed and managed? And what about the locals, who see their home suddenly becoming a ‘fictional’ location swarming with tourists? What does the increased prominence of this kind of tourism say about the relationship between imagination and reality in an era characterized by an increasing omnipresence of the media and global mobility? These are the sort of questions asked in this course. Students will explore different aspects of media- and cultural tourism, from its origins and history, its connection to other parts of the tourism industry, its relationships to audience- and fan-practices, managerial aspects, and tourist experiences in order to foster a sophisticated understanding of this multifaceted phenomenon. Starting from this, students will create their own small research project on an aspect of media- or cultural tourism that interests them. Students will use research techniques and methodology from cultural studies and qualitative sociology, hence it is advised to be familiar with these before partaking the course.  Leerdoelen This research workshop will introduce students to the key issues in media- and cultural tourism: that is, tourism inspired by (popular) media, such as films, TV-series, music, literature and video-games. Students will be able to identify the current themes and challenges to orient themselves within the ongoing academic debates surrounding media- and cultural tourism. Students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in academic publications. Students will extend this knowledge through conducting a small-scale qualitative research through hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data, developing a research design and reporting on their findings.

lecturers: ['A Cordina, LL.M', 'dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. C Bian', 'dr. FL Stevens', 'dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr. J Hornig', 'dr. M Stambulski', 'dr. P Wilinski', 'dr. SF Airey', 'drs. FJ Unz, LL.M', 'EW de Waegh, LL.M', 'I Aksakal', 'J Bonat', 'JP Valdivia Pizarro', 'mr. E Silva de Freitas, LL.M', 'mr. LE Dijkman', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema', 'SD Efstathiou']
text:
Inhoud The Research & Writing Skills course has the objective of developing practical skills in doing legal research and in writing legal texts. The course will assist students with developing expertise in three different legal methods, namely classical black letter law research, comparative law research and legal research design. Law and Ethics will be part of courses in block 2 to combine substantive and social aspects of law at the same time. The skills of the course of Research and Writing Skills will be trained through writing papers, oral presentations and group discussions.

All topics you will be studying relate to commercial law, with a further focus on questions relating to the master variation you have chosen. This way, the course not only introduces you to legal research, improving skills necessary for the remaining of the course as well as your legal career, but also introduces you to the exciting field of commercial law, which will be explored for the rest of the year.

During the Research & Writing Skills course you will be confronted with many practical and legal issues from recent years. Common to these issues is the international nature and complexity of the legal relations involved. In order to find sound and workable solutions to these problems, you must learn to determine the relevant international standard(s) applicable. Where no uniform international standard exists, a comparative legal approach may be necessary to determine the main schools of thought about certain issues adopted by different legal systems.

The internal moot case plays a central role in the Research & Writing Skills course curriculum. It means that (almost) all of the assignments are linked to this case and constitute important building blocks that you use, structuring your argumentation for instance when drafting a legal memorandum (it will be explained further in a section with the assignments’ overview). For example, the comparative law assignment concerns force majeure, which is a relevant legal concept used in the moot case. Case reports that are discussed during the workgroup sessions are also useful authorities that can be used to support legal argumentation during the internal moot.

Each week you will face more and more challenging legal concepts, which will be based on (building on) the knowledge already acquired from the previous sessions. It means that the course requires your full attention.

[IMPORTANT NOTE to Exchange Students]

Dear Exchange Students, Research and Writing Skills courses designed for different variations of Commercial Law LL.M. (RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84) offer an intensive small group teaching and training. These courses are taught by the same teachers, have a very similar structure and will allow you to acquire the same set of skills. Please bear in mind, however, that in case when the limited capacity of the chosen track is reached, we might be forced to assign you to another Research and Writing Skills variation of Commercial Law LL.M. (thus another course from those available under these codes RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84). Leerdoelen The course Research & Writing Skills has not only the objective of introducing the student to the subject matter by way of in-depth study of certain selected topics within the field of international commercial law, but also by way of developing the skills that are required for conducting legal research and are transferrable in their future (legal) career. After this course the student should have an ease of using the following research and writing skills both while working independently but also when collaborating with others.

course_title: Research and Writing Skills in International and European Union Law
lecturers: ['AE Christopoulou, LLM', 'dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. F Coman Kund', 'dr. SF Airey', 'mr. D Stankovic', 'prof.dr. A Arcuri', 'prof.dr. E Hey', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg']
text:
Inhoud he substantive theme of this course focuses on European Union (EU) and international law and in particular on the interactions between these legal orders, with significant attention devoted to processes of economic integration. During the course, students will acquire active working knowledge of essential international and EU law principles, rules, institutions and decision-making processes. Students will be given the opportunity to practice their research, writing and presentation skills by considering some of the following broad themes: the evolution of the international and EU legal orders; the roles of various international and EU actors and the interplay between them; the mechanisms for and intricacies of decision-making in a multilevel context; market integration within the EU and economic cooperation on the international plane; the role of courts and compliance bodies in international and EU law, etc. Throughout the course students will be invited to consider also the socio-economic and political context in which international and EU law instruments and actors operate. Furthermore, they will consider how international and EU law may impact societal values related to the rule of law democracy, human rights and the protection of the environment. This also entails taking into consideration ethical concerns in the development and application of EU and international law.

During the course students will practice both substantive knowledge and legal skills in a ‘learn by doing’ fashion through various individual and group assignments. Class interactions and group discussions will play a key role in stimulating the learning process. Students will develop their research, writing and presentation skills by analyzing relevant legal developments and by placing these developments in the critical context offered by academic literature. By combining substantive knowledge with academic skills students will develop their own critical analysis of the role law plays at EU and international levels. In order to develop these skills, several sessions will be devoted to both research methodology and different legal methods (e.g. case analysis, comparative legal research). Students are also encouraged to examine the relevance of other disciplines, such as economics, political science, public administration, ethics and sociology, for a better understanding of the context and dynamics of the European and international legal orders.   

The legal skills acquired and developed during this course will prepare students for the subsequent courses of the master programme, in which active academic learning is key. Moreover, students will be developing a solid basis for enhancing their knowledge and ability to work with EU and international law. In essence, this course provides students with transferable knowledge and skills, including the capacity to identify complex legal problems and develop solutions thereto, research a given legal topic, frame a research question, work with large volumes of legal information and select relevant legal sources, conduct rigorous legal analysis, synthesize their findings in a well-structured and written paper, and orally present their findings. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the IEUL master, including the finalization of the master thesis.
  Leerdoelen In this course students explore the legal dimensions of cooperation at the level of the European Union and at the international level. This course gives a foretaste of topics, which will be revisited and dealt with in greater depth during subsequent courses of the IEUL master programme. This course serves a dual purpose: (1) it provides a general introduction to public international and EU law at master level studies and (2) it provides training for the acquisition and development of legal research, writing and presentation skills.

More specifically this course will enable you to:
  • Conduct research on a specific legal topic and write down concisely and clearly the results of your research
  • Identify, understand and analyze, including by way of comparative analysis, relevant legal questions pertaining to International and EU law
  • Becoming aware of the multifarious effects, dynamics, and interconnectedness of legal institutions of International and European Union law, including by considering insights from other disciplines, such as political science, ethics and economics
  • Find, analyze and assess primary and secondary International and EU legal sources for the purpose of answering legal questions
  • Develop critical legal thinking and reasoning in applying International and EU law
  • Present your work in a clear and structured manner to a legal and non-legal audience
  • Collaborating with others, especially through team work and engaging in a mutual peer review process

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. JP Madiedo Montanez', 'MJ Iwanczuk-Prost', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The research fundamentals course is designed to support the individual master thesis project. The course focuses on the study of the various thesis research methodologies that are available for conducting research in Innovation Management. These include qualitative research (case studies or grounded theory), surveys and archival data analyses, and experiments.
The course main components are the Research Fundamentals I & II courses. Research Fundamentals I comprises a set of introductory lectures. The goal of these lectures is to discuss the basic concepts of research and for students to get a better understanding of how to design a research project. Students will work on topics that go from developing a research question to making a preliminary selection of a research method for their study. Research Fundamentals II comprises group sessions and workshops, specific to a certain research method. These sessions will provide students with in-depth knowledge and skills that can be applied on their own thesis. 
This course works according to the flipped classroom principle, which means that the student needs to prepare before class following the suggested material. The lectures are used for interactive feedback, gamification, and in-class discussion, to deepen the student’s knowledge of the methodology and to provide specific feedback on her/his work. Meanwhile, through the assignments, the student will work on the method section for the thesis, integrating what has been learnt through the course.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After this course, students:
  • Are able to make the distinction between qualitative and quantitative methodologies in studies of Innovation Management.
  • Are able to devise a research design and communicate it in a convincing way through a mini-research proposal.
  • Are able to make a choice between qualitative and quantitative analysis in accordance with the research question of their thesis.
  • Are able to use the selected methodology for answering the research question of their thesis.
  • Are able to plan and execute the actions to complete a thesis in the area of Innovation Management.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. FL Truijens', 'dr. M Boffo', 'T Laure, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

The course will give an overview of key research designs and approaches used in behavior change research, including quantitative, qualitative and mixed-methods approaches, and critical appraisal techniques. The focus is on how to address dilemmas in everyday research practice with a special attention on validity, feasibility, and reproducibility. Students are stimulated to develop 1) an understanding of the research process involved in the evaluation of behavior change interventions along all phases of design and implementation, and 2) a creative, yet pragmatic scientific thinking. The course will prepare students with the knowledge and skills to carry out research projects, such as their MSc thesis. 

The overarching goal of this course is twofold: provide students with a set of research principles, guidelines, tools, and skills necessary to design an empirical research project, and promote a critical understanding of methodological, ethical and pragmatic issues in the development and implementation of behavior change interventions. The course aims to introduce the fundamental ingredients of the research process for behavior change interventions, which are not exclusive to the “digital” context but are transversal to any type of complex behavioral intervention.

Leerdoelen
At the end of this course, you will be able to...
  1. Critically evaluate methodological and ethical aspects involved in the evaluation of a behavior change intervention, in the light of context, target population and type of intervention 
  2. Apply the basics of thematic analysis of qualitative data
  3. Design a detailed (mock) research proposal for the evaluation of a behavior change intervention by:
    1. Conceptualizing relevant and testable research question(s) and related hypotheses, and explain the background rationale
    2. Selecting appropriate research designs and methods to address the targeted research question(s) 
    3. Detailing all key aspects of the study methodology in relation to the study goals and scientific reproducibility and open science principles

course_title: Research on Social Enterprise and Entrepreneurship
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Class sessions will be devoted to reviewing and critiquing readings on social entrepreneurship and exposing you to different theoretical and analytical lenses through which to view SE research. We will also discuss pathways to make your research accessible to a broader audience, to develop research that is practically useful and how to identify “relevant” research questions.

This course is taught by Prof. Johanna Mair (Hertie School). Leerdoelen This summer school course covers major and foundational topics research on social entrepreneurship and social enterprise (SE). The objective of the course are, (1) to familiarize you with some of the core concepts and primary theoretical underpinnings of research on social entrepreneurship; (2) to help you gain a stronger understanding of, and think critically about, the SE domain, including its research requirements and methods for publishing scholarly research in management and organizational studies; and, (3) to provide a forum where you can further develop your thinking and writing skills as a social entrepreneurship scholar. 

The primary purpose of the course is to develop your ability to do scholarly research in this area. Therefore, the course should help you to (1) develop, refining, and present your own research ideas; (2) gain a better understanding of the research and publication processes; and (3) empower you to find your own voice.
