college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
Students will first be introduced in the field of cultural tourism, as an increasingly important subfield or niche of tourism in general. Cultural tourism has a long history, with roots reaching back to the Grand Tour in the 18th Century. Since then cultural tourism has been booming. Due in part to globalisation and postmodernism the character of concepts such as 'culture' and 'local identity' has become more fluid, with changing meanings to different groups in society. The ways in which tourism, visual culture and local identity are intertwining is the central theme and starting point of this research seminar. Next to that, several important qualitative research methodologies will be touched upon, familiarizing students with doing qualitative research towards cultural tourism by means of content analysis, participant observation, in-depth interviewing and ‘netnography’, amongst others. After this, students will be sent out into the field, explore how issues related to cultural tourism are acquiring significance in practice and engage hands-on in applying their methodological as well as theoretical knowledge in this field to engage with a small-scale empirical research project in line with their own interests.
Leerdoelen
Students will be made familiar with a wide range of qualitative research methods, which will prepare them for conducting an independent research towards the way(s) in which place, culture and tourism intertwine and intersect in empirical reality. In order to do so, students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in the field of cultural tourism in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in publications. Following this, students will apply their knowledge in a small-scale qualitative research, developing a research design and acquiring hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data in addition to presenting findings amidst peers.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Responsible Business Leadership (BT2101) is a course organized by the department of Business-Society Management and examines business in an increasingly global world, where organizations operate in a complex natural, social and economic environment. Corporations are expected to act responsibly toward various stakeholders, such as governments, competitors, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs), shareholders, suppliers and employees, to do the morally right thing, and to foster sustainable development. These high expectations can be challenging, yet they also create business opportunities. In particular, business plays a pivotal role in realizing the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals by creating not only economic value, but also ecological and social value.
Responsible Business Leadership is meant to be a provocative course, living up to RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change in the world by addressing the role of business and business leaders in both locally and globally relevant problems, such as inequality, corruption and climate change. While business is often a part of these problems, we examine how it can also be part of the solution. You are therefore encouraged to think about how business can create value not just specifically for shareholders, but also for other stakeholders, including society in general.

After introducing the Sustainable Development Goals as an overarching framework in Lecture 1, we will give in Lecture 2 and 3 a broad introduction to the central concepts of Sustainability—which is key in Workshop 1—and Responsibility. Lectures 4 and 5, which are central to Workshop 2, subsequently examine how sustainability and responsibility allow companies to go beyond business-as-usual in more specific domains such as strategy and entrepreneurship, as well as how this helps to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. Lecture 6 introduces the third central concept of this course, Ethics, to which Workshop 3 will subsequently be devoted.
The three workshops that are intermixed with these six lectures focus, respectively, on developing your vision on sustainability and your authentic leadership, formulating a proposal for a corporate responsibility strategy and discussing managerial moral dilemmas with other students. These workshops thus make the course material more directly relevant to you, by linking it to your personal development and awareness of sustainable challenges.
To help you further engage with the course material, supplementary video materials and animations will be made available. Finally, after six lectures, the online written test will be organized.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals
After this course, you will be able to:
• Explain the roles that companies play in the creation of and finding solutions for local and global sustainability issues, including corruption, climate change and inequality.
• Apply concepts and theories relevant to how organizations can and should contribute to solving these issues through the way they organize themselves internally and the way they interact with external stakeholders.
• Explain your own standpoint on how companies can contribute to solving these sustainability issues.
• Create a plan on how to contribute to solving these issues

course_title: Responsible Innovation - Digital Technologies and Power: Surveillance Capitalism
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

How is AI shaping our understanding of ourselves and our societies? AI can be seen as a technology of extraction: from the energy and minerals needed to build and sustain its infrastructure, to the labor behind “automated” services, to the data AI collects from us. In the book “The Atlas of AI” Kate Crawford offers us a political and a material perspective on what it takes to make artificial intelligence and where it goes wrong. While technical systems present a veneer of objectivity, they are always systems of power.

In this course, we will critically read the book “The Atlas of AI” and review it in the form of group debate sessions. This serves as an exercise in critically investigating long-term broad societal impacts of technological advances.

Leerdoelen

At the end of this course the participants will:

  • Be able to evaluate frameworks for societal impacts of digital technologies;
  • Be able to analyze the contents of the book;
  • Be able to apply the framework presented in the book to their own personal experiences, and connect to their disciplinary perspectives.

course_title: Responsible Innovation - Ethics, Culture and Biotechnology
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Digital and bio-based technologies are often claimed to make our lives easier, healthier and more efficient. Yet, their implementation in practice often entails important ethical concerns. For instance, when sensing technologies penetrate the bodily boundaries, becoming ingestible, implantable and embeddable, the body turns into a networked platform, whose integrity and safety can be compromised (in case of a hacking attack). Likewise, biometric information tracking or affective computing commodify and expose to surveillance the very physical conditions of human identity.

Furthermore, biotechnological practices (such as genetic modification) that involve manipulation of living beings present a challenge to traditional notions of nature and the human body. This is particularly true of synthetic biology, a form of bioengineering which includes both the design and construction of new biological parts, devices, and systems and the re-designing of existing natural biological systems. These developments pose pressing and urgent questions. Firstly, who has the right to re-design life? This is ultimately a question of legal and moral ownership and of the commodification of life and nature. Secondly, what limits do we, as a society, wish to impose on biotechnological innovation involving nature and the human body? And what notion of 'being human' or human dignity and of nature are these limits based on?

The starting point of this course is that digital and bio-based technology is testing accepted ethical and aesthetic values concerning the human body and nature to such an extent that we need multiple perspectives in our search for a theoretical and practical position on these new challenges. In particular, we will consider the contribution of art in this debate. We will discuss how artworks that engage with biometric sensing and practices of manipulating living matter enable the artist and the beholder to actively experiment with new ways of being, behaving and constituting subjectivities in relation to technological developments.

Leerdoelen

At the end of this course students should be able to

  • Describe key ethical issues in digital technology related to the body;

  • Describe key historical and cultural issues in biotechnology and its products;

  • Identify individual and social barriers that play a role in the application of (bio)technological innovations;

  • Identify various perspectives and values in the public debate surrounding technological development (such as posthumanism and transhumanism);

  • Reflect upon the role of the industry and the entrepreneur in addressing ethical issues regarding a technological product involving living matter and human body;

  • Develop debating skills and critical reading skills.*

*) The final course outline may differ.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

The world faces grand societal challenges. One of these is climate change. Most scientists agree that the emission of greenhouse gasses leads to global warming. This makes climate more extreme. Climate change impacts ecosystems including biodiversity, and also impacts human society. In turn, each of these three impact each other, leading to disastrous self-reenforcing effects. In its report Climate Change 2022 – Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) pleads for Climate Resilient Development. To make this happen, cooperation between governments, companies, and civil society is needed. Without innovation it will be impossible, and this innovation should be shaped in the form of standards. The concepts innovation and standardisation are core in this module. The assignments focus on their relevance for tackling the issue of climate change but the module addresses other areas of innovation and standardisation as well.

These other areas may relate to other grand societal challenges such as poverty, depletion of natural resources, housing and information security, and to more specific fields such as the Internet of Things (IoT), 5th generation networks, service platforms, the circular economy, energy transition and fair-trade products. These have in common that they trigger drastically changes in the way firms are innovating and combine business interests with societal dimensions. In their innovation process, companies have to cooperate with other firms because products and services offered by different companies get integrated in complex systems. Therefore, not only these products and services but also the interfaces between them and the entire system are to be innovated. This provides managerial challenges, also because innovation is not limited to the boarders of single organisations. And these innovative systems have societal implications. Negative externalities have to be mitigated. But even better: companies and other stakeholders can become a force of positive change by seeking positive societal impacts, such as storing rather than emitting greenhouse gasses.

Within complex systems, system elements are interconnected by means of interfaces. In general, such interface specifications should remain stable during a certain period in order to enable innovation at the level of the products, services or system elements they interconnect, so standards are essential. Though change is inherent to innovation, such stability via standards is needed as well, until this interface itself needs to be replaced by a substantially better one. Standardisation includes negotiation and decision-making processes within different cooperative and competitive settings.

The approach in this module will be learning by doing, without a written test, but with assignments instead. The assignments address standardisation and innovation in relation to climate change.

Leerdoelen

This course aims to provide you with basic knowledge, illustrated by a range of practice examples, about standardisation management and, next, its integration in responsible innovation management. This should enable you to develop and employ a strategy for an individual company, a supply chain or a branch of business on how to manage product or service innovation in combination with standards. After this course, you will be able to:

  • explain how standards support complex systems of processes, products and services;
  • illustrate standards’ roles in innovation of such systems and in improving sustainability;
  • distinguish between different ways in which standards can be developed;
  • formulate a strategy for a company to influence standards in a multi-stakeholder setting;
  • make concrete recommendations on using innovation and standardisation management to enable responsible innovation, in the context of grand societal challenges.

course_title: Responsible Innovation - Introduction to Responsible Innovation
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud This is the introductory course for the Responsible Innovation minor. Technology plays an ever-increasing determining factor in our lives as individuals and society at large. New technological innovations contribute to human well-being, but they may also introduce considerable risks to humans, animals, the environment and future generations. As such, we have every reason to insist that the new technologies we develop as a society respect the values we hold dear. Various governments, companies and research funding agencies have now recognized this need for “responsible innovation.” The main aim of this course is to reflect on the nature of technological innovation in relation to societal and ethical concerns, and to gain a solid understanding of the notion of responsible innovation and value-sensitive design. Responsible innovation can, as a concept, be understood in a substantive and in a procedural sense. As a procedural notion, responsible innovation refers to a process of innovation that meets certain norms, like transparency, public engagement, and accountability (to stakeholders and to society). As a substantive notion, responsible innovation refers to a process of innovation that results in innovative technologies that reflect important moral values, including health, safety, human and animal welfare, sustainability, justice, inclusiveness, democracy, privacy, trust, and autonomy. In this introductory course we will learn about responsible innovation by studying these concepts and by focusing on some of the above-listed values, asking just how they can and should be implemented in our innovations. Throughout the course, we will explore questions such as: what do we mean by “good” or “responsible” design and innovation? What is the role of technology in our daily lives, and what is the relationship between moral values and innovation? And how (if at all) can we really anticipate the future socio-ethical implications of newly emerging technologies? Leerdoelen

At the end of the course, students should be able to:

  • Understand what responsible innovation means by explaining the following key theoretical concepts: ethical anticipation, ethical values, the value-laden nature of technological artefacts, procedural responsible innovation, substantive responsible innovation, value sensitive design.
  • Analyze and debate ethical values at stake in concrete cases of innovation.
  • Identify at least one methodology for embedding ethical values into technological artefacts.
  • Discuss challenges with respect to the embedding of ethical values in technological artefacts.
  • Debate the role of technological innovation in relation to the value of human well-being.
  • Develop a cogent ethical argument applying course theory to a case study of technological innovation. The case study will consist of a group component and an individual component. For the group component, students will work collaboratively on a wiki-page. For the individual component, to promote an inclusive learning environment, students will be able to choose a format that best matches their learning style: e.g. a written essay, a presentation, a podcast. The requirements in terms of covering theoretical content will be the same for each of these assignments).

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Innovation management is turning ideas for new products or services to commercial success. This transformation process is typically multi-disciplinary in nature, which means that in practice people from different backgrounds and with various specializations work together.

The innovation process combines creativity and arts, marketing and technology, psychology and organizational design, law in relation to patents and to government regulation, and many more fields of expertise. All these different perspectives must be used to select the few good ideas out of hundreds of ideas and to turn those good ideas into commercially successful, yet responsible, applications. The course uses a variety teaching materials: lectures, moocs, case studies, workshops, articles, explainer video’s and podcasts.

Leerdoelen

After this course students will be able to:

  • Recognize and use the main (responsible) Innovation Management terminology and concepts.
  • Describe and recognize different types of innovation.
  • Be able to explain the adoption life cycle and innovation adoption at the individual level.
  • Define, explain and stimulate individual and group creativity.
  • Be able to describe what an innovation strategy is, why it is important, and which tools and methods can be employed to craft a responsible innovation strategy.
  • Describe what an innovation portfolio is and how to effectively and optimally select innovation projects.
  • Describe how to use and create open innovation in an innovation funnel.
  • Explain the importance of teams, team structures and networks for pursuing innovation.
  • Explain what a culture for innovation consists.

course_title: Responsible Innovation - Responsible Management of Risk, Safety and Security
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Introduction to the field of risk and safety/ security based on various texts (book, scientific papers and book chapters). In the course, safety and security are considered from multiple perspectives (industrial safety, transport safety, organisational safety, societal safety, occupational safety, fire safety, structural safety, physical security, cyber security). Methods and techniques will be taught to model the factors which influence safety and security in these domains (technical-, human-, and organisational factors), by adopting a decomposition approach of the overall socio-technical system.
Methods and techniques of safety-by-design and security-by-design principles for systems and processes are taught to inherently reduce risks of failure during the life cycle of these systems and processes. Examples of fault-tolerant design, fail-safe design, fool/hufter-proof design in the above domains are discussed. Leerdoelen

In this course, students will be introduced to safety and security risk management as it is applied in multiple domains. The focus is on how responsible decisions on safety and security, using the concepts of risk, can be made, in particular in the design phase of systems and processes.
Students learn to understand and use the concept of risk in safety and security settings, being aware of its benefits and limitations. They acquire practical knowledge and skills that allow them to describe the safety and security in qualitative and quantitative terms, to investigate the factors which have an impact on safety and security, and to derive and analyse decisions on safety- and security measures, made by risk managers.

The course starts with safety risk first (accidents), and then extends its scope to security risks (threats and attacks).The following topics will be covered:

  • Introduction of important safety and risk concepts, such as probability, frequency, hazard/ threat, vulnerability, impact/ consequence
  • Short history of safety and risk thinking
  • The management of risk and safety in public and private organisations
  • Similarities and differences between safety and security risks
  • Quantitative and qualitative assessment of safety and security risks
  • Several risk analysis techniques such as fault/ attack trees, hazard–barrier–target HBT-model and bowties
  • The psychology of safety and security, human error
  • A systems view on safety/ security

During the course various reports on risk/ safety topics in media will be discussed.

After this course, students are able to:

  • Understand, apply, and quantify risk and related concepts in safety and security settings, as well as reasoning about these
  • Explain the similarities and differences between safety and security risks and their assessment
  • Understand the tasks and responsibilities of the safety/ risk manager or professional
  • Apply several safety and security risk analysis techniques such as fault and attack trees
  • Make well-founded decisions regarding safety or security issues and countermeasures, explain these choices and communicate them

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

The integrative focal point of this minor are the Student Project Groups (SPGs) which consists of mixed groups of 3-6 students coming from the three universities, tutored by academic coaches. In each SPG, students diagnose, analyze, design, implement and evaluate a real-life innovative case. They will work together with a target stakeholder or problem owner from a company, a non-governmental organization, a public organization or a research institution.

One of the unique and valuable points of this minor is the interdisciplinary group work. It will probably be the first time that students work with peers from different disciplines as well as for professionals outside academia. This learning format helps students to broaden their perspective on the subjects, but it also might be challenging to understand each others’ specialized way of thinking and researching. During (bi)weekly coaching sessions, an academic coach will not only discuss the progress but also support the SPGs with the interdisciplinary group work. The different groups are formed during the first week of the semester, after all students announced their preferred project.

The structure of the SPG is based on the six steps of the Intervention Cycle: Problem Identification, Problem Analysis, Problem Definition, Solution (Re)Design, Solution Implementation and Solution Evaluation. Students will cover the entire cycle during the first block (September–November).

The SPGs are supported by individual sessions called Skill Labs, aimed to provide students with basic knowledge on academic skills. This includes sessions on the Intervention Cycle, research methods and academic writing.

Leerdoelen

At the end of the learning experience students can demonstrate understanding of the intervention cycle by applying the framework to a specific case of responsible innovation by working in an interdisciplinary team. This includes:

  • Applying practical and theoretical knowledge to papers and presentations
  • Reflecting on teamwork and team decision making processes

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

The integrative focal point of this minor are the Student Project Groups (SPGs) which consists of mixed groups of 3-6 students coming from the three universities, tutored by academic coaches. In each SPG, students diagnose, analyze, design, implement and evaluate a real-life innovative case. They will work together with a target stakeholder or problem owner from a company, a non-governmental organization, a public organization or a research institution.

One of the unique and valuable points of this minor is the interdisciplinary group work. It will probably be the first time that students work with peers from different disciplines as well as for professionals outside academia. This learning format helps students to broaden their perspective on the subjects, but it also might be challenging to understand each others’ specialized way of thinking and researching. During (bi)weekly coaching sessions, an academic coach will not only discuss the progress but also support the SPGs with the interdisciplinary group work. The topic of the SPGs in the second block depends on the results of the first block (Student Project Group 1) and is usually an continuation of the topic and research of the first cycle.

The structure of the SPG is based on the six steps of the Intervention Cycle: Problem Identification, Problem Analysis, Problem Definition, Solution (Re)Design, Solution Implementation and Solution Evaluation. Students will repeat the entire cycle during the second block (November – January) after they have covered it once during the Student Project Group 1 in the first block.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Course overview

Retail continues to be an important part of national economies. Retail operations refers to “all activities involved in the selling of physical* goods to ultimate customers for personal or household consumption.” We start this elective course in the third year of the bachelor programme with an overview of the most important retail operations activities in the retail supply chain. Next, we detail the activities in the backend, including distribution and fulfilment (warehousing, transport). We move on to the consumer facing part of retail operations, including assortment planning, inventory control, and returns handling. We discuss how first online, and more recently omnichannel, business models have affected consumer behaviour and operational processes along the retail supply chain. We will zoom in on the changing role of stores in retail and the need for sustainability in retail. We end with an overview of the most promising new technologies (e.g., AI, Internet-of-Things) introduced in retailing, how they allow us to better measure consumer behaviour and track operational performance. Finally, we discuss how retail analytics can be used to derive actionable insights from existing and new data sources. Retail operations challenges are increasingly on the interface of operations, marketing, and information systems. We therefore take a multi-disciplinary perspective in this course.

* We do not consider services in this course, but we will touch upon the notion of servitization (offering services around a product).

Leerdoelen

Learning Goals

After following this course, the student is able to*:

Content
1. Demonstrate knowledge of the role of operations and supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of retail firms. (ILO1)
2. Understand the dynamic, interdisciplinary challenges facing parties in retail supply chains. (ILO2)
3. Understand how new technologies and business models are affecting retail operations at large and specific decision areas (e.g., assortment, inventory) in particular. (ILO2)

Skills
4. Demonstrate effective skills in communicating (written and verbally) about retail operations challenges based on sound conceptual thinking. (ILO 5, ILO 6)

Attitude
5. Displaying an analytical mindset when it comes to dealing with operational challenges in retail supply chains; being able to factor in interdependencies between different actors in the supply chains and firm functions. (ILO 4, ILO 9)

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. I Gusc', 'JA Seijbel, MSC MA', 'R van Lent, MSc']
text:
Leerdoelen What is the use of history? Who determines the scientific character of historical knowledge? How can we be sure about historical evidence? Are the activities of truth committees in a society different from the work of professional historians? Providing answers to these questions is not simple, but it is very important to discuss and learn more about the intellectual and social relevance of history.
In this course, 'Rethinking History I', we reflect on the fundamentals of the scientific pursuit of history and the relevance of historical knowledge for society. You will be introduced to the basics of the historical discipline that are necessary to follow the courses in the History Bachelor. Based on primary source fragments and secondary scientific literature we will discuss the meanings of the term history related to historical consciousness, the infrastructure of the historical discipline, historical truth, fact and fiction, scientific integrity, history and identity, and the moral values of history.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. RJ Adriaansen', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'R van Lent, MSc', 'RN Murning']
text:
Inhoud This course further elaborates the theoretical issues related to historical scholarship discussed in Rethinking History 1. It does so by studying key issues and currents in the philosophy of the  humanities in general and in the philosophy of history (the philosophical reflection on the nature and study of history) in particular.
In our treatment of the philosophy of history, we will study both the 'speculative' philosophy of history and the 'critical' philosophy of history. While speculative philosophers such as Hegel and Spengler pondered over the grand schemes of history, 'critical' schools of thought, such as positivism, hermeneutics and post-modernism raised various questions about the extent to which we can know, study or represent the past. What is the meaning of history and what is the nature of historical truth? How can we justify historical explanations? To what extent can we understand the intentions of historical actors? Is historical objectivity desirable or even possible? How do historical narratives represent the past and what are the limits of historical representation?
This course will strongly challenge the purported truths of historical scholarship. Leerdoelen

·         Students can identify and explain the main concepts, theories and issues of the philosophy of history.

·         Students are able to recognize and critically assess historiographical and philosophical issues in examples of historical scholarship.

·         Students can take a well-argued stand in ethical and epistemological discussions on the study of history.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. M. van der Werf', 'dr. W.G.M. Janssen', 'L. Boer']

course_title: Review of Math. and Intro to Statistics
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['A.M. Baars', 'dr. J.M. van Rosmalen', 'dr. S.P. Willemsen']
text:
Inhoud

For more information about the course, please click on the item below: 
Course highlights

Belangrijk om te weten Please note that in case of cancellation or no show, the cancellation policy applies based on the full course fee. You will find the cancellation policy here.

Inhoud

This course reflects on world history from the perspective of various revolutionary moments that have shaped, or are perceived in hindsight to have shaped, the historical trajectories of human civilisations and societies, and have influenced how we live our daily lives today. Reading materials will delve into the concept of ‘revolution’ and look into key moments throughout world history and across geographical regions through the lenses of various technological, scientific, political and/or social revolutions. Topics include, but are not limited to, the shift from oral- to literate cultures, the rise of agricultural societies, the emergence of cities and trade, the professionalisation of armies, technologies of planetary exploration and Empire building. Reading materials are selected from multiple disciplines, including global history, anthropology and philosophy.


 
  Leerdoelen
  •           A critical understanding of the various theories of the historical Jesus and Muhammad and their methodological foundations
  •           A capacity to analyse the strengths and weaknesses of such theories, based on both the evidence and the methodological issues.
  •           Identify, interpret, and evaluate a range of images and source materials
  •           Developed knowledge of the classical themes in Christian-Muslim polemics and their influence on current interreligious debates
  •           Developed knowledge of select examples of the cultural reception and reworking of the traditions of Jesus and Muhammad
  •           Profound insight in the relation between religion and media and the way the transcendent has been portrayed in the visual arts
  •           Insight into the debate on aniconism in both religious traditions
  •           A critical understanding of the use of religious imagery in film and other modern media

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course discusses the recent global transformations in urban life. The rise of global cities since the 1970s was accompanied by a major increase in the urban population. More than half of the world population is living in cities after 2000, but the majority of these people does no longer live in rich centres, but in the poor slums of the urban periphery. The classical Weberian picture of the city as a place of freedom and development has been turned upside-down by these developments. Cities across the world are still centres of economic growth, but they face problems such as growing inequality, poverty, violence, pollution and rising sea levels. Students learn how a combination of socio-scientific and historical methods can help to analyse these challenges.
This course uses Saskia Sassen’s concept of the global city as a starting point for a critical discussion of the current trends in urbanisation. Students discuss major texts in the field of global urbanisation during the weekly meetings and they will discuss the impact of historical changes on city life in different parts of the world. The other half of the meetings will be used to explain students how they can use developments in the digital humanities to study urban life in globalised cities. Several methodologies will be discussed including the use of online quantitative databases, data mining, social network analysis and GIS.
  Leerdoelen
  • Students can describe the rise and transformation of global cities in modern times
  • Students can critically assess theoretical concepts from urban history and urban studies
  • Students can analyse the challenges of globalised cities from a historical perspective in different parts of the world

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Financial risk management is of the utmost importance for institutional investors, both from the regulatory and fiduciary perspective. In this course, the Vestia case is discussed in-depth as it is a prime example that highlights the importance of an effective risk management strategy. Vestia is a The Hague and Rotterdam-based social housing corporation, and it turned out to be one of the largest public sector scandals in the history of the Netherlands. In 2011, Vestia suffered very large losses on its interest rate derivatives portfolio and experienced serious liquidity problems in the aftermath.

In this course, the theoretical concepts are discussed in order for the students the fully understand the flaws in the risk management strategy of Vestia. The main sources of financial risk are discussed, such as: market risk, liquidity risk, credit risk and operational risk. Approaches to quantify each of these risks (e.g. duration, VaR, ES, etc.) as well as the various approaches to manage these risks are explored. The course explores the market for fixed income securities which were at the center of the Vestia case, and these are instruments with direct exposure towards market risk (interest rate risk) and credit risk.

Entry requirements or required background knowledge 
The study of risk management and fixed income securities is quantitative in nature. Students should be comfortable mathematics and statistics.

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • Recommend an effective risk management strategy for financial institutions (such as Vestia) with an exposure towards several sources of financial risk.
  • Analyze the exposure of an investment portfolio towards financial risks and be able to quantify this risk exposure using various techniques, such as: Value-at-Risk (VaR), Expected Shortfall(ES), and Duration.
  • Understand the markets for interest rate swaps and credit default swaps and be able to explain how to utilize these instruments to manage interest rate risk and credit risk.
  • Evaluate the exposure of a cash flow towards interest rates using the concepts of duration and convexity, and understand its shortcomings.
  • Understand the main sources of financial risks, such as market risk, liquidity risk, credit risk, and operational risk, and be able to analyze the importance of these risks for fixed income securities.

course_title: Roaming the Digital World: Data Analytics
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud It is often rightly noted that people have more and easier access to information than ever before, and that there is more media created today (often by media users and audiences) than at any point in history. This vast and diverse media content offers an incredible opportunity, but also a challenge, to media analysts. Some of the most difficult questions facing media research concern not only how to properly identify critically important media texts, but also how to collect and make sense of patterns that can be observed within and across media. In this course, students will be provided scientific and industry-leading methodological tools in order to carry out these tasks, particularly in digital environments.

However, the course is not exhaustive; comprehensive coverage would require multiple courses. Instead, students will acquire a feel for tools of digital research. Thus, proficiency in any particular digital analysis approach is not a prerequisite. However, curiosity and willingness to experiment with digital technologies – that, due to their novelty, can be capricious – is necessary to succeed in and enjoy the course. It should also be noted that the approaches for digital analysis often blend qualitative and quantitative techniques.

Via lectures and interactive hands-on workshops, students will become acquainted with theoretical concepts and scholarly debates surrounding digital research combined with a hands-on approach for dealing with data. As most professional research happens in teams, this course also includes a small group research project in addition to individual work. After completion of this course, students will be able to gather and analyze digital data for future projects using appropriate methodologies and tools.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of: 
  • Digital analysis and their applicability in the field of media and communication.
  • Research designs and measuring instruments for the analysis of digital media.
  • Practical considerations necessary for digital analysis, for example the concepts and issues surrounding the collection of online data and their management.
  
Students have developed the ability to: 
  • Propose appropriate methods to meet particular research needs.
  • Collect and analyze data from social media (Twitter, YouTube) and news (LexisNexis) on topics of their choice.
  • Present digital research in clear, novel and engaging ways, orally and in writing.
  • Perform basic text analysis, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and network analysis.

Inhoud This course is part of cluster 4. The Politics of Wealth: Inequality, Capitalism, Exploitation

In Europe, from the late Middle Ages onward the concept of ‘race’ was used in order to distinguish different kinds of people. As a rule the distinctions drawn between human races were accompanied by clear cut moral hierarchies. Most early modern Europeans appear to have considered racial differences the result of a variety of external circumstances, but during the Enlightenment as a result of taxonomical attempts to classify man within the wider context of nature a modern, allegedly scientific racism arose, according to which these distinctions had a biological basis. In this course we will concentrate on the way in which European authors active prior to Darwin, who denied the reality of different human ‘species’, and to such 19th- and 20th-century racists as Gobineau, Chamberlain, and Rosenberg tried to meet the challenge implied by the discovery of peoples and cultures that looked fundamentally different from the ones early modern Europeans had been accustomed to, born as they were into a world which only recently had started to globalize. Some of the texts involved take the superiority of the inhabitants of Europe for granted. Other early modern authors, however, reveal an evident fascination sometimes coupled with genuine admiration for indigenous ‘natives’.

Attendance at lectures and seminars is mandatory. If students miss more sessions than allowed, they will not be allowed to hand in their papers. Leerdoelen To gain a proper understanding of some of the main lines of thought dominating the early modern discourse on human diversity and to be able to analyze a major text belonging to this discourse.

course_title: Round table discussion and lab rotation
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)

text:
Inhoud

De cursus Russisch voor beginners bestaat dan ook 10 lessen van 2,5 uur. 

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Russisch A1.1?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de beginselen van de Russische taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, spreken en schrijven in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

  • kennis maken en jezelf voorstellen;
  • familie;
  • stad;
  • de weg vragen en wijzen;
  • vliegveld, hotel, restaurant;
  • een afspraak maken of een mening geven.
Leerdoelen Aan het einde van de cursus ben je in staat het Cyrillische alfabet te lezen en te schrijven en een eenvoudig gesprek te voeren en te begrijpen. Na afloop van deze cursus ben je op weg  naar het A1 niveau van het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). Belangrijk om te weten
  • Deze cursus in online via Zoom en Canvas.
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Russisch gesproken.
  • Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 5,5 of hoger.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.
Data en tijden Woensdagen 17.30-20.00 uur
Data: 25 januari - 29 maart 2023
Location: Online via Zoom en Canvas
Examen: in week 14

Inschrijfdeadline is 12 januari 2023

course_title: SAM-03 Stralingsbescherming MB'er in de screening

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
SCM students have the opportunity to combine the writing of their thesis with an internship with a company (minimum of 168 hours) and replacing an elective course. The internship should be solely related to the thesis research and the selection of the internship should be in consultation with the thesis coach or thesis coordinator. The Company Based Research Project will be assessed separately from the thesis (on a pass/fail basis) by the thesis coach and a company supervisor.

THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR SCM STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two other SCM programme electives! Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Students should use their time with the internship company to acquire skills with regard to doing SCM related research within a company setting.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['prof.dr. AW Veenstra', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster', 'prof.dr.ir. NAH Agatz']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The total workload of the course will be 224 hours (8 ECTS), divided between
  • class attendance (9 sessions, 5 sessions of 3 hrs and 4 seminars of 2 hours = 23 hours);
  • preparation of the seminar (5 hrs)
  • assignment (196 hrs). 
The projects will be executed in teams of three to four students, depending on the size of the project and the amount of the projects. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The students will already be familiar with various Supply Chain Management disciplines through course work; however, the use of this knowledge and the capacity to translate it into practical solutions for a real life and actual problem is a new challenge. The Business Consultancy Project (BCP) permits students to combine theory and practice. The learning objectives of the BCP can be summarised as follows:
  1. Define the research problem of the company, which exactly includes the question that the company would like to see addressed;
  2. Discuss the current state of research in the relevant Supply Chain Management topic for your project, both method-wise and content-wise, in a literature review, that is included in your final report;
  3. Present the current state of research in the relevant Supply Chain Management topic for your project, both method-wise and content-wise, in a seminar for your peers, which results in new insights for your analysis;
  4. Complete a consultancy project in which you:
    •  Analyze a supply chain problem;
    • Develop solutions and recommendations;
    • Manage a professional client relationship;
    • Deliver the final report before the deadline that satisfies the client.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The first phase of the thesis trajectory entails finding a research topic and a supervisory team. The program offers a wide array of themes and coach profiles for you to work with. Each research theme offers a broad research area, flexible enough to allow students to specify and investigate their own research questions. Moreover, the themes typically also provide a set of specific topics and potential research avenues. Different themes require different research approaches. The research themes are as following:
  • H2O - Healthcare and Humanitarian Operations
  • Material handling and Facility Logistics
  • Purchasing and Supply Management
  • Transport and Distribution Networks
  • Supply Chain Forecasting and Analytics
  • Global Sustainable Supply Chains and Smart Ports
  • Behavioral Operations

Generally, in our program, there are two types of master thesis projects:
  • Theory-oriented projects: aim to contribute to theory development and/or theory testing. Usually, empirical data is used to build/test theory or to validate the research framework.
  • Practice-oriented projects: aim to contribute to the knowledge or to help solve a problem of a practitioner. Usually this is combined with an internship at the practitioner via a so-called ‘Company based project’ or CBP. 

During the SCM Thesis trajectory the students will be individually coached by their coach and co-reader. The trajectory is organized along the following phases/deliverables:
  1. Thesis information session
  2. Preliminary Thesis Proposal and coach assignment
  3. Dragons’ Den
  4. Co-reader assignment
  5. Thesis Proposal
  6. Final Thesis
  7. Oral Thesis defense
Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Upon completion of this course students are prepared and have proven to execute an individual scientific research project.

course_title: SCORE course: Stem Cells, Organoids and Regenerative Medicine
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. ing. M.M.A. Verstegen', 'prof. dr. L.J.W. van der Laan', 'prof.dr. JH Gribnau']
text:
Inhoud Description
Goal of this course is to provide a comprehensive overview of stem cells, organoids and regenerative medicine through lectures of experts in this field.
You will learn about concepts, techniques and (future) medical applications (Knowledge and skills). Moreover there will be plenty opportunity  to get to know each other and to present/discuss your own research projects (Communication skills and Networking).

Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. EKE von Bone', 'dr. JJAM Schenk', 'dr. RA Roks', 'F Noori', 'FAM Baas', 'prof.dr. AJ Dur', 'prof.dr. G Oonk', 'prof.dr. PT van de Laar', 'prof.dr. SJC Hemels']
text:
Inhoud In this minor social, cultural, historical, legal, economic and criminal aspects of diversity will be elaborated in seminars and workshops on locations in Rotterdam such as Museum Boijmans-Van Beuningen. Within the context of Rotterdam’s city of superdiversity issues of diversity will be discussed in a creative setting of Codarts.  The best and Smart way to understand the impact and the positive and negative effects of diversity and inclusion is to relate them to arts and culture. Arts and creativity stimulate the empowerment of students and stimulate talents that help them in their professional careers after graduation. In sum, Cognition and Creativity. Until now, the EUR offers few opportunities to develop these tracks which incorporates them in an academic course. This minor uses the core values and ambitions of the EUR as starting point. The minor uses the case-studies’ methodology, using a creative matrix based on performative arts (theater, musical, opera or related etc.) which is unraveled by the lectures and students in interactive workshops. The outcomes of these series of lectures and workshops will be used by the students to re-write their own performances.  The assignments are thus a combination of academic skills and creativity. Different aspects of diversity and inclusion will be approached in an innovative and Erasmian way. The cultural aspects of this theme will be discussed. Workshops will be given in collaboration with Codarts, Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen, and World Museum Rotterdam. Students will be challenged to address contemporary diversity-related issues in an interdisciplinary knowledge and creative chain. Students will use theories and methodologies taken from the interdisciplinary lectures, including social-media analyses on diversity and inclusion (me-too, BLM, cancel culture). In creative and artistic workshops students are trained to apply these academic skills into practical case studies. The minor offers, therefore, academic, artistic and embodied knowledge experiences with the opportunity to have practice in the cultural sector of the city of Rotterdam.  
  Leerdoelen The following learning goals will be achieved:
  • to reflect on diversity by applying (historical) case studies on diversity and inclusion.
  • to elaborate cases on discrimination, the consequences of discrimination and what is needed to reduce the effects of discrimination. 
  • to learn how legal and financial systems are related to diversity.
  • to enhance awareness on how to deal with dissabilities in a diverse society.
  • to learn how to assess diversity in case studies by non-verban communication and creative tools. 
  • to learn how contribute to an inclusive society and a safe public space.

course_title: SNP Course: SNPs and Human Diseases
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. C.G. Boer, MSc', 'dr. J.M.H. Verkerk', 'dr. L. Broer', 'dr. M.C. Medina Gomez', 'dr. R. Kraaij', 'prof. dr. A.G. Uitterlinden', 'prof. dr. F. Rivadeneira', 'prof. dr. J.B.J. van Meurs']
text:
Inhoud Course description 
The analysis of DNA variations, including Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs), is a standard research approach to understand causes of disease, in particular the so-called “complex” diseases such as diabetes, osteoporosis, cancer, Alzheimer disease, etc. The field is changing fast with large scale reference projects (dbSNP, HapMap, 1000genomes, ENCODE), very large biobanks (UK Biobank, MVP), global collaboration in consortia, and novel technology being continuously introduced and refined, including SNP array genotyping and DNA  Sequencing. Several aspects are now being explored for implementation in clinical settings, such as for DNA diagnostics and risk profiling with polygenic risk scores.

Recommendation
Recommendation: This is an advanced course on genetics on the latest advances in complex traits and monogenic conditions. Participants of the SNP course should have basic knowledge of molecular biology (such as DNA and gene structure, DNA translation to protein, etc.) and basic principles of techniques used for gene discovery. Participants lacking this knowledge should attend the course ’Basic Human Genetics’. Basic background knowledge can also be found in any decent textbook of human molecular biology and genetics, such as "Human Molecular Genetics" (5th ed.; editors Strachan & Read; published by Taylor & Francis Inc.; €75,27).

Learning goals  
The aim of this course is to give a broad introduction in SNP techniques and applications.

course_title: SPD: Working towards the Research Paper
lecturers: ['dr. GM Gomez', 'dr. GTJ McCarthy', 'dr. KA Siegmann']

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
text:
Inhoud

Course description 
This introduction course on the statistical computer program SPSS will deal in a step-by-step way with several elements of SPSS. 

Learning goals  
•    Understand the difference between descriptive and inferential statistics; 

•    Understand the basics of hypothesis testing and p-values; 

•    Be familiar with the most important statistical tests for comparing groups and regression analysis, such as chi-square, t-test, linear and logistic regression; 

•    Understand the underlying assumptions and limitations of these techniques; 

•    Be able to perform basic statistical analysis in SPSS and interpret the results.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The organisation of this large event is in the hands of a small committee, consisting of seven senior members of STAR. The positions within the committee are presented below:
  • Chairman: end-responsibility for the total event; guiding and leading the committee; being in contact with the RSM
  • Treasurer: managing the budget and bookkeeping of the entire event
  • Commissioner of Marketing & Public Relations: creating and realising the marketing for the entire event
  • Commissioner of Speakers (2x): responsible for recruiting all speakers and managing relations with these speakers
  • Commissioner of Commercial Relations (2x): responsible for the acquisition of the event and maintaining relations with corporate partners
  • Events: responsible for the planning and organization of the event itself
 
Next to these positions, the modules Vice-Chairman and IT are available next to the common positions within the committee.
 
From all committee members it is expected that they:
  • are able an willing to bear total responsibility for the project
  • will be able to maintain professional relations with all stakeholders (corporates, speakers, suppliers, STAR, RSM, students)
  • will be able to successfully plan and schedule the project
 
Learning Goals
Essentially, functioning as a member of the committee involves ‘learning by doing’. At the same time, becoming a member is only possible when you fulfil the requirements set by STAR. Within the project, your starting qualifications will be brought to a higher level. The learning goals for the activity are such that committee members should already posses certain knowledge and skills which will be enhanced by the end of the project. The following starting qualifications and learning goals have been formulated. In brackets, courses that are part of the BSc BA or the BSc IBA have been indicated that clearly contribute to the required knowledge, skills or attitude.
 
Being considered for this committee, you should:
  • be able to work in a team (Introduction to Business/Inleiding Bedrijfskunde, Organisational Behaviour/Gedrag in Organisaties, Methodology, Effective Business Communication/Bedrijfskundige Vaardigheden, Strategic Business Plan/Strategisch Ondernemingsplan; Organisational Theory & Dymanics)
  • have basic knowledge of how to communicate with different (international) stakeholders (Effective Business Communication; Strategic Management; Cross Cultural Management)
  • have basic knowledge of bookkeeping and budgeting (Foundations of Finance & Accounting/Financiële Processen; Management Accounting, Corporate Finance. Having completed Financial Accounting is an asset)
  • be able to rationally argue (financial) decisions to the supervisor/board (Organisational Theory & Dynamics)
  • have a basic understanding of how to communicate and work together with businesses (Effective Business Communication/BKV)
  • have a basic understanding of how to come up with a marketing plan in order to sufficiently promote the project (Marketing Management; (International) Marketing Research)
 
After finishing the project, you should be able to:
  • work strongly and professionally in a team
  • make far-reaching decisions based on valid argumentation
  • effectively deal with stress
  • professionally conduct the bookkeeping and budgeting of encompassing projects
  • professionally communicate and work together with businesses
  • professionally develop, apply and evaluate the marketing of large projects
  • show strong endurance and perseverance
  • act responsibly when dealing with large projects
Leerdoelen The STAR Management Week is the largest off-campus business and recruitment event of the Benelux and one of the highlights of the year at the Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University (RSM). During this event the students will get the opportunity to enrich their student life by participating in various activities. They will be inspired by keynote speakers during the Academic Seminars, or by participating in discussions with well-known guests during the Honorary Discussions. The SMW also gives students the opportunity to get in contact with many companies during multiple recruitment activities. Whether students have just started their studies or are already close to graduation, during the STAR Management Week they will be offered a broad range of professional and exciting activities to participate in. The organisation of SMW is a challenging task for which only senior members of STAR are recruited who meet a range requirements, both in the field of content and in the field of skills and attitude.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
text:
Inhoud

Course description 

Is a laboratory an extreme hazardous workplace?  
Or is a laboratory a very safe workplace? 

To answer this question, you need to have a proper understanding of hazards you can be confronted with when working in a laboratory and how to manage and avoid them.  

Working in a laboratory you are certain to be confronted with different kind of hazards and potential risks for your health and safety. This can vary from small dangers to major health risks, which you are sometimes not aware of. Mostly these risks can be reduced to acceptable levels when the right control measures are taken.   

The objective of the training is to provide the participants specific knowledge and skills about hazards and risks when working in laboratories. The participant will be trained in recognizing, interpreting, managing hazards and risks and which control measures to take. The training is based on the TOB model and will provide insights on with specific hazards you can encounter and how to avoid or manage risk form three perspectives. During the training participants are asked to view and contribute their specific work situations. So, the risks relevant to the participants are dealt with in a focused manner.  
In this way theory and practice are merged. 

Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course. 

You will receive all details about the location the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.


Course program 

The training is divided into two days: 

Part 1 – 45 Participants, 13.00h-16.30 (day 1):  

In the first part, knowledge will be presented on which hazards and risks you may encounter when working in the laboratories and how these can be controlled in different ways. Topics are:  

  • Basic understanding of hazards and risks 

  • Working safe with dangerous chemicals  

  • Working safe with dangerous biological agents  

  • How to avoid physical strain  

  • What to do in case of an emergency  

  • How to deal with specific hazards of machine/laser safety 

  • Effective use of personal protective equipment 

 
Part 2 – 15 participants each group (day 2, divided in 3 groups, 15 participants each. 1 group/day) 
 
The set-up in part two is a workshop in which participants each introduce one or more un safe situations.  

The following questions are the core: 

  • What are the concrete risks that I have to deal with? 

  • How do we actually do things in our department? 

  • What is my basic attitude when thinking and acting with these risks? 

  • What role do I play in limiting the risks for myself, colleagues and the organization? 

 

These situations are classically discussed, analyzed and also specific control measures are suggested. During this workshop insight will be provided on how safety behavior works  

Participants get an answer on how they can deal with risks in their laboratory more professionally? 

Learning goals  

  • Provide the participants specific knowledge and skills about hazards and risks when working in laboratories.  

  • The participant will be trained in Recognizing, interpreting, and managing hazards and risks and which control measures to take.

Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. Inhoud

In this course, you will be exploring the exciting world of sales. As you know, ‘sales’ is no longer stigmatized by greasy door-to-door salesmen utilizing slimy tactics and techniques to con their customers out of cash (remember the “always be closing” speech from Alec Baldwin? Google it). Sales is a global and thriving enterprise at the heart of everything we do. Think about it: the sales department is often the only profit-generating function in an organization! ‘Sales’ is also relevant to our personal and professional lives, as we all use persuasion to promote ourselves and our ideas. Whether you are interviewing for a job, sharing your ideas with friends/colleagues, or preparing assignments for this course—you are selling! This course therefore covers a broad range of topics and competences related to your career in business and marketing whether you will be working in a sales role or not.

Leerdoelen

Sales and Account Management is one of three key areas of expertise that you develop during the Marketing Master's Program.

Therefore, this course addresses a broad range of learning objectives related to personal selling (e.g., apply the process elements of contemporary selling to a specific case), sales management (e.g., identify salesperson job candidates relative to key success factors for salesperson performance), and global sales issues (e.g., prepare novel recommendations for tackling the most pertinent global challenges related to sales management).

In completing this course, you will gain a solid foundation of these key aspects of contemporary selling, and how they relate to building relationships and creating value.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar All sessions held in person (versus hybrid).
Weekly 3-hour sessions rather than 2 1.5 hour sessions per week.
More inter-mixing of lectures with in-class activities/role-playing.
The addition of a second guest lecturer.
  Extra The exam is worth 120 points, distributed among these learning objectives as follows:  
  • Identify key themes of contemporary selling (20 pts.), 
  • Apply process elements of contemporary selling to a specific case (20 pts.), 
  • Describe decision stages involved in organizational buying (20 pts.), 
  • Identify salesperson job candidates relative to the key success factors for salesperson performance (20 pts.), 
  • Differentiate components related to the internal and external environment in contemporary selling (20 pts.), and 
  • Prepare novel recommendations for tackling the most pertinent global challenges related to sales management (20 pts.).

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
There is a very big contrast between the proportion of business school alumni that work in sales -which is high- and the proportion of business schools offering a sales related course in the curriculum –which is extremely low-. This is problematic because today’s world of sales more than ever requires professionals with an academic understanding of the field. Key trends like the knowledge intensity of sales work, and the shift towards a service economy have made the complexity of the sales environment higher than ever. Also, without a sale, it is impossible to run a business. Thus sales is an essential element of management.

In this course we will focus first on salespeople, and start with the question: “what makes a salesperson effective?” Next, we’ll move the analyses towards the sales team level and will zoom in on leadership. The central goal is to understand how sales leaders can best manage salespeople. We will analyze what is unique to the management and leadership of salespeople, and discuss how to cope with this. Research-driven insights will form the foundation of the course, complemented with cases from modern-day business practice. We will combine lectures, practical case studies, exercises and discussions. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  1. Understand the drivers of performance for salespeople and sales teams;
  2. Understand how sales leaders can effectively manage salespeople;
  3. Apply the theoretical knowledge to a business case;
  4. Be able to critically evaluate performance cases of salespeople and -teams.
