  • Special subjects, such as consolidation, mergers and acquisitions, foreign currency, accounting changes, financial instruments, leasing, segment reporting, environmental/sustainability reporting, cash flow statements, management discussion and analysis;
  • Analysis of the annual financial statements of a public company.
  • Students have to present papers, solve cases, prepare presentations and take part in the discussions.
Leerdoelen
  • Obtain knowledge about financial accounting and reporting.
  • Obtain insight in the recent law and standards concerning external financial.
  • Obtain the differences between Dutch GAAP and IFRS.
  • Understand the purposes of the annual financial statement.
  • Obtain knowledge in which way assets and liabilities and income and expenses in the annual financial statement need to be presented.
  • Be able to write papers of different subjects concerning the annual financial statement.
  • Based on recent literature students should be able to perform an presention during the course.
  • Be able to discuss within the group the relevance and interesting subject in a paper written by collegue students.
  • Be able to erform minutes of the college for the other student.
  • Be able to function as chairman, as discussiant and as secretary during the course.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar We have changed the case to include a more recent case. 

We also removed some dated literature. 

And we have added literature on subjects such as ESG based on recent developments. Extra There is no final (re)examination.

lecturers: ['dr. A Quaini', 'dr. AM Camehl', 'dr. HJWG Kole', 'dr. M Grith', 'dr. O Kleen', 'dr. W Wang', 'JMJ van Druten', 'PA Opschoor', 'prof.dr. C Zhou', 'prof.dr. DJC van Dijk', 'T van der Zwan, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

Students work in teams of 4 on specific (theoretical or empirical) financial econometric research projects, which are supplied by firms in the financial industry (including asset managers, hedge funds, insurance companies, and pension funds). Examples include problems in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing.
Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. Each group writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the course term, in which the research project is presented by a member of the group and discussed by a member of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.

Leerdoelen
  • Learn how to formulate a proper research question with testable hypotheses.
  • Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques and necessary data to answer the research question.
  • Learn how to use the outcomes of an econometric analysis to answer the research questions.
  • Learn to report about the research project in the form of a (scientific) report and a presentation.
  • Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
Extra This course is only accessible for students enrolled in the Master programme in Econometrics and Management Science.

Inhoud

Following the most recent trends in empirical research, this seminar will take a firm-level approach to the study of international trade. To have a firm grasp in understanding the empirics, we will start off with the “new” trade theory of international trade, its extension with heterogeneous firms, and the related gravity model of trade. We will then focus on the empirical research on heterogeneous firms and trade by studying and discussing frontier academic papers. The topics covered will include: self-selection into exporting, learning by exporting, intermediaries in trade, and most importantly, the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms.

Leerdoelen

The purpose of this seminar is to provide students with an understanding of the role of firms in international trade. By completing this course, students will be able to answer questions such as: Why only a few firms export? How are they different than other firms? What is the role of intermediaries in facilitating trade? What is the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms? Upon the completion of this course, the students will be able to critically evaluate empirical research, especially in identifying causal effects using micro-data to answer policy-relevant questions.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar


Some materials are updated to reflect recent developments in research

lecturers: ['dr. H Zhu', 'dr. NRD Dwarkasing', 'prof.dr. PAE Koudijs']
text:
Inhoud

In this seminar, we will explore Finance’s fascinating history to generate valuable insights for today’s world. The seminar is organized around four themes (1) securities markets, with special emphasis on how information is processed by financial markets, (2) limited liability, with special emphasis on entrepreneurship and banking, (3) banking and financial crises, with special emphasis on banking regulation and the real effects of crises, and (4) politics and finance, with special emphasis on the interaction between finance and people’s political attitudes. This seminar is relevant for all students who are interested in why today’s financial system looks the way it does, what lessons we can draw from past failures and successes, and the implications this has for how we should organize financial markets and institutions today. Tasks include the presentation and discussion of scientific papers. For the final (group) assignment, students will write a policy brief based on historical research. Alternatively, students will get the opportunity to develop a thesis proposal.

Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge of and insight into: the important role financial markets play in processing information, and how that information shapes real economic decisions.
Students have knowledge of and insight into: limited liability, and the role this plays in risk-taking decisions
Students have knowledge of and insight into: the central role of banks and other financial institutions, the way they operate, and the inherent risks they pose.
Students have knowledge of and insight into: how politics and finance can interact to have positive or negative impact on society
Students are able to: read, interpret and evaluate academic work.
Students are able to: translate academic findings into policy relevant insights
Students are able to: write a concise and effective policy brief
Students are able to: identify potential thesis topics from the topics discussed in class.

Extra Assessment:

Participation and discussion points               30%
Presentation / Chairing                                  30%
Group assignment                                         40%

Inhoud

Most traditional market boundaries have disappeared. Successful firms in sectors as diverse as consumer packaged goods, consumer durables, industrial goods, and services have discovered that traditional rules of competition – such as focusing only on the competitive interplay in each country separately – have changed dramatically in today’s globalized markets.
New strategies are determining who are the winners and the losers. Firms which respond proactively to the challenges of a globalized world outperform firms who are unable to adequately respond to a changed world. Firms cannot ignore this trend to globalization. Even if they decide not to be involved in the global or pan-regional (ASEAN, EU, Mercosur, USMCA, etc.) marketplace, companies still face increased competition in their home markets because of nimble foreign competitors reaping the benefits of global strategies.

Leerdoelen

Knowledge of factors and criteria to determine foreign market attractiveness
Understanding the different ways in which brands can be rolled out globally
Understanding the impact of digitalization on global brands
Understanding the impact of sustainability on global brands
Implementing global marketing strategies that are a smart combination of global standardization, local adaptation, and worldwide learning

Belangrijk om te weten Students are required to purchase the digital reader (course-pack) and StratSim simulation for this course.
  Extra Several business cases from The Case Centre. The Cases will cost somewhere around $10-$15.
- CountryManager simulation ($49.95)

Inhoud

Firm globalization arises along four dimensions according to Gupta et al. (2008). As a first dimension, global market presence refers to the extent to which the firm is present across international markets and serves a worldwide customer base. Interestingly, there are not many firms with a truly global presence although some oil, car and retail companies do sell products in many different locations across the globe. As a second dimension, supply base globalization, involves the degree to which firms have sliced up their value chains globally to optimally exploit the advantages of different locations. For instance, production may take place in locations with cheap labor and access to excellent transport infrastructure while a firm’s R&D activities are located in high-tech clusters with a large pool of skilled labor. The globalization of the capital base can be perceived as a third dimension and reflects how the company has globalized its financial structure, including its listing and tax payment locations as well as places where it attracts operating capital and distributes profits. Finally, the globalization of the corporate mind-set reflects the extent to which firms are culturally inclusive and able to integrate new ideas and management practices from around the globe.

Accordingly, in devising their optimal globalization strategy firms are very selective when choosing locations to invest or source goods and services. As a result, not all locations are suitable for all types of firm investments, simply because they lack the appropriate specialized advantages. Economic activities therefore tend to be very concentrated in space.

The aim of this seminar is to understand how firms internationalize, how they grow and where they locate. Most notably, attention will be paid to the empirics of multinational strategy and foreign direct investment. During the first half of the course, students are expected to present, discuss and evaluate recent articles related to the topic of the course. In the second half of the course, students have to conduct an empirical study in which they combine econometric techniques with theories on the importance of firm globalization strategies and location.

Leerdoelen
  • Discuss and critically evaluate theories and empirical research on the global firm strategy with a particular focus on investment and location.
  • Think and act in an academic way on the interface of economics, business and geography.
  • Conduct an empirical study on global firm strategy using econometric techniques.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar A selection of articles and assignments is replaced or updated.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['CF Parra Mujica', 'dr. B Wouterse', 'prof.dr. MP Garcia Gomez', 'prof.dr. TGM Van Ourti']
text:
Inhoud Note: this course will be offered for the first time in 2022-2023. 

The seminar Health Economics has several goals:
  1. Expose students to real-world cases in the field of health economics, provided by external guest lecturers (government, industry).
  2. Train students in using quasi-experimental methods to answer policy questions, including what to do when quasi-experimental methods are not feasible
  3. Practice writing and research methods for thesis
Alumni talks will clarify the usefulness of quasi-experimental methods for professional life

The main features of the schedule are listed below:
  • Introduction + recapitulation of quasi-experimental methods (week 1)
    • 1 online session
  • Three research Assignments on health economics topics provided by instructors (week 2-4)
    • 3 presentations; 3 Q&A session; submit 3 research assignments
    • Group work
  • Solve a real-world industry or government case (week 5-8)
    • 3 presentations (Research proposal, practice, final); 3 Q&A sessions
    • Group work
Admission requirement
All students that have participated in the exam/assignments of 'Applied Microeconometrics' can enroll for the course, including students that failed the exam/assignments.
 
Exam
The exam is composed of three group assignments (each 10%), three presentations related to the assignment (each 5%), one case report (35%) and two presentations related to the case (each 10%). Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.
 
Re-sit
Only the final grade will be published in Osiris. Leerdoelen Students should be able to:
  • In terms of the group assignments
    • Distill the exact identification strategy and threats to identification from journal articles.
    • Retrieve the main contribution of an existing journal article to the existing literature.
    • Apply quasi-experimental techniques (DiD, RDD, IV) to data to answer a research question
    • Discuss research design and design of a research proposal with classmates
  • In terms of the government or industry cases
    • Translate a case into a quantitative research question
    • Search for, compare with and discuss contribution to existing literature
    • Decide whether a causal or non-causal research design is required.
    • Present and discuss findings of the actual research
    • Write a research report

Inhoud

The seminar is structured around three main topics.
First, the course starts with analyzing the largest category of institutional investors based on assets under management, defined benefit and defined contribution pension funds. We will also study endowment funds and sovereign wealth funds, and compare the assets and liabilities of these institutional investors.
Second, the seminar will focus on the asset allocation policy implemented by institutional investors. We will answer two key questions. How do institutions decide on the level of capital to allocate to individual asset classes? How to implement the asset allocation? The seminar will discuss the issues of diversification, portfolio optimization, trading costs, passive and active strategies. We will discuss not only traditional investments in equity and fixed income, but also investments in alternative assets, like private equity, hedge funds and real estate. The students will also work on a quantitative assignment that analyzes the added value of alternative assets for the current portfolio of a pension fund.
Third, the seminar will cover in-depth the governance and organizational complexities surrounding institutional investors. This part of the course will discuss the fiduciary responsibilities of institutional investors and study the role of socially responsible investing and institutional shareholder activism. An important question is whether investing in this type of funds has consequences for institutional investors because of the inherent restriction of the universe of stocks.

Leerdoelen

The goal of this seminar is to get a good understanding of the way institutional asset managers invest large pools of money. The focus is on pension funds, sovereign wealth funds and endowments.
Insights in the role of alternative asset classes in a portfolio, such as hedge funds, private equity and commodities.
Insights in the difference and between active and passive investment strategies and the implications for asset management organization.
Insights in the practice of responsible investing by institutional investors.
Students will learn how to work in groups, participate in a discussion, critically read academic articles, present to an audience.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No fundamental differences. One group assignment less than before. All classes in person on campus, apart from a few guest lectures. Belangrijk om te weten No additional costs. We are probably not going to visit a company this year. If we do, that would involve the cost of a train ticket to Amsterdam for those who don't have a public transport card. Extra The main elements for which you receive a grade are: group assignments (50%), presentation (15%), participation (15%), individual assignment (10%) and a small in-class exam (10%) at the end.
Obligatory attendance at all sessions.
Satisfactory result for assignments.
In-class presentations.
Active participation in class.

course_title: Seminar Interest Rates and Stock Markets
text:
Inhoud

This seminar covers several topics on interest rates and stock markets.
In particular, we discuss term structure of interest rates, interest rates modeling, cross-sectional stock returns, investor recognition hypothesis and financial crisis.
Students are expected to study and present the literature from renowned academic journals, lead and participate in group discussions. There are two assignments on empirical asset pricing.
In addition, you will present your own ideas and write a research proposal.

Leerdoelen
  • Understand empirical methods in asset price analysis.
  • Design interest rate modelling for security pricing.
  • Design portfolio selection methods and analyze their advantages and disadvantages.
  • Evaluate studies in the field of asset pricing and judge their contributions.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar some articles have changed due to updating of class contents Extra na

lecturers: ['dr. LE Westerink - Duijzer', 'dr. MH Akyuz', 'dr. S Sharif Azadeh', 'prof.dr. D Huisman']
text:
Inhoud

The seminar covers the application of different Operations Research techniques to a real-world application presented by a company. The particular cases vary from year to year and include public transport planning, vehicle routing, inventory control, etc.
The seminar builds forth on the theory given in all other masters courses. Moreover, good programming skills are required.

Leerdoelen
  • Students should be able to formulate a quantitative model for a specific logistic problem.
  • Students should be able to defend their model selection and be able to adapt standard operations research model to the sitation on hand.
  • They have to be able to formulate the necessary assumptions and evaluate their practical implication; Students have to be able to analyze data to come up with the parameter values needed for the model.
  • Students should be able to implement a method in a computer program and give advice for the problem on hand.
  • Students have to be able to interpret the results and write a management / scientific report as well a presentation on the results.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar There will be no major changes compared to last year, since last year almost all Covid restrictions were released. Therefore, the set-up will be the same as last year. 

The cases themselves are every year different. More information about the cases will be available end of December. Extra Other obligations for the student:
  • Scientific report on their study:
  • Presentations on their study.

Inhoud

This seminar focuses on the design and use of accounting information for decision making and decision influencing. The emphasis will be on understanding how managers can design and use accounting information to help the organisation achieve its objectives. Some of the topics that will be discussed are Management Control Frameworks, Performance measurement, Incentives, Costing systems, Budgeting and Accouting for non-profits. In this seminar learning will occur trough active participation, class discussion, and self-discipline. To enhance this, the professor will assign each student to a team consisting of 2-4 students. Each team has to write a paper on one of the topics of the seminar, assigned by the professor. Each team will present their paper in the session on that specific topic. One of the other teams has to be the discussant team, and still another team is responsible for chairing the session and stimulate the discussion in class. Each team has to fulfill each of the different roles at least once. The professor will make a schedule at the beginning of the seminar that lists when each team has to perform a specific role. Please note that this seminar is one of the most important parts of the bachelor program. It will be very time-consuming: 12 ECTS in 8 weeks is, on average, 42 hours of work per week.

Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insights into the “state-of-the-art” in the academic management accounting and control literature on selected topics.
  • Students are able to apply Management Accounting and Control concepts, theories, and research techniques.
  • Students are able to conduct research in the field of Management Accounting and Control resulting in a seminar paper.
  • Students are expected to actively participate in the class discussion, to present pieces of the empirical literature, to chair meetings, critically analyse research paper, and to write a paper based on corresponding group assignments.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Last year, the seminar sessions were held online due to the Corona measures. As it appears, this year the sessions will be held on campus. Extra Obligatory attendance at all sessions.

Inhoud
  • This course discusses the commonly used control mechanisms used by firms such as performance measurement, pay-for-performance systems, target setting, promotion decisions, and corporate governance. In particular, students learn why certain control methods are used, what are the advantages and disadvantages, and how to apply them.
  • This course relies on both academic papers and real-life cases to help students understand the control systems and to build connections between theories and problems in practice.
Leerdoelen

This course provides students with a thorough understanding of research topics of management control. Management controls refer to management activities that can stimulate employees and managers to act in the way that organizational goals can be achieved. Management accounting research thus examines antecedents and consequences of different control methods that rely on accounting information to motivate agents to behave in the desired manner. By learning these topics, students should be able to apply theories to practical control issues that commonly happen in firms.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The set-up is similar to the previous year. This course uses different tasks to help students learn the theories and build the link between theories and practice. To help students better prepare for the master thesis, students this year will write a thesis proposal in this seminar.

lecturers: ['dr. BLV Tindemans, MBA', 'drs. MJL van Hasselt, BSc']
text:
Inhoud

Marketing strategy addresses firm opportunities to advance customer relations through research, analysis, and long-term planning. The fundamental goal is to gain a competitive advantage and maximize long-term profit. This seminar is designed to synthesize knowledge already acquired in core marketing and strategy courses, and then apply it to specific business cases. Therefore, the aim is not to gain new knowledge, rather to apply theoretical models and market research methods to real marketing problems. Students will work as individuals and in groups to learn about and analyze several interesting cases studies; then, develop actionable strategic marketing plans. Students will be expected to submit written plans and at times present orally.

Leerdoelen

This course attempts to help develop integrated marketing skills to succeed in business. It has a strong application orientation. Specifically, students will learn:

  • How theoretical models work in practice;
  • How to link different concepts and theories learned and apply them to real marketing cases;
  • How to successfully market products or services, as well as develop innovation strategies;
  • How to make optimal use of market research and analysis techniques in developing marketing strategies.

Inhoud

The seminar is organized around several key papers (and background reading) in the economics of organizations. Topics covered include the theory of contracts, theory of the firm, incentives and productivity, and vertical integration. Topics vary from year to year depending on the interests of the students.

Leerdoelen
  • Provide students with a toolkit for thinking about and dealing with problems inside organizations.
  • To learn about the state of the art in the economic theory of organizations.
  • To learn about the data and methods required to test the theory, and more specifically how field experiments can be used to glean insights about organizational theory.
  • To be able to assess inefficiencies relating to incentive problems and organizational design more generally and to evaluate alternative pay schemes and organizational structures that purport to alleviate such efficiencies.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course set up will be quite different as compared to previous years. Students will work on a topical issue, making contributions to a joint living document. During the sessions, research questions will be developed and research findings by the students will be presented and discussed.

course_title: Seminar Ports and Global Logistics: Disruptive Scenarios
text:
Inhoud

Content
Scenario planning originates from the military. Scenarios allow military planners to augment enemy moves and get grip on the uncertainties of a dynamic battlefield in order to manage the deployment of troops and military assets effectively. Likewise, international businesses and multinational enterprises operate in various interconnected markets and are exposed to a great variety of risk, non-linearity and complexity. Think about the sudden but enormous impact of Covid-19 on the short term (quarantines, travel bans) and how it might impact on the long term (digital acceleration, deglobalizing supply chains). Scenario planning is used by international businesses as a strategic tool to cope with rapidly changing business environments that are often characterized by disruptions and uncertainty. Thinking in scenarios allow business leaders to augment possible futures on the fortunes of their company upon which they can define various options and strategic investment decisions. In this seminar students will learn how to apply scenario planning as a strategic management tool. Each group of students will write a scenario report for one real-world international company active in shipping, trade and logistics

Leerdoelen

Learning aim
The aim of this seminar is to apply scenario planning techniques and methodologies so that students can develop realistic future scenarios for the year 2040 on behalf of an international company in the shipping industry that operates in world full of disruptions and uncertainty.
Learning outcomes
After this seminar students are able to:
• Identify various trends and disruptions with an impact on ports, shipping and supply chains
• Generate large amounts of business intelligence from various sources and synthesize these into a coherent strategy
• Employ scenario planning methodologies
• Self-organize into groups and communicate results under time pressur

Inhoud

The seminar covers a set of timely topics including income inequality, unconventional monetary policy, and the recent (current) pandemic. Ample attention is given to the challenges posed by the economic crises to the macroeconomic profession. The seminar will be highly interactive. In the first part of each lecture, prof. Markiewicz will introduce and explain the theoretical and empirical foundations of each topic. The second part of each lecture will contain the presentations of the related scientific articles by the students. Basic knowledge of macroeconomic models and econometric tools is required for this seminar.

Leerdoelen
  • Have up-to-date knowledge of current macro models.
  • Be able to carry out a simple forecasting exercise.
  • Know how to estimate a small-scale VAR model.

course_title: Seminar Recent Advances in Economics of Markets and Organisations
text:
Inhoud

During the seminar, academic research papers are presented and discussed by students. Moreover, each student works on a research project (which can, but need not be an extension of one of the papers) and writes a short note on this. Papers are chosen from a list of recent academic research papers on current topics in the economics of markets and organisation. These include both theoretical and empirical papers.

Leerdoelen
  • Learn about recent advances in both theoretical and empirical economics of markets and organisations.
  • Learn how to present an academic paper in the area of economics of markets and organisations.
  • Learn how to formally discuss an academic paper in the area of economics of markets and organisations
  • Learn how to perform a small-scale academic study, either theoretical or empirical, in the area of economics of markets and organisations.
  • Learn how to write a short essay reporting research findings.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Papers will be updated. Extra Obligatory attendance at all sessions.
Satisfactory results for essay, presentation, formal discussions in class (at least twice), discussion slides (twice a week), participation in general discussion.
As compared to last year, there will be a couple of sessions where students present their draft research proposal.

Inhoud

Cities and regions are going through a constant process of economic, social and spatial change. This applies to the most successful global cities but also to those cities that had to go through (or are still going through) a process of economic restructuring because their dominant industries collapsed. This continuous economic, social, and spatial development of cities can strengthen its competitive position but for cities struggling to reinvent their economies, it can be (and possibly still is) a painful process. Additionally, urban areas, companies and citizens increasingly face problems in terms of accessibility and mobility. Congestion, pollution and social exclusion are only some of the major challenges that decision makers have to address. And they have to do this in a fast-changing world; in recent years new forms of mobility (sharing-, electric-, micro-, floating-mobility) have developed at a fast pace. Finally, the recent COVID-19 crisis will most probably influence the way we travel for a while. Hence, the economic and transport development of cities and regions are topics that are high on the agenda of companies, policymakers, practitioners and academics.
In this seminar, the objective is to develop the ability to give strategic advice to stakeholders in order to increase their competitiveness. Students learn to use different research methods (i.e. data analysis, case study, surveys etc.) in order to come up with intelligent solutions to the most common urban and transport problems. These skills can be used by students when conducting research for their master thesis.
Some seminar sessions might include guest speakers’ presentations. In the last years this seminar has covered the following topics:
• Regional Economic Policies and Networks
• Travel Behaviour
• Smart Mobility and Transport Infrastructure
• Sharing mobility and mobility hubs
• Urban retail
These topics are discussed based on the latest scientific insights and real-life case study. Students are stimulated to use a variety of research tools to analyse actual challenges. This is an intensive course that combines interactive group discussions, the writing of weekly individual essays, (field) assignments as well as empirical group work and assignments.

Leerdoelen

The main aim of the course is to train students in the economic analysis of contemporary challenges in the fields of transport, and urban and regional development. More specifically the objectives are:
1. To deepen the knowledge on specific regional and transport problems by advanced scientific readings.
2. To develop the ability to apply research and methodological tools to analyse contemporary regional and transport challenges.
3. To develop accurate and sound economic strategic advice for stakeholders.
These aims will be achieved through interactive group discussions and the writing of individual essays and a group assignment.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The Urban Retail session has been replaced with an additional transport-related topic, related to a case study  of an European sharing mobility company. This will include one or more guest lectures.

Inhoud

The financial sector constantly creates new products, services, and institutions. Some examples of paramount importance include financial The globalization of business paired with rapid technological changes, increased volatility in the financial markets, and extraordinary monetary policy measures has changed the risk profiles of many companies and banks dramatically. At the same time, derivative markets have grown accordingly and the routes to managing market and credit risks have expanded. As a result, many firms have embraced the concept of risk management. However, applying derivatives for risk management ('financial engineering') requires a deep understanding of their characteristics, their pricing and last but not least of the markets on which they are traded. This seminar is devoted to the analysis and management of risks and complements the course FEM11023 - Financial Risk Management. The seminar covers a wide range of derivative contracts, ranging from plain vanilla (forwards, futures, swaps and options) to more exotic (exotic options, weather and insurance derivatives) that will be applied in a trading game. Moreover, you will learn how changes in monetary policy and the macroeconomic environment affect the business models of financial institutions. We will also cover origins and consequences of recent crises, like the global financial crisis, or the COVID crisis. By means of group assignments, various practical and theoretical issues of derivatives, risk analysis, integrated risk management, and the changing role of banks for the real economy are explored in depth.

Leerdoelen

• Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory of financial risk management.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into recent developments in financial innovation.
• Students are able to apply standard measures to evaluate market and credit risks.
• Students are able to write a research assignment

Extra The final grade is determined based on individual work including discussion contributions (oral and written), presentations, a discussion leadership, and the group assignments with a common grade.

course_title: Seminar Stock Pricing and Investment Strategies
text:
Inhoud

Among the topics discussed are:

  • Seasonal anomalies
  • Cross-sectional anomalies such as the size effect and the value premium
  • Multifactor risk models for explaining differences in stock returns
  • Investor behavior, under- and overreaction
  • Limits to arbitrage
Leerdoelen
  • The goal of this seminar is to get a better understanding of the pricing process in stock markets, where an emphasis is put on empirical research in practice.
  • Insights in the measurement of (ab)normal returns and the risks, the interpretation of empirical results in relation to stock and firm features, and the construction of investment strategies.
  • Students are expected to actively participate in the class discussion, to present pieces of the empirical literature, to chair meetings, to do empirical research with stock and firm data, and to write short papers based on corresponding group assignments.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Only a few papers on the syllabus changed. Extra Grading is based on two papers, a presentation, discussion participation in class, discussion points and being a discussion leader.

Inhoud

To achieve its learning goals, this seminar combines a hands-on marketing strategy simulation (StratSim) with discussion-based sessions (lectures, coaching, and cases), which allows us to offer you important insights that can become the cornerstone of a career in marketing, consulting, corporate strategy, or entrepreneurship.

In particular, we will embrace four common tension points in marketing strategy:

1. The tension between the short and the long term
2. The tension between targeted and focused marketing efforts (i.e., a "local" approach) and mass market appeal (i.e., a "global"approach)
3. The tension between volume and profit margin
4. The tension between insights and evidence, and the need for assumptions and intuition when making decisions under uncertainty

Thus, we will make strategic marketing decisions for simulated firms and for a total of 7-8 simulated years, which will allow us to feel and practice how to handle these tensions.

Leerdoelen

Marketing strategy is critical for firms. However, it is not always clear how marketing leaders should make strategic marketing decisions. In this course, you will learn how to make strategic marketing decisions in a realistic environment.

The three key objectives of this course are:
1. Learning and practicing marketing strategy (i.e., we will bridge the “theory” and the “practice” of strategic marketing.
2. Learning and practicing evidence-based decision-making (i.e., we will learn the benefits and limitations of market research data and insights for strategic marketing decisions)
3. Gaining soft skills and teamwork skills (we will work in a diverse large team, comparable in size to a strategic leadership team, and learn how to divide roles, adopt decision processes and join efforts to make better decisions)

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar We restructured the guest lecture sessions. We also restructured the ‘insights’ part to emphasize two emerging topics in marketing research (customer immersion and new ethnographic methods + A/B testing and experimentation in companies). Belangrijk om te weten All students are required to purchase our digital reader (course pack) for this course ($49.95; approx. 42 EUR). The price of the course pack serves mainly to pay for the individual license of the StratSim simulation from Interpretive Simulations.
  Extra Assignments (100%):
Class participation (peer evaluation): 15%:
StratSim performance: 15%:
Stratsim reports (3): 45%:
Evidence-based strategic marketing report: 25%:

All students are required to purchase our digital reader (course pack) for this course (approx. 50 EUR). The price of the course pack serves mainly to pay for the individual license of the StratSim simulation from Interpretive Simulations.

lecturers: ['A Gupta', 'dr. MH Coveney', 'dr. TLPR Peeters', 'dr. VH Gonzalez Jimenez', 'ME Hees', 'T Atav']
text:
Inhoud

The content of the seminar is fourfold. Two group assignments:
1. Solving a business case on a strategy issue using relevant insights from the academic literature and available data to the best extent.
2. Collecting and summarizing research papers to give an overview of relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy Providing a critical assessment of the literature to identify a relevant research question for further research.
And two individual assignments:
3. Presenting a research paper in class to give an insight in relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy. Answering questions from fellow students and moderating a class discussion.
4. Writing a summary on each of the research questions discussed in class with critical assessment of the presented papers.
Example topics:
1. Can successful management practices be transferred across countries and firms?
2. What is the impact of top managers on the performance of firms?
3. Can firms acquire new technology by hiring workers?
4. What is the effect of entry regulation on economic performance?
5. Why are firms using other firms to produce their output?

Leerdoelen
  • Read and understand state-of-the-art economic literature on strategy, managerial economics and firm entry and exit.
  • Summarize and communicate insights from scientific papers on economics of strategy in a class presentation.
  • Search and analyse firm data in a group project to solve a business case related to entry strategy.
  • Write an informed opinion on current topics in strategy research based on relevant literature.
  • Conduct an in-depth literature review and define a relevant research question on a specialized topic in industrial dynamics and strategy.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Research themes change continuously in response to student interests and scientific developments. Extra N.B.: Application to this seminar implies obligatory attendance in case of admission!

course_title: Seminar Supply Chain Management and Optimisation
text:
Inhoud

This seminar gives a quantitative insight into the design of a supply chain. It provides a tool-box in terms of research skills (Optimization through Excel and statistics skills and finding data) , theory and methods in order to be able to analyze and optimize supply chains, focusing on costs as well as CO2 emissions. We focus on a case for transporting white goods from China to Europe. The case serves to get hands-on experience in the considerations for choosing between different transport modes (ship, truck or rail), cost structures, selection of distribution network type, port choices and locations of distribution centers. Finally we also evaluate environmental issues relating to supply chains. The required theory will be given in courses at the start of the seminar.

Leerdoelen

To understand the effect of various supply chain drivers.
To be able to analyse a supply chain according to various characteristics.
To be able to apply supply chain design and transport chain models.
To develop the research skills and methods necessary to analyze and optimize supply chains w.r.t costs and environmental criteria.
To develop computer skills for supply chain calculations and visualisation.
To write a well-documented report.
To present results in a clear and convincing way.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Updated figures for container transportation costs will be used.
Product models will be updated.

lecturers: ['dr. AS Bhaskarabhatla', 'dr. B Hoogendoorn', 'dr. SJA Hessels']
text:
Inhoud

Required literature (journal articles) is announced in the schedule below and is listed in the assignment document texts that will be provided on Canvas. For several of the assignments students will also have to search for additional literature themselves.

Leerdoelen

The “Seminar in Strategic Firm Behaviour” provides students with insights into a number of timely topics in the field of Strategy Economics. The Seminar concentrates on several strategic decisions that help firms sustain in the market. These strategic decisions include, among others, pricing strategy, competitive strategy, sustainability strategy, export strategy and growth strategy. The seminar is research-orientated, helping students to further develop and apply their skills for conducting academic research as well as for doing more applied research useful for future employers in the field of Strategy Economics. The seminar helps students how to develop advice for firms and policy makers based on analysing data and reviewing relevant literature. Students work in groups of maximum 4 students on three different group assignments. Students also work on two assignments individually.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No significant changes in the seminar although there are some changes in the timing and organization of the various assignments during the seminar.

Inhoud
  • General development of FinTech disruptions
  • Machine learning and credit default risk
  • Discrimination and technologies
  • Marketplace credit lending
  • Technology adoption on financial market
  • Digital banking
Leerdoelen

After completing this seminar, students can

  • gain immediate knowledge on the major financial innovations regarding their performance
  • learn about the first-order debates around such applications
  • evaluate FinTech disruptions both qualitatively and quantitatively
  • obtain basic skills in big data analysis, machine learning, and master thesis writing
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar We will have a new guest lecture from KPMG. Extra The grade is based on group casework, research projects, and individual presentation, discussion participation, etc.
Test:​
Assignments, presentations, discussion, essays, ... (100%)

Inhoud

This seminar covers recent topics in International Trade. Among others, the following questions are explored: Can international trade help countries grow rich? Does international trade cause inequality? Who is for and against trade in politics, and why? Why do countries have trade surpluses/deficits, and to which extent are such imbalances problematic? What are the causes and effects of trade wars? How does international trade affect international relations? The seminar combines economic theory, quantitative empirical evidence, and historical case studies to throw light on these topics.

Leerdoelen

1. Familiarize yourself with the most important theories in international trade
2. Get to know the quantitative empirical evidence
3. Get a big picture overview of the history of global trade

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar n contrast to last year, there will be no final exam for this seminar. Instead, the assessment is based entirely on assignments.

course_title: Seminar Urban, Port and Transport Economics
text:
Inhoud

In the seminar of major Urban, Port and Transport Economics, students analyze a spatial economic question. The seminar develops an economic location choice framework. Supplemented with spatial analysis (GIS) and empirical analysis of commuting (gravity equations), students simulate the spatial effects of a real-life economic scenario, such as the construction of new houses, new rail or road infrastructure, or structural economic change. An introduction to working with and visualizing spatial data is part of the course.

Leerdoelen
  • To define a problem and to use a coherent economic framework to address it
  • To analyze and visualize large data
  • To formulate advise based on economic research
  • To organise work and cooperate in a group.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Following developments in the field and society, new case study on logistics is introduced, supported by a game. Extra Final grade is a weighted average of individual (20%) and group assignments (80%).
The individually obtained grades must be sufficient (5.5 or higher).

Inhoud

The Seminar in Business Analytics aims to apply and possibly extend econometric and machine/deep learning techniques in a business context. At the central stage is the customer in a broad sense of its meaning aiming to benefit from a business analysis. Examples of questions related to this topic are: How to recommend products to customers?, How to summarize sentiment information from product reviews?, How to make predictions that can help customers make better decisions? How to aggregate heterogeneous product information? The domain of applications is broad, some examples are: e-commerce, marketing, finance, politics, and sports. The data can come in different modalities: numeric, text, image, sound, or video, which means techniques from statistics, knowledge representation, natural language processing, and computer vision can also be used.

Examples of research topics are: market/business forecasting, credit default prediction, anomaly detection, sentiment mining, recommender systems, and duplicates detection. Groups of four students will work on a business analytics topic, spanning a full research trajectory composed of: research question formulation, related work analysis, methodology design and implementation, results evaluation and interpretation, and research summarization and future work suggestion. Students will need to present various research artifacts, show critical thinking, and write a short scientific paper based on the results of their work. The datasets will be provided as well as guidance in selecting an appropriate research question.

Leerdoelen
  • Obtain in-depth knowledge about econometric and OR techniques related to business analytics, and new developments in this field.
  • Learn how to formulate a research question.
  • Learn how to critically read and discuss academic papers.
  • Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
  • Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
  • Learn how to interpret results to answers to research questions.
  • Apply quantitative techniques in a real-world setting.
  • Learn to report about the research project in the form of a scientific report and a presentation.
  • Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Seminar is new

lecturers: ['J Klooster', 'JMJ van Druten', 'prof.dr. RL Lumsdaine', 'S van Meer', 'SJ Koobs']
text:
Inhoud

Economic forecasting plays a key role in macroeconomics, monetary policy decisions, labor market decisions and quantitative finance. It is an indispensable tool at central banks, different governmental institutions and various financial institutions. The seminar focuses on both theoretical foundations and practical implementation aspects on how to construct good forecasts, how to evaluate whether our constructed forecasts are good enough, and how to compare competing forecasts given by different methods. Within this general framework, the topic of the seminar revolves around the following research questions:

  • How to forecast and compare forecasts in unstable environments (for e.g., covid recession)?
  • How to forecast in data-rich environments?
  • How can machine learning be useful for forecasting?
  • How to forecasts inflation in the current high inflation times?
Leerdoelen
  • Obtain in-depth knowledge about econometric techniques related to forecasting, and new developments in this field.
  • Learn how to formulate a research question.
  • Learn how to critically read and discuss academic papers.
  • Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
  • Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
  • Learn how to interpret results to answers to research questions.
  • Apply quantitative techniques in a real-world setting.
  • Learn to report about the research project in the form of a scientific report and a presentation.
  • Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Seminar is new

lecturers: ['B Van Os, MSc', 'dr. G Freire', 'JMJ van Druten']
text:
Inhoud

In this seminar we discuss econometric and financial research related to investing. In particular, you learn how to form and evaluate optimal portfolios. Relevant research questions include “How should an investor optimally distribute wealth? What estimates are needed to implement these allocations? What estimators are suitable given features of the data? How can we evaluate and compare empirical performance? What are the practical shortcomings of the allocations?”. To explore this topic, we address fundamental features historically associated with equity markets. This includes the importance of diversification and timing for investing. From this starting point we consider the econometric methods required for a successful implementation of optimal portfolios. We carefully discuss potential limitations such as parameter uncertainty and its practical implications. Based on literature covered in the first three weeks of the case studies, you are able to delve into the most recent research and formulate your own proposal. The research projects are conducted by groups of four students.

Leerdoelen
  • Obtain in-depth knowledge about econometric techniques related to investing, and new developments in this field.
  • Learn how to formulate a research question.
  • Learn how to critically read and discuss academic papers.
  • Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
  • Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
  • Learn how to interpret results to answers to research questions.
  • Apply quantitative techniques in a real-world setting.
  • Learn to report about the research project in the form of a scientific report and a presentation.
  • Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Seminar is new

lecturers: ['dr. MA Mankowski', 'H Deng', 'JMJ van Druten', 'M Mueller', 'MFO Welz', 'prof.dr. RL Lumsdaine']
text:
Inhoud

Data is known to be the oil and gold of the 21st century. However, surprisingly few professionals have enough skills to ensure the best use of this resource. With the growing availability of data, machine learning is becoming increasingly important in strategic decision-making and problem solving. Data-driven solutions can deliver benefits in virtually every industry ranging from credit scoring models and image recognition to self-driving cars and content selection on Netflix. Various machine learning techniques can uncover highly complex relationships in data which can be used for the strategic decision-making process. With the help of insights gained from structured or unstructured data, organizations hope to gain a competitive advantage and efficiency.

In this seminar, students will be introduced to the broad field of machine learning with its main concepts and principles. The students will be introduced to such central methods of machine learning as penalized regression, tree-based methods, and neural networks. Subsequently, methods for text analytics and cluster analysis will be discussed. All methods will be illustrated by concrete practical examples. Finally, the students will apply the gained knowledge to work on their own projects. After finalizing this seminar, students will acquire the necessary skills to consider data science problems from different angles, including managerial and technical.

As a result of successful studies students:

  • will be able to solve real-world problems by identifying a suitable machine learning tool;
  • will have the necessary skills to analyze the validity of machine learning algorithms for different types of data (binary, categorical, discrete, numerical, text, image, audio);
  • will be able to select most suitable techniques by performing evaluation of learning algorithms and model selection;
  • will create policy recommendations for companies by transforming results produced by machine learning algorithms.
Leerdoelen
  • Obtain in-depth knowledge about econometric and OR techniques related to machine learning, and new developments in this field.
  • Learn how to formulate a research question.
  • Learn how to critically read and discuss academic papers.
  • Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
  • Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
  • Learn how to interpret results to answers to research questions.
  • Apply quantitative techniques in a real-world setting.
  • Learn to report about the research project in the form of a scientific report and a presentation.
  • Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Seminar is new

lecturers: ['dr. MA Mankowski', 'dr. RM Badenbroek', 'JMJ van Druten', 'prof.dr. APM Wagelmans']
text:
Inhoud

In this seminar you learn how to apply methods in Econometrics and Operations Research to logistics. Logistics is a broad and important application area of Operation Research. Questions to be answered when solving a practical problem are: “What is a suitable optimization model, what data is required to optimize the model, and how can the results be interpreted and applied?” The seminar explores new mathematical modeling and optimization techniques focusing both on the theoretical background and the practical implementation. The practical implementation consists of a case study conducted by a group of four students.

Examples of case studies in recent years are:

  • Optimization of the production of concrete floors at Dycore
  • Design of a maintenance policy for a fleet of specialized multipurpose survey vessels
  • Planning audit visits to suppliers for Philips
  • Planning and routing of recycling trucks on a Danish peninsula
  • Inventory optimization at Bol.com


Each year students will work on a case that is different from any case in previous years.

Leerdoelen

Obtain in-depth knowledge about OR techniques related to logistics, and new developments in this field.
Learn how to formulate a research question.
Learn how to critically read and discuss academic papers.
Learn to decide upon the appropriate modeling and optimization techniques to answer the research question.
Learn how to select a suitable optimization model based on the available data.
Learn how to interpret results to answers to research questions.
Apply quantitative techniques in a real-world setting.
Learn to report about the research project in the form of a scientific report and a presentation.
Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar based on the student evaluations of last year, we have followed the suggestion to have the introductory meeting at the beginning of the first week. Furthermore, the case will be different than last year.

course_title: Sensitivity and Competence in the Diverse Educational Context
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['AS Dias - Broens, MSc', 'R de Lima - van Gent']
text:
Inhoud The aim of the practical ‘Intercultural sensitivity and competence’ is to support students and give students tools to become aware of, develop and strengthen their own intercultural sensitivity and competences in society, and in the daily practices within education. Firstly, students will work on the ability to observe cultural differences. They will make use of intercultural incidents they encountered themselves and they will reflect on these encounters together. In this way, the intercultural environment of the student is used as a starting point in the process of becoming aware of and developing intercultural sensitivity and competences. Next, students are asked to investigate daily practices and challenges professionals in urban education encounter via qualitative research. In particular, students will interview professionals working in the field of education in the urban context of Rotterdam. The interviews will be transcribed, coded and analyzed by the students. Finally, the students are asked to apply the gained knowledge and skills with regard to acting sensitive and competent in intercultural settings in practice via an educational advice and in a role-play situation. The assessment of this practical is based on students’ critical reflection on their intercultural sensitivity and competences throughout this practical.
Leerdoelen Following completion of this course, students are able to do each of the following:

• Be aware of/perceive (in)equity and in-/exclusion in society and daily practice in education;
• Describe and evaluate their own frame of reference and the consequences of their actions in a diverse setting;
• Act sensitive and competent in diversity-related situations (i.e., they act in an inclusive way);
• Investigate, by means of qualitative research, the dilemmas professionals in the urban educational context encounter
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud When mental illnesses become complex, chronic, and comorbid, they may hit the limits of traditional mental health care. Especially when severe mental illnesses, such as psychosis spectrum disorders, go hand in hand with confused behaviour, comorbid conditions, homelessness, or other social problems, they are often considered difficult-to-treat. In this course, we take a different perspective on recovery in severe mental illness, to gain a new understanding of illness experience and meaningful outcome. We explore multidisciplinary, person-centred, process-based, and assertive outreach approaches, that incorporate personal and societal factors beyond the traditional clinical focus. 

In this course, you will actively evaluate the merits of traditional and innovative diagnostic and treatment models for complex cases of severe mental illness. You are challenged to take a critical position regarding DSM-driven diagnosis and treatment. You reflect on methodological standards and ethical dimensions in mental health research, and their impact on clinical practice. Finally, you reflect on your role as health care professional, and work on a constructive use of language to facilitate meaningful recovery in severe mental illness. Leerdoelen

At the end of this course, the student knows how to 

1. Evaluate different models of psychopathology, treatment, and recovery. 
2. Identify complex mental disorders and disabilities related to psychosis and ‘confused behaviour’. 
3. Take a critical stance towards the use of the DSM and other diagnostic approaches in clinical practice and scientific research. 
4. Reflect on research methods and their impact on clinical practice. 
5. Explain the value of multidisciplinary research and practice versus standardized approaches in working with severe mental illness. 
6. Reflect on their own role as a psychologist within a multidisciplinary team, including awareness of the ethical dimension of clinical practice. 
7. Choose language that is sensitive to personal meaning and supportive to the recovery process. 

Belangrijk om te weten Attendance is mandatory for three tutorial group meetings in weeks 2-4. Students are urged to attend the lectures before the tutorial group meetings.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. J.E. Roeters van Lennep', 'dr. M. Kavousi', 'prof. dr. A. Maassen van den Brink']
text:
Leerdoelen

Course description 
The department of Epidemiology, in collaboration with the department of Internal Medicine, offers medical and health professionals a short introductory one-day workshop on Gender & Health at Erasmus University Medical Center. To realize gender equality in health care, sex and gender dimension needs to be integrated in all aspects of research and clinical practice. This course brings together experts from a multitude of disciplines including clinical, basic science, public health and policy and provides participants with resources that will assist them in developing and strengthening gender-equal clinical care and research programs. 

The purpose of the course is to provide participants interested in improving gender-equal health and well-being with essential knowledge and principal skills from several disciplines. 

Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course. You will receive all details about the location and the final programme for the course one week prior to the start of the course. 

Learning goals  
1.To provide insight on the Erasmus MC policy of diversity 
2. To provide insight on the importance of sex and gender in health care research 
3. To provide tools how to implement in basic, epidemiological and clinical research 
4. To provide knowledge on sex and gender in research funding 

Course Schedule 2022-2023

Assessments  
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course 
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.
Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.
The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.     
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’. 

Evaluation  
Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years.  On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.  

No certificates 
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved. 

Cancellation policy  
Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. HC Dibbits', 'dr. I Gusc', 'dr. L Green', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. MF van Dijck', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. RJ Adriaansen', 'dr. S Bertrand', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'dr. V Baptist', 'dr. Y van Hoef', 'L Zurné, MA', 'prof.dr. CR Ribbens', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann', 'prof.dr. RD Futselaar']
text:
Inhoud During the Master’s program, students have the opportunity to explore a professional field of interest by means of a Research Internship. Arrangements have been made with around 15-20 national and international archives, museums, research institutes, educational organizations and business companies for research projects which students may select as the subject for their Master’s thesis. Please note that this is not a policy-related internship; it involves an academic research project. The final product may be a publication, an international workshop, website, object analysis or exhibition storyline. This research activity covers 18 working days (5 ECTS). Some internships are linked to the research of a master thesis.
All internships will be announced at the end of term-1 on BlackBoard; there is also an indication whether an internship is linked to a master thesis subject. The internships will also be presented at the Master Thesis Market.
 
Each student formulates a working plan after consultation with the faculty supervisor and the supervisor of the internship institution. Based on that working plan, an official Agreement Research Internship Master History of Society will be signed by: the student, the supervisor of the institution and the faculty supervisor. The research internship will be completed with a report, written by the student according to the guidelines of the master. The report contains also appendixes with important outcomes and products (written or images of the products). The whole report and internship will be assessed during a final interview with the supervisors. Based on this interview the supervisor of the institution will write a general assessment. The faculty supervisor will assess whether the student
has reached the aims of this internship; there is no grade. For an explanation see the documents on the websitehttp://www.eshcc.eur.nl/english/history/mahs/current/researchinternship/. Leerdoelen
  • Students can apply historical skills and knowledge in a professional organization
  • Students can explain how their historical knowledge and skills are transferable to different sectors of employment: business, culture, education, government, research
  • Students can reflect on their internship activities in an internship report

Inhoud

De volgende simulatietechnieken worden behandeld:

  • Inleiding simulatiemodel
  • Vertalen complexe econometrische en besliskundige problemen in een simulatiemodel
  • Simulatiemodel validatie
  • Inleiding random generatoren
  • Methoden voor het genereren van realisaties van kansvariabelen
  • Discrete event simulatie
  • Monte Carlo methode
  • Statistische analyse van de uitkomsten van simulatie-experimenten
  • Simulatie optimalisatie

Dit vak gebruikt kennis van FEB22008 Markov Processen en FEB22012 Programmeren, en is nodig voor FEB23004 Quantitative Methods for Logistics.

Leerdoelen
  • Het zelfstandig kunnen vertalen van complexe econometrische en besliskundige problemen in een simulatiemodel.
  • Het kunnen genereren van realisaties van kansvariabelen op een efficiënte manier.
  • Het kunnen interpreteren en bekritiseren van de resultaten van discrete event simulatie-experimenten.
  • Het kunnen implementeren van simulatiemodellen met gebruik van Java.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No major changes

Inhoud

The following simulation techniques will be covered:

  • Basic set-up of a Discrete-event simulation model
  • Formulating complex econometric and OR problems in a simulation model.
  • Model validation
  • Random number generators
  • Methods to generate realisations of random variables
  • Discrete event simulation
  • Monte Carlo method
  • Statistical analysis of simulation results
  • Simulation optimization

This course uses knowledge of FEB22008X Markov Processes and FEB22012X Programming, and is required for FEB23004 Quantitative Methods for Logistics.

Leerdoelen
  • Being able to formulate independently a complex econometric / OR problem into a simulation model.
  • Generating realisation of random variables in an efficient way.
  • Interpreting and analysing outputs of discrete event simulation-experiments.
  • Being able to implement a simulation model using Java
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No major changes t

Inhoud
Instructor: 
prof. dr. B.F. Heidergott (VU), dr. A.A.N Ridder (VU)
 
Course content:
This course gives a broad treatment of the important aspects of Monte Carlo simulation and its applications in areas such as inventory control, project planning, reliability, risk analysis and financial models. The emphasis is on modeling the stochastic dynamic system as a discrete event system, and analyzing and improving its performance by means of discrete event simulation. The topics covered include generating random numbers, selecting input distributions and model validation. The course also teaches the statistical output analysis and the use of simulation in optimization and learning.
Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

Knowledge and Understanding:  Understand sampling random objects, discrete event simulation, simulation based sensitivity analysis, statistical output analysis.

Application of Knowledge: Model real-life problems by discrete-event models; conduct Montecarlo simulation-based analysis of a problem and provide an output analysis; apply simulation in optimization and learning.

Making judgement: Draw conclusions from simulation output.

Communication: Report on their findings from a simulation study.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences

course_title: Skills Workshop I: Scientific integrity, Transparent Algorithms, & Ethical Data Analysis
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: Peter Wakker (EUR).
 
Course content:
The skill workshop series enables students to fine-tune skills needed for a successful academic career. The series opens by tackling important issues related to the scientific integrity, transparent algorithm and ethical data management, which are highly relevant for a business data scientist. In the second year, practical aspects related to how to handle the review process, and grant applications will be discussed. In these workshops, writing and positioning skills are emphasized. The series closes with a workshop on presentation skills for research talks and conference presentations.
Leerdoelen This series of workshops have the primary objectives to:
  1. Provide students with a solid understanding of scientific integrity issues and ethical data management
  2. Understand and practice the review process, as author and reviewer
  3. Understand and practice the grant application process
  4. Fine-tune their academic presentation skills.
This course in particular has the primary objective to provide students with solid understanding of scientific integrity issues and ethical data management.
