college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Skill Seminars are training seminars in practical skills offered within the CEMS network. They are essential to kick-starting an effective professional career and fundamental to adjusting easily to an international management environment. Skills seminars may be offered by a CEMS school or by CEMS corporate partners and are often offered in small-group settings to ensure and interactive dimension.


Topics may include:

  • Personal/leadership development
  • Intercultural (management) skills
  • Project Management
  • Group work skills
  • (International) negotiation techniques
  • Presentation skills
  • CV building and job application preparation
  • business communication


In order to meet graduation requirements, CEMS students must accrue minimum six skills seminar days, of which:

  1. 2 days must be in the form of the Global Citizenship seminar at the beginning of the spring semester
  2. And four additional days of a student’s choice must be taken


For IM/CEMS home students, one they have completed the above requirements and the Personal Leadership Development (PLD) module, they will be issued 4 EC toward the MSc International Management curriculum.

Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • To gain practical experience in developing professional skills in a variety of business domains

Inhoud

The small business is the most common type of business in every modern economy, and it is not just a scaled-down version of a large business. The course Small Business Economics is about the importance of small businesses and entrepreneurship for markets and economies. Main topics include the differences between small and large businesses, how small business ownership and entrepreneurship are related, how entrepreneurs exploit and deal with uncertainty, how small businesses contribute to economic growth, and how small businesses can attract finance. Lectures are organized around central questions. During the course, two assignments need to be completed on timely topics in the field of small business economics.

Leerdoelen
  • Introduction to the world of small business economics and the economics of entrepreneurship
  • Becoming familiar with the differences between small and large firms both from an external perspective (economy, market) and from an internal perspective (management, organisation)
  • Reflecting upon the impact of small businesses and entrepreneurship on economic development
  • Introduction to the specifics of small business finance
  • Applying theory to case studies
  • Mining publicly available data about small businesses and entrepreneurship for stylised facts using basic statistical tools
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Structure of the course will remain the same, but the lectures and assignments will get some updates to reflect the most recent literature and data.

course_title: Smart and Shared Cities: The world is changing and becoming "smart", but how do we ensure it is “SHARED”?
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['A Psyllidis', 'AJ Klievink', 'dr. JM Engelbert', 'E Eumann', 'L Meilof', 'MJ Slotboom, MSc', 'prof.dr. EA van Zoonen', 'prof.dr. JR Ortt', 'VM Butot, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

The minor SMART and SHARED Cities is a 15 EC and 30 EC minor programme combined. The student should choose the course load when registering for the minor. This is a full-time minor program – and participating in lectures and activities is mandatory.  

This minor is built on a combination of data, urban, political and social sciences. This multidisciplinary minor is open to all students who are interested in the development of smart and shared cities. The minor is offered in English and accessible for both national and international students. The format and modules include classic and innovative teaching methods, i.e. lectures and seminars, field trips, case-based group assignments, video production, blogging and logbooks and the integration of academia and practice. If necessary – all classes and activities will be online.

The program is characterized by a multi-disciplinary approach, which allows students to take different perspectives and understand the complexity of smart city life. The program intends to stimulate a reflective mindset, focusing on the interrelation of problems and responsible innovation. The learning goals concern knowledge, attitude and skills which in combination need to equip students with a critical mindset that enables them to work towards public needs and interests in smart cities.

Knowledge: Upon completion of the minor, the student will know what a smart city is and how the associated definitions and discourses produce a particular technological and data practice in which particular concerns and interests take privilege over others. S/he will also understand the kind of participatory spaces that are created by and for citizens, and the competing governance models that smart cities advocate. The student will also have a basic insight in the various data and analytics that are relevant to the development of smart cities.

Attitude: Students will develop a critical but constructive attitude towards different views and opinions about the smart city. They will value the contrasting perspectives of private and public stakeholders and will be able to adapt to and explain different views, suggest different solutions and prioritize advices based on different cases with different values. The core ethos of the minor concerns, however, public values in the smart cities, which are encapsulated in the SHARED principles and ethics that underlie various Dutch digital agendas and have been adopted by the VSNU.

Skills: Upon completion of the minor, students will be able to recognize particular interests and values in smart city discourse and practice; they will be able to choose appropriate data for specific urban challenges (critical thinking and information literacy); they will be able to work in multidisciplinary and trans-sectoral teams and adapt to particular team requirements and collaborative styles (collaboration and communication). For the 30 EC minor, an additional set of skills (e.g. Initiative and technology literacy) will be acquired through internships and projects in the research labs.


Special aspects:

Since this is a Leiden-Delft-Erasmus minor, the location of where education is offered difference per module. The minor takes place at Erasmus University, TU Delft and Leiden University. This minor is a full-time programme. Therefore it is not possible to combine this minor program with other extra-curricular activities.

It is possible for Erasmus students to complete the minor for 15 EC (modules 1, 2 and 3). EUR students can also choose to complete the minor as a whole for 30 EC. The extra 15 EC is extra-curricular. To include the extra 15 EC in your Bachelor program, EUR students need to ask permission from their Exam Board.

Deficiencies of students’ knowledge will be tackled at the beginning of each module. Each module will begin with an online quiz that will provide the student with a list of material for self-study to align the knowledge base of students from the various disciplines. All modules will be given in a blended form, i.e. partly face-to-face (e.g. lectures) and partly online (e.g. video’s, web lectures, online documents).

This program is specially developed for students from Leiden University, Delft University of Technology and Erasmus University Rotterdam. The purpose of this minor programme is to educate professionals from different fields such social, economic, environmental engineering and political science on the importance of the different aspects in the use of Big, Open and Linked Data within creating the smart and shared city.

A point of attention regarding the different students and the diversity in study background, as this means that students will most likely have different entry levels. This is considered while designing the programme and the prerequisites to participate. By blending education and using online and offline tools, teachers can check the levels of knowledge of the students upon entry of the course and eventually supply them with relevant background materials to get up to speed.

For this minor there is a balance between traditional and innovative learning methods. The modules are designed in a blended learning form, meaning lectures will make use of face-to-face lectures, online documents and articles, and video’s/online lectures. Reading materials include policy papers, reports, articles and books. We will use Canvas as the electronic teaching environment.


Module 1: Introduction to the smart city

  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University
  • Content: In this first module the students will be introduced to the core ideas of the smart city and technologies. The module will cover various smart city concepts and address the basic digital and data technologies (key enabling technologies) that constitute smart cities. There will also be ample attention for the legal, ethical, political and social dilemmas in smart cities. 
    • Week 1    What is a smart city and which economic and social actors make it?
    • Week 2    How is the smart city connected to economic and political power? 
    • Week 3    Which democratic and ethical control is needed in and for the smart city?
  • Teaching method(s): reading, guest lecture, field trip and video.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)     
Module 2: Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city
  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University
  • Content: Many of the smart city projects are framed as producing solutions to large challenges in cities, regarding, among others, the environment, mobility, security and safety. In this module we approach the smart city from the perspective of the citizen and the social fabric in the city. Who benefits from smart city developments, whose interests are served? Which groups miss out, and how is everyday life in streets, stores, pubs and clubs affected?
    • Week 1    How do citizens participate in urban development, planning, governance and local democracy?
    • Week 2    How do digitization and data play a role in how citizens participate in urban
      development, planning, governance and democracy?
    • Week 3    How can we apply data and empowerment-examples and theory to support citizens to participate in urban development, planning, governance and democracy?
  • Teaching method(s): online reading, documentary, response lecture, research presentation and living lab.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)
Module 3: Governing the smart city
  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Faculty Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University
  • Content: Data and digital technologies offer both great potential for cities and great risks. In this module we discuss the effects of platform capital in cities, in the form of, among others, AirBnB and Uber. We explore the various responses from banning (as in Barcelona) to regulating (as in Amsterdam) and free entry (as in many other cities in the world). We will show the political-economic interests of these platforms and discuss the European regulations and attempts at curtailing them. We also zoom in on the way cities themselves explore the use of digital and data technologies and which models of regulation and participation they have developed. The module will have a strong public input from public administration perspectives and discuss how different governance ideologies (new public management vs new public service) produce different understandings of what a smart city should achieve. 
  • Learning objectives:
    • Understand the playing field of smart cities with the use of conceptual models;
    • Understand the consequences of the complexity of smart city playing fields for the
    governing of the smart city;
    • Design instruments/strategies for interactive governance of the smart city.
  • Teaching method(s): reading, online lecture, guest lecture, online library / toolkit and groupwork.
  • Teaching materials: Scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)  

Overview content per week:

Week 1-3    Introduction to the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 4-6    Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 7-9    Governing the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 10     Module 1, 2 and 3 - Resit
                   

How do you get your grade for the minor?

Each module has a number of graded assignments. You will get specific instructions in each module.
The grade for each modules is based on a bespoke calculation that may differ per module.
All assignments will be handed in through Canvas, under heading ‘Assignment’.
You need to pass every module, the average of three modules is your final grade

Module 1:

  • You have various mandatory activities and three graded assignments, one per week;
  • All mandatory activities have to be finished and handed in before the set deadline;
  • Each graded assignment counts for 33%.

Module 2:
  • Complete 3 group assignments (pass/fail);
  • 1 individual Assignment (for a grade).

Module 3:
  • An individual final paper based on weekly journal entries;
  • A group presentation book on a multistakeholder governance challenge;
  • An individual reflection on the groupwork;
  • A group video showcasing the presentation book.

No final marks are given between 5.0 and 6.0 and the following rounding rules are used: a 5.5 or higher is rounded to 6.0 and a 5.49 or lower is rounded to 5.0; Outside the 5.0 - 6.0 range, final marks are expressed as a number with one decimal.

Students need to pass each module with a grade of at least 5.5 (there is no compensation) in order to complete the minor.
Each module will have its own grade composition which will be described in the syllabus for the minor.

Essays with corrections and feedback will be returned to the students. There will be a feedback moment after each of the assignments.
The lecturer provides written or oral feedback on the individual assignment and the group assignment.

Leerdoelen For students completing this minor, there are generic competences and specific competences to be acquired. The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants. 

Module 1. Introduction to the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Explain the origins and functions of the smart city concept;
•                 Identify enabling technologies and methodologies of the smart city;
•                 Identify (recognize) and compare the different conceptions of the smart city concept;
•                 Position him/herself in the smart city debate, argue for that position and reflect on that position.

Module 2. Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Understand the digital & social division in society;
•                 Explain how citizens can take role in city dynamics;
•                 Evaluate tools that mobilize groups of citizens.

Module 3. Governing the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Understand the playing field of smart cities with the use of conceptual models;
•                 Understand the consequences of the complexity of smart city playing fields for the governing of the smart city;
•                 Design instruments/strategies for interactive governance of the smart city.

course_title: Smart and Shared Cities: The world is changing and becoming "smart", but how do we ensure it is “SHARED”?
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['A Psyllidis', 'AJ Klievink', 'dr. JM Engelbert', 'E Eumann', 'L Meilof', 'MJ Slotboom, MSc', 'prof.dr. EA van Zoonen', 'prof.dr. JR Ortt', 'VM Butot, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

The minor SMART and SHARED Cities is a 15 EC and 30 EC minor programme combined. The student should choose the course load when registering for the minor. This is a full-time minor program – and participating in lectures and activities is mandatory.  

This minor is built on a combination of data, urban, political and social sciences. This multidisciplinary minor is open to all students who are interested in the development of smart and shared cities. The minor is offered in English and accessible for both national and international students. The format and modules include classic and innovative teaching methods, i.e. lectures and seminars, field trips, case-based group assignments, video production, blogging and logbooks and the integration of academia and practice. If necessary – all classes and activities will be online.

The program is characterized by a multi-disciplinary approach, which allows students to take different perspectives and understand the complexity of smart city life. The program intends to stimulate a reflective mindset, focusing on the interrelation of problems and responsible innovation. The learning goals concern knowledge, attitude and skills which in combination need to equip students with a critical mindset that enables them to work towards public needs and interests in smart cities.

Knowledge: Upon completion of the minor, the student will know what a smart city is and how the associated definitions and discourses produce a particular technological and data practice in which particular concerns and interests take privilege over others. S/he will also understand the kind of participatory spaces that are created by and for citizens, and the competing governance models that smart cities advocate. The student will also have a basic insight in the various data and analytics that are relevant to the development of smart cities.

Attitude: Students will develop a critical but constructive attitude towards different views and opinions about the smart city. They will value the contrasting perspectives of private and public stakeholders and will be able to adapt to and explain different views, suggest different solutions and prioritize advices based on different cases with different values. The core ethos of the minor concerns, however, public values in the smart cities, which are encapsulated in the SHARED principles and ethics that underlie various Dutch digital agendas and have been adopted by the VSNU.

Skills: Upon completion of the minor, students will be able to recognize particular interests and values in smart city discourse and practice; they will be able to choose appropriate data for specific urban challenges (critical thinking and information literacy); they will be able to work in multidisciplinary and trans-sectoral teams and adapt to particular team requirements and collaborative styles (collaboration and communication). For the 30 EC minor, an additional set of skills (e.g. Initiative and technology literacy) will be acquired through internships and projects in the research labs.


Special aspects

Since this is a Leiden-Delft-Erasmus minor, the location of where education is offered difference per module. The minor takes place at Erasmus University, TU Delft and Leiden University. This minor is a full-time programme. Therefore it is not possible to combine this minor program with other extra-curricular activities.

It is possible for Erasmus students to complete the minor for 15 EC (modules 1, 2 and 3). EUR students can also choose to complete the minor as a whole for 30 EC. The extra 15 EC is extra-curricular. To include the extra 15 EC in your Bachelor program, EUR students need to ask permission from their Examination Board.

Deficiencies of students’ knowledge will be tackled at the beginning of each module. Each module will begin with an online quiz that will provide the student with a list of material for self-study to align the knowledge base of students from the various disciplines. All modules will be given in a blended form, i.e. partly face-to-face (e.g. lectures) and partly online (e.g. video’s, web lectures, online documents).

This program is specially developed for students from Leiden University, Delft University of Technology and Erasmus University Rotterdam. The purpose of this minor programme is to educate professionals from different fields such social, economic, environmental engineering and political science on the importance of the different aspects in the use of Big, Open and Linked Data within creating the smart and shared city.

A point of attention regarding the different students and the diversity in study background, as this means that students will most likely have different entry levels. This is considered while designing the programme and the prerequisites to participate. By blending education and using online and offline tools, teachers can check the levels of knowledge of the students upon entry of the course and eventually supply them with relevant background materials to get up to speed.

For this minor there is a balance between traditional and innovative learning methods. The modules are designed in a blended learning form, meaning lectures will make use of face-to-face lectures, online documents and articles, and video’s/online lectures. Reading materials include policy papers, reports, articles and books. We will use Canvas as the electronic teaching environment.


Module 1: Introduction to the smart city

  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University
  • Content: In this first module the students will be introduced to the core ideas of the smart city and technologies. The module will cover various smart city concepts and address the basic digital and data technologies (key enabling technologies) that constitute smart cities. There will also be ample attention for the legal, ethical, political and social dilemmas in smart cities. 
    •  Week 1    What is a smart city and which economic and social actors make it?
    • Week 2    How is the smart city connected to economic and political power? 
    • Week 3    Which democratic and ethical control is needed in and for the smart city?
  • Teaching method(s): reading, guest lecture, field trip and video.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)     
Module 2: Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city
  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University
  • Content: Many of the smart city projects are framed as producing solutions to large challenges in cities, regarding, among others, the environment, mobility, security and safety. In this module we approach the smart city from the perspective of the citizen and the social fabric in the city. Who benefits from smart city developments, whose interests are served? Which groups miss out, and how is everyday life in streets, stores, pubs and clubs affected?
    • Week 1    How do citizens participate in urban development, planning, governance and local democracy?
    • Week 2    How do digitization and data play a role in how citizens participate in urban
      development, planning, governance and democracy?
    • Week 3    How can we apply data and empowerment-examples and theory to support citizens to participate in urban development, planning, governance and democracy?
  • Teaching method(s): online reading, documentary, response lecture, research presentation and living lab.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)

  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Faculty Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University

    governing of the smart city;
    • Design instruments/strategies for interactive governance of the smart city.
  • Teaching method(s): reading, online lecture, guest lecture, online library / toolkit and groupwork.
  • Teaching materials: Scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)  

Module 4: Urban Data Science

  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: TU Delft Faculty of Industrial Design Engineering, Delft University of Technology
  • Content: Urban Data Science is an evolving field that merges concepts, methods, and tools from computer science, spatial statistics, quantitative geography, and urban planning. These methods and tools deal with accessing, collecting, processing, exploring, visualizing, and analyzing data about cities, in which the locational component plays a prominent role. The learning goal of the UDS course, in particular, is to introduce students to the variety of new forms of urban data sources (e.g. sensors, Internet of Things devices, social media, Web portals, mobile phones etc.) used in smart city planning and governance, and to enable students to address urban challenges from a data-driven perspective. More specifically, in the context of the UDS course, students will be acquainted with and gain insight into the various urban data sources (conventional and novel), as well as familiarize themselves with the corresponding computational methods, analytical techniques, and tools that help make sense of the data.
  • Teaching method(s): readings, online tutorial, groupwork and field trip.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 6 per week (hours may differ) 

Module 5: Research participation and projects

  • 10 EC
  • Faculty: Faculty of Architecture and the Built Environment, Delft University of Technology, Faculty Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University, Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University.
  • Content: This module (10 EC credits, 280 hours of study) aims to put the theoretical and practical knowledge students have accumulated in the previous modules into practice. The theoretical subject matter is often offered via projects: project-based working.
    Groups of three to four students will be working together on an assignment during a period of eight weeks. The groups will be made by the minor and module coordinator to optimize the division of studies and disciplines amongst project groups. In some cases, and only in consultation with the course coordinator may projects be done individually. The assessment criteria will be the same for either individual or group projects. Each research assignment is provided by a commissioner; a researcher or organization affiliated with BOLD Cities. The project list is communicated on Canvas.
    Each group is to assume the role of academic consultants and as such, solve the problem for the commissioner based on designing and carrying out scientific research. The students themselves are responsible for delivering the requested end-product at the agreed deadline. Within the groups, the various tasks are to be decided and divided: who will do what and within which period of time? The minor and module coordinator will make sure that the students are given enough support in this process. The project commissioners provide mandatory literature and provide guidance along the way.
  • Teaching method(s): groupwork, lectures, workshop and literature.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 6 per week (hours may differ) 


Overview content per week

Week 1-3      Introduction to the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 4-6      Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 7-9      Governing the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 10       Module 1, 2 and 3 - Resit
                     Research participation and practice - Research project market: meeting commissioners and choosing a research project
Week 11-15  Urban Data Science - Classes on Monday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
                     Research participation and projects - Classes on Wednesday
Week 16-20  Research participation and projects - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday, Thursday.      

How do you get your grade for the minor?

Each module has a number of graded assignments. You will get specific instructions in each module.
The grade for each modules is based on a bespoke calculation that may differ per module.
All assignments will be handed in through Canvas, under heading ‘Assignment’.
You need to pass every module, the average of five modules is your final grade

Module 1:

  • You have various mandatory activities and three graded assignments, one per week;
  • All mandatory activities have to be finished and handed in before the set deadline;
  • Each graded assignment counts for 33%.
Module 2:
  • Complete 3 group assignments (pass/fail);
  • 1 individual Assignment (for a grade).
Module 3:
  • An individual final paper based on weekly journal entries;
  • A group presentation book on a multistakeholder governance challenge;
  • An individual reflection on the groupwork;
  • A group video showcasing the presentation book.
Module 4:
  • Written group report;
  • Two group presentations (mid-term and final) ;
  • Individual assignment.
Module 5:
  • Formulation of a research/project plan;
  • Academic paper;
  • Final presentation (academic transfer).

No final marks are given between 5.0 and 6.0 and the following rounding rules are used: a 5.5 or higher is rounded to 6.0 and a 5.49 or lower is rounded to 5.0; Outside the 5.0 - 6.0 range, final marks are expressed as a number with one decimal.

Students need to pass each module with a grade of at least 5.5 (there is no compensation) in order to complete the minor.
Each module will have its own grade composition which will be described in the syllabus for the minor.

Essays with corrections and feedback will be returned to the students. There will be a feedback moment after each of the assignments.
The lecturer provides written or oral feedback on the individual assignment and the group assignment.

Leerdoelen For students completing this minor, there are generic competences and specific competences to be acquired. The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants. After completing block B (30 EC programme), students will have acquired knowledge about urban data science, its advantages and limitations and how it could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants. The knowledge that students will acquire in these modules will be applied in a case project, where theory is applied in practice by means of a research project.

Module 1. Introduction to the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Explain the origins and functions of the smart city concept;
•                 Identify enabling technologies and methodologies of the smart city;
•                 Identify (recognize) and compare the different conceptions of the smart city concept;
•                 Position him/herself in the smart city debate, argue for that position and reflect on that position.

Module 2. Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Understand the digital & social division in society;
•                 Explain how citizens can take role in city dynamics;
•                 Evaluate tools that mobilize groups of citizens.

Module 3. Governing the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Understand the playing field of smart cities with the use of conceptual models;
•                 Understand the consequences of the complexity of smart city playing fields for the governing of the smart city;
•                 Design instruments/strategies for interactive governance of the smart city.

Module 4. Urban Data Science (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Identify new sources of spatiotemporal urban data, and ways to collect them;
•                 Compare different types of urban data based on their characteristics;
•                 Select appropriate sources of urban data to address problems of smart cities, relating to a range of application domains (e.g. mobility, health, housing etc.);
•                 Explain and discuss applications of new forms of urban data in cities, as well as concepts and methods of spatial data analysis and visualization;
•                 Explain the risks, limitations, and ethical implications relating to the use of different (traditional and novel) urban data sources;
•                 Develop a data-driven strategy for smart cities;
•                 Discuss the opportunities, limitations, and ethical implications of the data-driven strategy for  smart cities, as well as potential ways to resolve them.

Module 5. Research participation and projects (10 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Developing an understanding of professional and ethical responsibility;
•                 Identifying the research problem;
•                 Performing a literature review and writing a theoretical/conceptual framework;
•                 Researching the design or approach to the problem;
•                 Collecting and/or analysing data and/or designing and validating the design;
•                 Drawing conclusions and giving recommendations;
•                 Communicating  the  results  of  the  research  to  a  wider  public  through  for  an  appropriate medium (e.g., film, podcast, photography, etc.).

college: Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS)
text:
Inhoud SMART cities use technology in combination with smart governance and smart people to better manage and develop cities. If well governed, the technologies are expected to lead to gains for citizens. The use of smart technologies is growing in popularity, with many governments jumping on the bandwagon to become a “Smart City’. The use of technology is also of great interest to the private sector, who sees the opportunity to innovate and to have access to lucrative business opportunities. Creating smart city policies is however difficult as the concept of smartness is diffuse and contested. What is smart in Rotterdam, may not be smart in other urban contexts. In addition, government organisations may lack the required capabilities and resources to use technologies in an integrated, safe and inclusive manner. Authors argue that smart cities as a neo-liberal city brand may favour smart citizens who are tech-savvy and entrepreneurial, while possibly excluding the elderly, low educated and low income. They do not necessarily lead to sustainability. Smart cities can also lead to further pollution, exclusion and disempowerment.

However, smart cities can also be empowering, inclusive and sustainable. Urban actors may find smart solutions to local problems, enabled by (digital) technologies available in cities. Examples are the use of apps to inform communities of jobs, disasters, subsidies or safety risks. Smart technologies can improve social capital and enable participation in decision making. However, these inclusive and smart innovations tend to be place and time specific.

This course therefore raises the questions: what sustainability and inclusiveness challenges do smart cities face?; how we can govern smart cities in such a way that they become more sustainable and inclusive?
  Leerdoelen After the module, participants should be able to:
  1. Critically reflect on the different concepts underpinning Smart Cities, Inclusive Smart Cities and Sustainable Smart Cities;
  2. Appreciate the trends in and impacts of smart technologies on urban management and development;
  3. Assess different governance and project responses and their relevance for the development of smart, inclusive and sustainable cities.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['A Bosdijk, MSc', 'dr. M Vollmann', 'dr. MD Hilverda', 'dr. MPB van den Broek', 'dr. RA Scheepers', 'PI Crompvoets, MSc', 'prof.dr. AP Nieboer', 'prof.dr. PHM van Baal', 'S Lousberg, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
Wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte en gezondheid vormt de basis van de medische praktijk in onze westerse samenlevingen. Deze kennis over ziekte is, met het huidige biomedische model als uitgangspunt, van betrekkelijk recente datum: het eind van de 19e eeuw. In dit vak bestuderen studenten deze biomedische kennis, onder meer aan de hand van een aantal in Nederland veel voorkomende gezondheidsproblemen. Aan de hand hiervan zal tegelijkertijd duidelijk worden dat de huidige wetenschappelijke kennis het resultaat is van sociale en culturele factoren. Kennis is dan ook veelal historisch bepaald. Door middel van deze meer (medisch) sociologische visie krijgen studenten inzicht in de "constructivistische" zienswijze op wetenschappelijke kennis over gezondheid en ziekte.
Gezondheidsproblemen komen niet in dezelfde mate voor in verschillende bevolkingsgroepen. Zo zijn er verschillen naar geslacht en leeftijd, maar ook naar sociaaleconomische positie en etnische herkomst. Om dit te bestuderen is demografische en epidemiologische basiskennis nodig om gezondheidsproblemen en deze relevante factoren te meten en om de onderlinge relaties vast te stellen.
 
Bovendien worden basale modellen ter verklaring van dergelijke verschillen in gezondheid geïntroduceerd, evenals modellen ter verklaring van verschillen in het omgaan met ziekte (gezondheidspsychologie) en in het zoeken van hulp. Een belangrijke factor hierbij zijn de zogenaamde "lekenopvattingen" van ziekte en gezondheid. Immers, de wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte wordt ook vandaag niet door alle bevolkingsgroepen in dezelfde mate gedeeld. Inzicht in deze "lekenopvattingen" is belangrijk vanwege de invloed op de omgang met ziekte en het zorggebruik, waaronder bijvoorbeeld de therapietrouw.
 
Uit voorgaande beschrijving wordt duidelijk dat de sociaal medische wetenschappen bestaan uit verschillende disciplines. Studenten maken daarom kennis met de biomedische geneeskunde, (medische) sociologie, demografie, epidemiologie en gezondheidspsychologie.
De beoogde doelstellingen worden bijgebracht aan de hand van hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. In de hoorcolleges worden de basisconcepten, -modellen en relevante theorieën toegelicht. In de werkgroepen worden deze inzichten toegepast aan de hand van een aantal geselecteerde gezondheidsproblemen. Daarbij wordt gekozen voor voorbeelden van uiteenlopende aard: infectieziekten, chronische gezondheidsproblemen en psychische problematiek.
 
Leerdoelen De student kan na het volgen van deze cursus…
 
  1. de disciplines binnen Sociaal Medische Wetenschappen (SMW) –biomedische geneeskunde, epidemiologie, demografie, (medische) sociologie en gezondheidspsychologie – in eigen woorden omschrijven
  2. objectieve en subjectieve gezondheidsmaten van gezondheidsverschillen in eigen woorden omschrijven
  3. uitleggen wat primaire, secundaire en tertiaire preventie is
  4. modellen van arts-patiënt relaties (consensusmodel, conflictmodel, onderhandelingsmodel en contractmodel) toepassen op een casus
  5. de ervaring van ziekte verklaren aan de hand van gezondheidspsychologische theorieën (het stress-copingmodel en het common-sense model)
  6. gezondheidsgedrag verklaren op basis van het HAPA-model en het Health Belief model
  7. uitleggen hoe de betekenis van ziekte en gezondheid onderhevig is aan tijd en cultuur
  8. de verschillende sociologische theorieën van ziekte en gezondheid (functionalisme, symbolisch interactionisme, marxisme, sociaal constructivisme en de labelling theorie) uitleggen

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['A Bosdijk, MSc', 'dr. M Vollmann', 'dr. RA Scheepers', 'PI Crompvoets, MSc', 'prof.dr. AP Nieboer', 'prof.dr. PHM van Baal']

Bovendien worden basale modellen ter verklaring van dergelijke verschillen in gezondheid geïntroduceerd, evenals modellen ter verklaring van verschillen in het omgaan met ziekte (gezondheidspsychologie) en in het zoeken van hulp. Een belangrijke factor hierbij zijn de zogenaamde "lekenopvattingen" van ziekte en gezondheid. Immers, de wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte wordt ook vandaag niet door alle bevolkingsgroepen in dezelfde mate gedeeld. Inzicht in deze "lekenopvattingen" is belangrijk vanwege de invloed op de omgang met ziekte en het zorggebruik, waaronder bijvoorbeeld de therapietrouw.
 
Uit voorgaande beschrijving wordt duidelijk dat de sociaal medische wetenschappen bestaan uit verschillende disciplines. Studenten maken daarom kennis met de biomedische geneeskunde, (medische) sociologie, demografie, epidemiologie en gezondheidspsychologie.
De beoogde doelstellingen worden bijgebracht aan de hand van hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. In de hoorcolleges worden de basisconcepten, -modellen en relevante theorieën toegelicht. In de werkgroepen worden deze inzichten toegepast aan de hand van een aantal geselecteerde gezondheidsproblemen. Daarbij wordt gekozen voor voorbeelden van uiteenlopende aard: infectieziekten, chronische gezondheidsproblemen en psychische problematiek.
 
Leerdoelen De student kan na het volgen van deze cursus…
 
  1. de disciplines binnen Sociaal Medische Wetenschappen (SMW) –biomedische geneeskunde, epidemiologie, demografie, (medische) sociologie en gezondheidspsychologie – in eigen woorden omschrijven
  2. objectieve en subjectieve gezondheidsmaten van gezondheidsverschillen in eigen woorden omschrijven
  3. uitleggen wat primaire, secundaire en tertiaire preventie is
  4. modellen van arts-patiënt relaties (consensusmodel, conflictmodel, onderhandelingsmodel en contractmodel) toepassen op een casus
  5. de ervaring van ziekte verklaren aan de hand van gezondheidspsychologische theorieën (het stress-copingmodel en het common-sense model)
  6. gezondheidsgedrag verklaren op basis van het HAPA-model en het Health Belief model
  7. uitleggen hoe de betekenis van ziekte en gezondheid onderhevig is aan tijd en cultuur
  8. de verschillende sociologische theorieën van ziekte en gezondheid (functionalisme, symbolisch interactionisme, marxisme, sociaal constructivisme en de labelling theorie) uitleggen

course_title: Sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek in de praktijk
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Deze cursus introduceert diverse sociale wetenschapsonderzoeken perspectieven en methodologieën. Door deze cursus wordt jouw begrip van filosofische, theoretische en ethische kwesties die van belang zijn voor het doen van onderzoek verbreed, en krijg je meer inzicht in de relatie tussen theorie en onderzoek in de praktijk.
 
Om meer inzicht in het onderzoeksproces te krijgen—van idee tot onderzoeksdesign tot de productie van nieuwe kennis— volgt de cursus twee afzonderlijke, doch aan elkaar verbonden, paden. Het eerste pad betreft het aanleren van methoden van data verzamelen, data analyse en de interpretatie van de analyses. Het tweede pad bestaat uit het tonen van voorbeelden van onderzoek te tonen die gebruik maken van: kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve methoden, innovatieve dataverzamelings- en analysetechnieken, ‘natural experiements’, en creatieve vergelijkingen van verschillende hypotheses.
 
Deze cursus bestrijkt algemene onderwerpen zoals: wetenschappelijke integriteit, epistemologie, ethiek, ‘mixed’ methoden en ‘big data.’ Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een reeks (zogenaamde) kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve onderzoeksmethoden.
Daarnaast geeft deze cursus je een methodologische basis voor de verdere ontwikkeling van je methodologische gereedschapskist en draagt de cursus bij aan de ontwikkeling en het management van je eigen onderzoeksprojecten (in het bijzonder je masterscriptie). De geleerde onderzoeksvaardigheden zijn niet alleen binnen, maar ook buiten de wetenschap (zowel in de publieke als private sector) van belang voor een socioloog.
  Leerdoelen Na de voltooiing van deze cursus kun je:
 
  • De basale wetenschapsfilosofische componenten van diverse methodologieën in de sociale wetenschappen uitleggen (bijv. naturalisme, constructivisme).
  • De principes van ethiek, privacy en wetenschappelijke integriteit in sociaal onderzoek uitleggen en toepassen;
  • Beantwoordbare sociaalwetenschappelijke onderzoeksvragen formuleren, alsmede aangeven welke data en analyses het beste bij die vragen aansluiten;
  • De principes van ‘sampling’ uitleggen;
  • Verslagen van empirisch sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek evalueren en bepalen in hoeverre zij antwoorden bieden op de gestelde onderzoeksvragen;
  • De belangrijkste benaderingen in kwalitatieve dataverzameling begrijpen (interviewen, observatie, documenten en combinaties daarvan (bijv. etnografisch onderzoek));
  • De belangrijkste procedures voor de analyse van kwalitatieve data en interpretatie van resultaten begrijpen en beschrijven (coderen, contentanalyse, discours analyse en grounded theory);
  • De belangrijkste benaderingen in kwantitatieve dataverzameling begrijpen (enquêtes, experimenten en het gebruik van secundaire kwantitatieve data);
  • Verschillende technieken voor de analyse van kwantitatieve data en interpretatie van resultaten begrijpen en beschrijven (verschillende typen regressieanalyses);
  • De rol van mixed methods en triangulatie in sociologisch onderzoek begrijpen en beschrijven;
  • De belangrijkste benaderingen in evaluatieonderzoek begrijpen en beschrijven (random control trials, quasi-experimentele designs, realistic evaluation).

course_title: Social Choice Theory and Political Representation
text:
Inhoud

When multiple criteria (such as the preferences of different voters) give rise to different orderings of some set of alternatives (such as candidates running for election), the following question arises: how should one aggregate the different orderings into a single ``taking-all-criteria-into-account” ordering of the alternatives? That question is the central question of Social Choice Theory. Answers to the question crucially depend on the type of information that may be used in the aggregation. In the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, only ordinal information is allowed. In the traditional framework, answers to the central question are constrained by impossibility results such as Arrow’s theorem, which, very roughly, state that no adequate aggregation method exists. In the literature, various ways to escape these impossibility results have been proposed that all involve, in one way or the other, leaving Social Choice Theory’s traditional framework.
An attempt to aggregate individual preferences into “the societal preference” is often described as an attempt to capture “the will of the people”. This illustrates that the (impossibility) results of Social Choice Theory are important for our thinking about representative democracy and, more generally, political representation.
William Riker (1982) was the first to discuss the upshot of SCT’s results for our understanding of democracy. Riker distinguishes between two different conceptions of democracy: Populism and Liberalism. Basically, Riker argued that SCT’s results testify that Populism is an incoherent conception of democracy. Although SCT’s results have no such bearing on Liberalism, the latter is a very minimal conception of democracy-basically, the possibility for the people to replace the powers that be. Riker;s account of the relation between SCT, voting an democracy has elicited various critical responses in the literature which will be traced in the course. Thus, this course is an introduction to Social Choice Theory and a discussion of the relevance of its results for voting systems, democracy and political representation

Leerdoelen
 
1. Course goals 2.Percentage 3. Intended learning outcomes 4.Percentage
1. The student can name the basic assumptions of the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, is able to give definitions of its central notions (e.g. preference ordering, preference profile, social ordering, social welfare function) and can explain the relevance of Social Choice Theory for voting theory.


10%		 To have thorough insight into the cohesion of a number of developments in the history of thought, as well as in analytic and continental philosophy.


3.33%
    To be able to think through and interpret philosophical problems in their complexity

 
3.33%
    To be able to place the knowledge gained in a broader, multidisciplinary context 3.33%
2. The student is familiar with various often-used Social Welfare Functions (e.g. plurality rule, majority rule, Borda rule) and is able to apply these functions (to compute e.g. the outcome of elections).

5%		 To be receptive of societal relevance of philosophical questions, and to be prepared to interpret the studied literature in that light (keeping an eye on the societal and ethical responsibility attached to this).

 

2.5%
 
    To be able to place the knowledge gained in a broader, multidisciplinary context 2.5%
3.  The student is familiar with various properties (e.g. monotonicity, IIA, Pareto, strategic manipulability) for SWFs, is able to discuss the desirability of these properties in a voting / policy context and is able to explain how often-used SWFs fare with respect to these properties.

15%		 To develop a critical academic attitude in the area of contemporary philosophy (where the highest norms of philosophical rigor and creativity are taken into account).


 

10%
 
    To be receptive of societal relevance of philosophical questions, and to be prepared to interpret the studied literature in that light (keeping an eye on the societal and ethical responsibility attached to this).
5%
4. The student is able to explain which properties for SWFs are mutually incompatible, is familiar with Arrow’s Impossibility Theorem and Sen’s Impossibility Theorem and is able to comment on the significance of these impossibility theorems in a in a voting / policy context.
15%		 To have deep knowledge in the area of the chosen specialisation (track).
 
          10%
 
    To be prepared to refrain from untimely ‘solutions’ and to be willing to keep asking questions, also in ‘unorthodox directions’
5%
5. The student is able to explain how, by giving up certain features of the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory (e.g. universal domain or transitivity of social orderings), the impossibility theorems can be escaped.

20%		  To be prepared to refrain from untimely ‘solutions’ and to be willing to keep asking questions, also in ‘unorthodox directions.

10%
    To have deep knowledge in the area of the chosen specialisation (track).
 
10%
6. The student is familiar with the Balinski-Laraki framework for Social Choice Theory, able to give definitions of its central notions (e.g. grade profile, merit profile, majority judgement) and able to critically compare the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory with the Balinski-Laraki framework.

10%		 To be prepared to refrain from untimely ‘solutions’ and to be willing to keep asking questions, also in ‘unorthodox directions’.
 

5%
    To have deep knowledge in the area of the chosen specialisation (track).
 
5%
    To be receptive of societal relevance of philosophical questions, and to be prepared to interpret the studied literature in that light (keeping an eye on the societal and ethical responsibility attached to this).
5%

 
7. The student is able to understand and engage with recent philosophical debates on the relation between SCT, representative democracy and political representation. 25% To be receptive of societal relevance of philosophical questions, and to be prepared to interpret the studied literature in that light (keeping an eye on the societal and ethical responsibility attached to this). 20%

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. P Versari', 'SF Jellema, MSc', 'SM Murell Lema']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Social entrepreneurship is an emerging field of academic study and real-world practice. At its core, social entrepreneurship pertains the combination of market-based and nonprofit approaches to solve social issues, a feat social entrepreneurs achieve by combining the knowledge and skills used in traditional business with a passionate commitment to having a meaningful and sustainable social impact. By combining insights from the academic literature with real cases and scenarios, the course will introduce students to both theory and practice of social entrepreneurship. 

Each week, the course will focus on one important aspect or theme of social entrepreneurship, through two types of lectures: a “theoretical” lecture and a “workshop”. 

  • “Theoretical” lectures will compose the first appointment of each one of the six weeks of the course. These lectures will take the form of traditional frontal lectures where the lecturer will cover the material related to the week’s topic. 
  •  “Workshop” lectures will instead compose the second appointment of each week and will focus on interweaving the theoretical content covered in previous lectures with real case scenarios and practical exercises. Such lectures will be interactive in nature, with in-class exercises (both individual and in groups), case-studies, and contributions from guest practitioners. 

The six weeks of the course will cover the following topics:

  • Week 1. Social Entrepreneurship: definition and characteristics 
  • Week 2. Social entrepreneurs and opportunities recognition 
  • Week 3. Hybrid business models for social enterprises 
  • Week 4. Scaling impact in social entrepreneurship 
  • Week 5. Evaluating social impact
  • Week 6. Group projects final presentations 
Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The goal of the course is to expose students to the field of Social Entrepreneurship. At the end of the course students will be able to: 
  1. Recognize the different types of social entrepreneurial action and its characteristics.  
  2. Examine the opportunities opened by social entrepreneurship in comparison to normal entrepreneurship. 
  3. Evaluate the typical challenges faced by social enterprises. 
  4. Design social entrepreneurial models coherently combining commercial and social value creation.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud What are dimensions of inequality? How unequal are societies in which we live? Is it getting better or worse? What factors determine these trends? In this course, students will develop the tools necessary to critically evaluate such questions. Students gain an overview in the many dimensions of inequality in contemporary societies (e.g. economic, ethnic, gender, spatial). We will look both within societies and across societies to develop an understanding of how inequality manifests in local and international contexts. Special attention is given to the mechanism through which these inequalities are produced and reproduced in social institutions like school, neighborhood and workplace. Furthermore, we will focus on the consequences of social inequalities in terms of individuals’ wellbeing and health. Students will learn how researchers study these processes in national and international contexts. They will learn about the challenges facing scholarship, and participate in key debates that animate contemporary inequalities research.
  Leerdoelen

After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
 
1. Explore central concepts through which sociologists investigate inequality.
2. Develop a descriptive and analytical understanding of how class, gender, ethnicity and other dimensions of inequality impact interactions, institutional placements, choices, and social policy in contemporary societies.
3. Become familiar with key debates that animate contemporary research on inequality.
4. Consider and critique competing explanations for social stratification and social mobility.
5. Learn about how these concepts are applied in quantitative, qualitative and mixed-methods empirical research.
 
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skill:

1. Be able to write an academic paper on patterns, causes and consequences of social inequalities.

course_title: Social Media Data Analytics for Business
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: 
dr. C.S. Bos (VU) and dr. I.D. Lindner (VU)

 
Course content:
Social media data analysis is indispensable for businesses of all sizes. Social media provide a platform for customers to share reviews of products, they indicate directions in which the market develops and represent a powerful tool for marketing purposes. This course delves, handson, into the wealth of social media data which is readily available, and the manners in which this data can be collected, analyzed, and put to good use for business strategies and research. For this purpose, the course applies the advances in tools available, covering the use of sentiment analysis, basic machine learning and artificial intelligence for extracting the information in social media posts.
Leerdoelen After this course, students will be able to
1. Collect data from social media services such as Twitter and YouTube using Application Programming Interfaces (API’s) and basic web scrapers.
2. Clean, visualize and analyze data from various social media services.
3. Analyze textual comments for sentiments expressed in them.
4. Understand the theory of social media communication networks.
5. Identify trends for business strategies and set up models for research and development purposes.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course offers a combination of theory and practice designed to prepare students for entry level jobs in social media marketing.  We discuss relevant theoretical knowledge about marketing communication, but we also strive to teach you the practical skills which are essential for a career in social media marketing.
In this course, you are invited to challenge the mainstream concepts of marketing communication from a cultural and social perspective. We analyse the strategies that companies employ online in various industries (e.g., fashion, technology, cosmetics) and research new trends such as sustainability, diversity, and brand activism. We also look at narrative aspects of social media advertising such as originality, creativity and storytelling.
The main goal of the course is to meld essential theory with practical application and cover core skills such as strategic planning for social media applications, branding, business communications, and harnessing social media data to yield consumer insights. We achieve this goal through case studies, creative brainstorming, research activities, teamwork and the contribution of social media marketing experts from Adidas, American Express, Aperol/Campari, Unilever, and VanMoof.

This course was previously called "Social Media Strategies in Business Communication" but it is still the same course. If you already took CM2274 or CM2074 under the old name, please note that you cannot take this course. Leerdoelen Students gain knowledge and understanding of:
  • ·The cultural and social implications for both marketers and consumers;
  • ·The elements of social identity, how individuals build their social identities, and why identities are relevant to marketers;
  • ·How some of the world’s leading brands have successfully applied content and digital media into their strategies;
 
Students have developed the skills to:
  • ·Focus on emerging trends in digital culture, consumer behavior, and data analytics;
  • ·Analyze and apply marketing strategies for social media;
  • ·Use storytelling in social media advertising;

  • Use storytelling in social media advertising;
  • Create short videos for social media.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Digitization, convergence and connectivity have enabled organizations in the cultural industries to boost the social aspect of their audience relations; users are not only just recipients of media content, but can participate and create value themselves. This participative culture impacts the way organizations in the creative industries function. But how exactly? The possibilities are endless – audiences can be brand ambassadors and aid in the viral marketing of their cultural products. They can be invited for co-creation projects through social media. They are enabled to take up distribution roles in peer-to-peer networks, create content, comment, review, publish, share, download, upload, remix and communicate by means of social networks such as Instagram, Snapchat, YouTube, Twitter or Facebook. Social media also pose challenges for organizations in the creative industries: What if your audience is not engaged? What are the motivations for people to become actively involved? What if your creative product causes a strong reaction on social media? Or how should you tell your story online?

In this research workshop, the use of social media in the creative industries will be our research domain. You are free to choose your own perspective – the producer side or the user side. By means of qualitative research methods, you will explore and analyze a self-chosen topic in more depth. You will design and execute your own empirical research, and report about your findings in our peer-reviewed academic journal: the Erasmus Journal of Social Media. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • State-of-the-art theory on the topic of this workshop.
  • Current research designs and methods to examine social media use.
Students have developed skills to:
  • Design and execute a small-scale empirical research
  • Report about the results of their research both in written and oral form.
  • Critically reflect on the constraints and societal implications of their research.
  • Constructively work as part of a team.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
De opleiding Psychologie van de Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam wordt gekenmerkt door probleemgestuurd onderwijs (PGO). Voor studenten zal dit een eerste kennismaking zijn met een onderwijsvorm waarin gewerkt wordt aan de hand van problemen binnen een kleine groep studenten (de onderwijsgroep). Om binnen dit onderwijssysteem goed te functioneren is een aantal vaardigheden, zoals het leiden van een gesprek, notuleren, informatie zoeken etc. van groot belang. Hieraan zal tijdens de training dan ook uitgebreid aandacht worden besteed. Het tweede belangrijk onderdeel van dit blok is een kennismaking met de sociale psychologie. De sociale psychologie is een deelgebied van de psychologie dat zich richt op hoe mensen elkaars gedrag, denken en voelen beïnvloeden. Je zult kennismaken met enkele klassieke thema's uit de sociale psychologie, zoals attributie van gedrag en attitudes. Een ander thema dat in meerdere problemen terugkomt, is de invloed van de groep op het individu. Groepen kunnen bijvoorbeeld een groot effect hebben op hoe goed wij presteren en hoe bereid wij zijn anderen te helpen. Ook passen wij ons gedrag sterk aan aan dat van de groep en kunnen we zelfs in een groep onze eigen identiteit verliezen. De sociale psychologie is een subdiscipline die vaak als leuk en interessant wordt ervaren. Dit is niet in de laatste plaats omdat deze zo dicht staat bij de ervaringen van elke dag en je bij uitstek laat nadenken over je eigen gedrag en dat van mensen om je heen.
Leerdoelen
Dit blok heeft de volgende zaken tot doel:
  • Basiskennis verwerven op het gebied van de sociale psychologie. Meer specifiek wordt kennis verworven rondom de volgende thema’s: hulpgedrag, attitudes en attitudeverandering, conformisme, sociale facilitatie en social loafing, deïndividuatie, gehoorzaamheid, sociale perceptie en attributie van gedrag, stereotypen en vooroordelen, en affiliatie en attractie.
  • Kennismaking met probleemgestuurd onderwijs (PGO) en training in vaardigheden die voor PGO belangrijk zijn, maar ook in algemene studievaardigheden. Dit zijn onder meer het werken met de Zevensprong, het gesprek leiden, notuleren, luisteren en samenvatten, feedback geven voor PGO. Meer algemeen wordt er aandacht besteed aan het leren zoeken van informatie, het bestuderen en integreren van de gevonden informatie, leerstijlen en taalvaardigheid.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding. For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['CA Malig Jedlicki, MSc', 'DR Geveke, MA', 'dr. N Oosterman']
text:
Inhoud This course focuses on the application of qualitative and quantitative research methods in the social sciences with a specific focus o on  arts, culture, and the media. The course focuses specifically on interview and survey research designs, however, discusses a wide range of quantitative and qualitative research methods, such as quantitative content analysis and experiments. The course furthermore familiarizes students with the full process involved in setting up a research project. During the course, students conduct a qualitative and quantitative research proposal, including creating research questions, operationalizing theoretical concepts and variables, and familiarise themselves with several methods of data collection and analysis. Other course activities involve practical assignments that lead to the development of research skills, research designs, and the critical evaluation of research reports.
  Leerdoelen
This course aims to familiarize students with the main research designs, methods, and techniques of social science research. It provides students with the necessary theoretical and practical knowledge of qualitative and quantitative research methodologies. It furthermore thoroughly discusses the theoretical and philosophical foundations of research paradigms underlining common methodological approaches. After completing this course, the students will be able to:
  • Develop a basic research design
  • Critically evaluate research reports
  • Draw theoretical and practical conclusions based on their review of the research literature
  • Present their research reviews and plans in a systematic and clear manner, both orally and in writing.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course introduces a wide range of perspectives on and methodological approaches to social science research. You will broaden your understanding of the philosophical, theoretical and ethical issues that matter in research, and will gain insight in the relationship between theory and research practice.
 
To gain insight into the research process—from an idea to research design to the production of new knowledge—the course pursues two avenues. One is to help you develop practical skills in data collection, data analysis and interpretation. The other is to present you with exemplars of research using qualitative and quantitative methods, innovative uses of data, natural experiments, and creative comparisons of competing hypotheses.
 
The course content covers general topics such as scientific integrity, epistemology, ethics, mixed methods and big data. In addition, attention is devoted to a range of so-called quantitative and qualitative research methods.
 
The course aims to provide you with the methodological foundation to further develop a specialized methodological toolkit and to develop and manage your own (thesis) research projects, and to acquire a set of skills that are sought by government and non-government agencies, and industry.

  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, you will be able to:
 
  • Explain the basic philosophical components to various methodologies in the social sciences (e.g. naturalism, constructivism);
  • Explain and apply the principles of ethics, privacy, and scientific integrity in social research;
  • Formulate answerable social scientific research questions, and identify which data and analyses best match those questions;
  • Explain principles of sampling;
  • Evaluate reports of empirical social science research, and assess to what extent they provide answers to the formulated research questions;
  • Understand the main approaches in qualitative data collection, i.e. interview, observation, documents, and combinations thereof (e.g. ethnography);
  • Understand and describe the main qualitative data analyzing techniques and its procedures to interpret the results, i.e. coding, content analysis, discourse analysis and grounded theory;
  • Understand the main approaches for quantitative data collection, i.e. survey design, experimental design and the use of secondary quantitative data;
  • Understand and describe techniques for analyzing quantitative data and interpret the results, i.e. various types of regression analysis.
  • Understand and describe the role of mixed methods and triangulation in sociological research;
  • Understand and describe the most important approaches in evaluation research (random control trials, quasi-experimental designs, realistic evaluation).

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['BC Fici, MA', 'dr. L Green', 'JA Seijbel, MSC MA', 'R van Lent, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Social and cultural history are two disciplines in field of history. They arose in the late nineteenth century in reaction to traditional schools of political, military, and diplomatic history. Initially, social history focused on the experiences of ordinary people and aimed to unearth the structural sources of historical change. Cultural history analyzed cultural expression (for instance art and architecture) and collective mentalities.
Since the “cultural turn” of the 1980s, cultural history has been influenced by post-modernism and post-colonialism. The fields of social and cultural history have also affected one another: for instance, social historians may engage in discourse analysis as part of their investigation into people's lived experiences; and cultural historians may examine the ways in which ordinary people challenged social constructs.

This course offers a broad introduction into the historiography, methods, and theories of both disciplines. After an introduction to social and cultural history, we focus on a number of themes, including travel, women, death, carnival, gender, and revolution.
  Leerdoelen Students are introduced to the disciplines of social and cultural history. They are acquainted with the history of both disciplines, they can critically assess works of social and cultural historiography and they can apply main theories and methods of both disciplines in academic papers.

Inhoud
Instructor: 
prof. dr. B.F. Heidergott (VU), dr. I.D. Lindner (VU).

 
Course content:
This course discusses the complex “connectedness” of social and economic relationships which is found in numerous incarnations: the rapid growth of the world-wide-web, the ease with which communication takes place, the fast spread of news and information as well as it’s impact on opinion formation and our society. 52 We start with an analytical toolbox of recognizing and analyzing patterns of network data. These tools show how to simplify complexity such as (1) global patterns (degree distributions, path lengths and the small world phenomenon, decomposition of networks), (2) segregation patterns (node types and homophily), (3) local patterns (clustering, transitivity, support) as well as (4) positions in networks (neighborhoods, centrality, influence measures). Next, we will discuss research on network formation and analyze how different model assumptions leave their characteristic footprint on network data. On the one hand, there is the large class of (growing) random networks models which explains a plethora of phenomena (rich-get-richer, small world, social media communication graphs). This class also serves as an important benchmark for identifying non-random properties of networks in which links are formed strategically (business relationships, co-author models). Hybrid models lie in between these two complementary approaches and are able to explain a large class of data (islands-connections model). Finally, we will discuss dynamic implications of the network structure in the context of (1) diffusion through networks (spread of information and diseases, financial contagion) as well as (2) learning and consensus formation on networks (imitation and social influence, wisdom of crowds). Key issues for both classes of dynamics are identifying key actors and their impact on aggregate behavior and beliefs. In particular, these methods allow to analyze the value of individuals in a collectivity (value of players in football teams).
Leerdoelen After completing the course, students will be able to:
  • Mathematical techniques for analyzing social network theory.
  • Classify social network data in terms of structural properties.
  • Identify the underlying incentives of network formation aggregate dynamics
  • Formulate a network model for analyzing selected phenomena in social networks.
  • Design policies to optimize outcomes in social network processes.
  • Reflect upon societal consequences of social network dynamics.
  • Present Research results.
